DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Televising of the House of Representatives

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask for leave of the House to make a statement concerning a determination by the Standing Committee on Televising of the House of Representatives.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present this report on behalf of the Committee as the Speaker, yourself, who is the Chairman of the Committee, excused himself from these deliberations. On 16 October 1991, the House agreed to authorise the live television broadcast and rebroadcast of its proceedings and of the public proceedings of its committees. It also appointed a committee to consider and determine the conditions that would apply to television broadcasts, whether there have been breaches of the conditions and, if so, what penalties would apply.

PARA.TAB: The conditions which were adopted were those set out in the report on the televising of the House of Representatives which was tabled in August last year. One of those conditions is:

SPEECH.PARA: Points of order and matters claimed to be points of order are not to be rebroadcast.

That is condition 7. It was suggested to the Chairman of the Committee that an item in the 7.30 Report of 2 April 1992 on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation breached the conditions. The members of the Committee have considered the suggestion and have viewed copies of the item. The Committee then sought comments from the ABC on the suggestion that it had breached the conditions.

PARA.TAB: Mr Manning, the controller of ABC news and current affairs, replied that the program's Federal political correspondent, Paul Lyneham, assured him that he—Mr Lyneham—had always sought to comply with the conditions for broadcasters. Mr Manning went on to suggest that Mr Lyneham would never contravene the conditions by rebroadcasting any material ruled by Mr Speaker to be a genuine point of order.

However, Mr Lyneham would not appear to be fully conversant with the condition which prohibits not only the rebroadcast of points of order, but also `matters claimed to be points of order'. The item rebroadcast not one but six points of order, or parts of a point of order, and has definitely breached the conditions.

The conditions suggested penalties which may apply to breaches of the conditions. For a first offence, it is withdrawal of the service to the station for three days. However, to penalise the ABC because of one program would seem unfair. The Committee considers that withdrawal of the service to the program rather than the network is more appropriate. Accordingly, the Committee determined the feed be provided by the Sound and Vision Office to the ABC on the understanding that the feed is not provided to the 7.30 Report for three sitting days with effect from today.

Televising has presented the Parliament with new challenges; it has also presented the television networks with opportunities to use footage of the proceedings. How the footage should be used is, in the main, for the program producers. However, the House has an interest and has set conditions. Those conditions cannot be ignored. It is with reluctance that the Committee has proposed the imposition of penalties; however, it had little option in this case. The Committee is prepared to discuss the guidelines and would welcome suggestions on the conditions rather than a disregard of them.
The following Bill was returned from the Senate without amendment:

PROCTEXT.PARA: Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 28 April, on motion by Mr Robert Brown:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak on the National Rail Corporation Agreement Bill 1992. This is a significant development. As the second reading speech of the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) indicates, the purpose of the Bill is to allow the Commonwealth to approve the shareholders' agreement relating to the establishment of the National Rail Corporation. This Bill involves significant restructuring of rail institutions, technology management and work practice. I agree that without such initiatives we will be unable to meet the community's current needs, let alone our future needs.

PARA.TAB: It is an important transport reform. Transport affects almost every area of Australia's economic and social activity, and it is extremely important to those of us in rural Australia. As a significant immediate cost, efficient transport is vital to the competitiveness of our economy. The test for the Government, and indeed the Parliament, will be to ensure that the full ambit of reforms are proceeded with while not leaving existing transport systems isolated, non-viable or inoperable. In 1989-90 the Industry Commission estimated that a more efficient land transport system alone, including a more efficient rail system, could realise an additional $6 billion in gross domestic product every year. Of this, $4.4 billion was attributable to rail.

One of the major reforms the industry must overcome is the inability of the existing systems to obtain their proper share of interstate freight, particularly on the eastern seaboard. In the main, this is due to the quality of the service that rail delivers. As the Minister's second reading speech states, terminals are inadequate; work and management practices need improvement; and reliability needs to be greatly improved. It is widely acknowledged that much of the problem lies in the fragmented management of our rail network.

I acknowledge that the Federal Government has positively promoted the revitalisation of the interstate freight rail system, and the coalition parties agree. This is part of a broader set of transport industry objectives within which each of the transport modes can undertake the task to which it is best suited. I emphasise, as the second reading speech emphasises, that it is not a matter of favouring one mode over another. What the Government should be striving for—and I believe it is—is an integrated rail system that will provide the community with an efficient and competitive land transport system. Therefore, I hope that the Minister and his Government understand what this means.

Australia is highly dependent on road transport. It is imperative that no action be taken to impede road transport's operations. That rail can be a success in Australia has been clearly demonstrated by the Commonwealth's own railway, the ANR Commission. AN has long practised the commercial approach that will be taken by the National Rail Corporation and its success is clear for all to see. The Industry Commission acknowledged this achievement in its recent rail report.

I join with the Minister in taking the opportunity to congratulate AN, its employees and management for the efforts that they have put in since its creation in 1978. Indeed, I expect that the skills and expertise built up by AN will prove to be a valuable asset for the National Rail Corporation.

We cannot, however, say the same about our State systems, which are fraught with outmoded work practices and undercapitalisation; they have a very low morale and are horribly in debt. I understand that the Australian-wide rail system lost $4 billion last year. It is well known in Victoria that the most profitable days that V/Line has are the days on which its employees are, in fact, on strike and the system is not operating.

The Commonwealth and all mainland States, except South Australia, signed an agreement establishing the National Rail Corporation at the Special Premiers Conference in July 1991. This means that, for the first time, interstate railway freight operations will be brought under one management structure. The NRC has been incorporated under the Companies Code as a strictly commercial corporation at arms length from government. The directors of the company have to comply with all relevant provisions of the company law, including the obligation to act in the interests of all shareholders. The company has been established for the purpose of conducting interstate and rail freight operations on a commercial basis.

The major aspects of this agreement indicate that the company has to operate on a strictly commercial basis with a financially viable corporate plan and be subject to the Trade Practices Act. The company will have access to the assets, including track infrastructure, necessary to achieve this commercial viability. It will operate under labour arrangements incorporated in an enterprise award, which reflects best practice in productivity standards through efficient work and manning practices, determined by the technical capacity of its equipment and commercial considerations.

It will also have the capacity to contract out activities where that is the most efficient approach. The company will provide access on a commercial basis to the NRC network and to terminal facilities for both private and public sector operators. It will have the capacity to provide services to governments, with the charging for such services being on a strictly commercial basis. The company will not be responsible, financially or in any other way, for redundancies that may arise in rail authorities resulting from its formation and the transfer of functions and assets to it. It will be subject to all rates, taxes and charges, will not have the shield of the Crown and will be treated as an ordinary incorporated company. Any new rail projects undertaken by the NRC will be subject to normal State and Federal environmental legislation.

Such a proposal warrants our support and the support of this Parliament. Such a standardised rail system is essential for Australia's economic and social well-being and should be supported. However, there are many concerns that I would like to raise today, particularly as they relate to the State of Victoria, and to my region in that State.

On 17 March a public meeting was held in the city of Horsham and the Chairman of the NRC, Mr Ted Butcher, attended. He gave an honest, blunt and concise explanation of his and NRC's charter. A number of very significant questions were answered. He clearly indicated that Victoria's State network would not be part of the Corporation's plan for a standard gauge national railway. He doubted that the intrastate system would offer a positive rate of return for the Corporation. He also dispelled doubts as to the route, indicating that it would follow the existing Melbourne-Adelaide line and be achieved by shifting lines from broad standard gauge. This, in itself, was a change from the plan the Corporation was originally speaking about in December: that the preferred route would be the most direct route.

Mr Butcher responded to many questions concerning the impact on our road transport system. He believed that the new freight system would halve the increase in road transport use. Current figures indicate that 10,000 vehicles travel this road interstate annually, with an increase to 20,000 by the year 2000 if rail is not improved. NRC calculations now suggest that this increase will drop to 15,000 if a new freight system is successful and B-doubles are operated effectively. The Corporation believes therefore that truck numbers will not reduce, but will increase at a slower rate.

We recognise this Federal Government decision. Its economic statement is strictly a mainline strategy with uniform linkages for capital cities and some crucial regional areas. My concern, however, is for the future of Victoria's domestic network and, particularly, for the bulk freight lines including the Dimboola-Yaapeet line, the Murtoa-Hopetoun line and the Ararat-Portland line.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very important.

—They are important lines, and these lines, and others such as the Mildura and Swan Hill lines, are vital to the maintenance of our State's viability, and to the maintenance of our agricultural and horticultural sectors and all those industries that depend particularly on bulk transport for their operation.

PARA.TAB: We must know the plans for these lines because we have learnt from bitter experience that any networks lost are not easily replaced and every loss reduces the viability of the total system itself. The two systems under the existing plans are incompatible. Mr Butcher, as Chairman of the Corporation, has a charter to which that Corporation must adhere, but this Parliament, this Government, and appropriate authorities in the States must urgently answer many more questions.

It is important to look at rail transport as an integrated system allowing diverse freight and passenger options and not assess the performance of one line or mode of transport directly against the other. The Victorian Government must respond immediately to its plans for the maintenance and upgrading of the State's rail network to mesh in with and complement this new standardised system. The plan must tell us what portion of the line may be duplicated. Will triple lines be an option? What portion can be built by shifting one line? What will be the maximum speed given to the selected route? What, for instance, is to become of the passenger services on the National Rail Corporation line? My preferred option for the three significant freight lines that I have already mentioned—the Yaapeet-Dimboola, Hopetoun-Murtoa and Ararat-Portland lines—is that they should be standardised. I believe this is the most simple and sensible proposal.

This matter is extremely important for the future of Australia. It is particularly important for the future of the State of Victoria where, as I have said, the existing network will be incompatible with the new standardised gauge. The harsh reality is that either the State Government standardises the State rail system now incorporating the main Melbourne-Adelaide line or many rural communities now dependent on rail must change holus-bolus over to road transport with all the implications that that brings. It is incomprehensible that a national rail authority, supported by the Federal Government and this Parliament, could embark on the national line without some complementary program to compensate for the resulting disruption in a State lacking the financial capacity for capital works on any scale. I support this legislation, but these questions require an answer, if possible by the Minister but more particularly by the State of Victoria which has a responsibility for ensuring that our rail system is adequate to meet the needs of future generations and future industries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to participate in this debate on the legislation to enable the establishment of a National Rail Corporation. I want to say at the outset that almost a century after Federation we still do not have a truly national rail freight system. Rail systems and industrial arrangements have been State based and State controlled. The fact that State rail systems met at State borders has, in the main, been regarded as incidental to our Federation's economic interests. Development of an efficient, competitive interstate rail system has never been a priority of the several State railway systems. The fact that 91 years after Federation we still have three separate gauge systems and a multiplicity of management and organisational systems across the country is clear evidence of this. Anyone who has had to deal with the individual rail fiefdoms and the anachronistic system of State railway commissioners in the past is well aware of the burdens that their style of management, their objectives, their powers and their policies have imposed upon their employees and upon this nation.

PARA.TAB: Railways have had a proud and loyal history. They have played a great role in the development of our nation, particularly in the earlier part of this century when railways displaced river transport and horse-drawn transport. Since World War II, they have to a large extent taken the transport task away from coastal sea transport.

Railway personnel—railway men, railway women—have a proud history of loyalty to their system and to their organisations. Many have worked for decades in poorly paid, lonely tasks, often unpleasant tasks, with little recognition of the nature of the work that they have to do. They have had little opportunity for training and little opportunity for career advancement, yet they have all been barrelled and lumped together in the definition of the railway system. Certainly there have been sections within the railway systems that have been better paid and better rewarded, but many railway men and women have been poorly paid, and their efforts and their isolation have not been adequately recognised.

In the past it used to be that many young men in this country aspired to become engine drivers, loco drivers. The loco drivers were the aristocrats of the railway system and in yesteryear they were the equivalent of the Boeing 747 captains of today. They have had a proud involvement with their industry. They feel proud of their industry, and they deserve better treatment than they have received over recent decades.

In the process of change it is essential, therefore, that railway men and women be consulted and be involved in the changes that are to take place. If we are to get the best from the railway system, we need to take advantage of the expertise of those people who work at grassroots level, who are actually involved in providing the services, and to ask them for ideas, as we do when we are talking about award restructuring, workplace rearrangements and operational practice changes. The people who do the jobs need to be consulted and involved. Most certainly, when we are talking about a rapid change in the number of positions and the nature of their tasks, the families of those railway men and women need to be involved and consulted. There needs to be a great deal of sensitivity and care for them in respect of the impact upon their lives and their careers when we move to the establishment of the National Rail Corporation.
In his second reading speech, the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) said:
One of the major problems in the rail industry is the inability of the existing systems to obtain their proper share of interstate freight, particularly on the eastern seaboard.

This is due in the main to the quality of the service that rail delivers. Terminals are inadequate, work and management practices need improvement, and reliability needs to be greatly improved. It is widely acknowledged that much of the problem lies in the fragmented management of rail.

SPEECH.PARA: At this stage, I want to try to remove some of the mythology about the transport task in this country, that rail is good and road is bad, or road is good and rail is bad. It is not a case of one being good and the other bad; it is a case of each complementing the other. Out in the marketplace, in a large share of the transport task rail has a natural advantage and in a large share of it road has a natural advantage.

PARA.TAB: The reality is that 80 per cent of goods transported move distances of less than 100 kilometres. I read a good deal about greater use being made of rail in moving goods from ports. Again the reality is that in Sydney and Melbourne 88 per cent of containers finish up in the metropolitan area, and clearly rail is not suited to that task; it is rubber-tyred transport that performs that short-haul task. So it is not a case of one being good and one being bad—let us get rid of that mythology—it is a case of each form of transport performing that task in which it has a natural advantage and for which it is best suited socially, economically and technically.

I do not want to go through a description again of what is involved in the Bill, because the Minister has covered that in his second reading speech, but I do want to mention the financial and industrial objectives of the new National Rail Corporation. It has been given a timetable of breaking even within three years and becoming totally self-supporting after five years. The Minister says the meeting of this target will, in itself, be a major achievement. It certainly will be a major achievement. It is a daunting objective.

I do not know what `break square' or `breaking even' means. I think we need to have that spelt out more clearly. Is it breaking even in respect of operating costs or some proportion of overhead costs, or is it approaching break square in terms of expenditure and revenue? I think that needs to be spelt out so that there are not unrealistic objectives built up and, as this process of change in the establishment of the NRC proceeds, so that we do not find ourselves a few years down the track having it pointed to as not having achieved its objectives.

The renegotiation of the industrial arrangements to have an enterprise agreement across the National Rail Corporation is, in itself, also a daunting task. It is an essential task, but a daunting one. There should not be any exaggerated expectations of what is to be achieved. People who will be affected should be involved, should be consulted, about the change that needs to be made. I am heartened and encouraged by the fact that at the top level of the ACTU there is very strong support for this objective. I just want to make the point that the objectives that have been set are very difficult to achieve. I want to see them achieved, but let us not underestimate the magnitude of the difficulties involved in achieving those tasks.

Currently the interstate rail freight deficits run at about $375m a year. That is more than $1m a day. Every day of the year the taxpayers of this country are handing over more than $1m to meet deficits on interstate rail freight. That effectively is a subsidy from taxpayers to commercial interests. It is what I call commercial welfare. That alone, the easing of the burden on taxpayers, is one reason why we have to press on with this objective. There will need to be ongoing vigilance to see that the timetable is adhered to, that the objectives are adhered to and that the organisational arrangements that are essential to this initiative are progressed.
I would have liked to see greater utilisation of the skills of AN. The Minister paid tribute to the achievements of the Australian National Railways Commission. In his speech he said:

That rail can be a success in Australia has been clearly demonstrated by the Commonwealth's own railway, the Australian National Railways Commission. AN has long practised the commercial approach and will be taken by the National Rail Corporation, and its success is clear for all to see. The Industry Commission acknowledged the achievements in its recent rail report.

SPEECH.PARA: He took the opportunity to congratulate AN, its employees and its management on what they have done since its establishment in 1978. Indeed, he said:
I expect that the skills and expertise built up by AN will prove to be a valuable asset of the National Rail Corporation.

Let me add to that my congratulations, my commendation, in respect of the achievements of Australian National. It has been a long, hard slog. AN's employees have been involved in a great deal of trauma, as have the communities where services have been withdrawn in South Australia and where changes have been made. It is not easy, whether it be Mount Gambier, Victor Harbor, some of the country towns or wheat towns of South Australia or Port Augusta, Port Pirie or Peterborough. In all of those areas people have given their all to the improvement of Australian National.

PARA.TAB: I am disappointed that greater opportunity is not being taken to utilise those skills and that commitment. Australian National is the only railway system in this country that has a national ethos. It is the only railway system that has a truly commercial ethos. It is the only railway system that knows what national and interstate rail freight is about, because most of its revenue comes from that activity.

The great difficulty with State railway systems has been that interstate rail freight revenue has been a minor proportion of their total revenue. It is not too late for Australian National to be closely involved and for the successes of Australian National and its expertise to be utilised to a greater extent.

I particularly want to pay tribute to the people of Port Augusta. I mentioned Port Pirie and Peterborough. Those three towns in the Iron Triangle, but particularly Port Augusta, sitting astride the north-south, east-west axis of the interstate rail freight system of this country, have made a great effort and placed a great deal of trust in this Government to ensure that they remain a major rail centre. As an individual and as a member of this House, I pay tribute to them for their cooperation and support through the difficult times in the earlier years in helping to get AN to the point where it is now.

When I talk about consultation, I am talking about consultation right down to workshop level, to the fellows who work in the foundry, who work on the tools and who sweep the buildings. It is at that level that insecurity and worry for their families about change need to be addressed. It can be addressed; it is not an impossible task. I emphasise that because we owe it to those people in the railway system and in those State railway systems that will be affected by the establishment of the National Rail Corporation to address it.

The One Nation package announced considerable investment in the railway system. There was the standard gauge connection from Acacia Ridge in Brisbane; an investment of $82m which was long overdue for the upgrading of the Sydney-Brisbane line; and an investment of $110m, almost 20 years overdue, for the upgrading of the Sydney-Melbourne line. The experience and behaviour of governments, industry and State rail systems on the Sydney-Melbourne line is a clear example of what inertia and State interests can do to what is an essential national service.

The BTE report of 1975 pointed to a very positive cost-benefit result in the upgrading of the Sydney-Melbourne line. It pointed to a possible reduction in journey time of something considerably less than that being forecast now, something approaching seven to eight hours, virtually aiming for a halving of the journey time between Sydney and Melbourne. A halving of the journey time means a doubling of the capacity of that line. That sat on a shelf during the period of the Fraser Government because everybody became distracted with the proposed electrification of the Sydney to Melbourne line. It was a nonsense to begin with and it remained a nonsense, but it took us seven years to get that out of the system.

Then in 1984, as we started trying to get the States thinking nationally about rail freight systems—we established the national rail freight group, I think in 1985, to try to get orientation towards the national economic interest—along came the VFT proposal. The VFT was always an indulgence and I would not put a rotten dollar of my money in it, but it served to distract the Government's attention away from what needed to be done, that is, the upgrading of the Sydney-Melbourne line, the most important link in the rail service of this country. So 14 years were lost by distractions with grand schemes rather than getting on with the basic issue that needed to be addressed and carried out, the upgrading of the Sydney-Melbourne line.

We need to look also at port investment and at interstate rail investment. Where are the railways going? Where are port movements going? I will look quickly at the figures that are available. We hear a lot said about trucks between Sydney and Melbourne. There will always be trucks between Sydney and Melbourne because there are services—high value, low volume cargoes—that are better carried out by trucks. The market will determine that. If we have road, rail and sea, each performing at peak efficiency and each performing the task to which they are best suited, it is then up to the market, through a soundly based pricing or rating system, to determine who gets what share. Each of the three has a natural advantage, particularly road and rail.

When we look at the movement of containers in 1990-91 between the various major capitals, we find that in that period overall some 4.4 million tonnes of goods were moved by containers and that 1.1 million tonnes of containers of shipping origin were moved. Already integrated services are provided, and part of the objective of this exercise is to have an integrated road, rail and sea service. Already there is substantial movement of containers as part of a total shipping journey by rail between our capitals, between Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne.

Looking at the movement south from New South Wales to Victoria, 74,000 tonnes were moved in containers by rail in 1990-91. On the northbound journey, V/Line to New South Wales, 122,000 tonnes were moved. From Queensland down to New South Wales there was a vast difference. The tonnage of containers for domestic use, land side use, was 256,000 tonnes. But the movement of containers south from Queensland to New South Wales was 236,000 tonnes—almost a match in the quantity of cargo moving by land as part of an overall sea journey. Similarly, if we look at the other figures—and I do not have time to go through all of them—I simply make the point that most container movement by rail is in respect of only a land journey. About the equivalent of a quarter of those figures are journeys of containers as part of an overall shipping movement.

I have mentioned the ports and I have mentioned the investment in the ports. We hear a lot of talk about land bridging, whether it is east-west land bridging or north-south land bridging from Alice Springs to Darwin, from Darwin to Alice Springs, or to points in the south such as Adelaide or Melbourne. Again, I think that is something that is way in the future. When we talk about land bridging, we are talking about a ship dropping goods off at a port and then the goods continuing east-west by rail. The theory is that all ships eastbound will unload at Fremantle and cargo will go by rail for the rest of the journey, and that all ships westbound will unload in Sydney or Melbourne and cargo will go westward by rail.

For land bridging to work, it must offer a substantial commercial advantage over existing services. The fact is that it does not. This can be compared with the alternatives in the US, where land bridging ships drop off goods on the west coast of the US which then travel by rail across the US to a major market in the mid-west. There are markets generating in the mid-west going to the east coast of the US. The alternatives are to go down around the Panama Canal, which is a much longer journey, or even via Cape Horn, which is a much, much longer journey.

That does not apply in the case of east-west movement of containers in Australia. In fact, the journey distances are about the same. Unless there is a commercial advantage, it will not happen. I do not think it will happen. It ought not happen unless it is soundly based commercially; it has to be the right commercial thing to do.

The story is different for north-south land bridging from Brisbane, Sydney, Melbourne and possibly Adelaide. The upgrading of the port services into Melbourne and Dynon and the road link to the Dynon goods yard will facilitate movement of containers in and out of Melbourne and connection to the rail system. Similarly, southbound Acacia Ridge-Fisherman Islands standard gauge link will mean that there will be the potential for ships to unload at Brisbane and for the containers to then continue the rest of their journey southbound, regardless of where they are going—Sydney, Melbourne or Adelaide—by rail. That is already happening and it will happen more.

As we have a global shipping service that concentrates on the big 4,000-container vessels going around the world east or west and as Australia's shipping services feed up and down from the major ports, particularly Singapore, that means that the ships which will be visiting Australian ports will be ships of smaller size and poorer configuration which are less efficient. That is the nature of the world market. But it means that, with an upgraded Sydney-Brisbane line and an upgraded Sydney-Melbourne line, the Brisbane rail system will have the potential to play a much more effective role for the right commercial reasons. It will offer better rates, better service or both. That is how it ought to happen.

The National Rail Corporation has the potential to see that improvement. The National Rail Corporation, if it is properly managed, properly oriented and moves with speed in its establishment and development, will be able to make a substantial addition and improvement to the efficiency not only of our interstate movement of containers, but also of our international movement of containers and bring a considerable economic benefit to this country. For those reasons, I have tried to bring the National Rail Corporation into the national context. It has a very difficult task ahead of it. I wish it well and I commend the Bill to the House. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson Mr M.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) is at the table. He was recently in Ballarat, and he knows what a very vibrant city it is and what great potential it has, with a bit of input from everyone across the board: both community and government.

PARA.TAB: My friend and colleague the shadow Minister for land transport, the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), discussed the generalities of this matter in the House yesterday. I do not intend to do that and I make no apologies for being extremely parochial in my comments today. The NRC and the question of Ballarat's future are obviously of enormous relevance and significance to the Ballarat electorate and especially to those in Ballarat. It is of great significance to those many men and women who have served with the railways in my region for many years and to those who wish to retain their jobs, as well as to those who wish to get some of the advantages which may flow from this proposal.

There is also another group whom this concerns, and that is the many men and women who travel from Ballarat to Melbourne and return every day. They are people who have seen the light and who wanted to get out of Melbourne. I hope that my colleague the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), who is at the table, will excuse me for saying so, but I really cannot blame them for trying to get out of Melbourne and move to the magnificent centre of Ballarat and its districts. I say that somewhat tongue in cheek, but the problems they potentially face under one of the options, or a number of the options, are of great significance to them. That also includes the option of Ballarat-Melbourne via Geelong. There are a number of options in that regard.

I am a member of the Ballarat National Rail Support Committee, which has been very active in this matter. I will read from the submission put to Mr Ted Butcher, the Chairman, in a document dated 12 February. This submission relates to three matters. Part 1 is `Ballarat Railway Workshops: A Profile', part 2 is `Ballarat Freight/Container Terminal Strategy', and part 3 is `Passenger Rail Services Between Ballarat & Melbourne'. It is impossible for me to provide all honourable members with a copy of this report; therefore, I will quote selected parts from it. Part 1 says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Ballarat Railway Workshops continues Ballarat's proud tradition of involvement in the manufacture of locomotives and other rolling stock—a tradition which began in the 1870's when the first steam locomotive was built at the Phoenix Foundry.

The Phoenix Foundry, which started making machinery for mining companies in 1856, was responsible for the manufacture of 352 steam engines for Victorian Railways. At its peak, the foundry employed 700 men and produced more than 20 different classes of locomotive. However, the subsequent development of the Newport Workshops resulted in the closure of the Phoenix Foundry in 1906.

Within 10 years, Newport was struggling to satisfy the demand for engines. This led to calls for the establishment of further workshops elsewhere in Victoria to take the pressure off Newport. In response, the Ballarat City Council offered to make a financial contribution if the Government would consider establishing an engine building factory at Ballarat. Although the Government declined the offer of financial assistance, it did agree to build workshops at Ballarat.
Completed in 1917, the Ballarat Workshops opened with 100 men repairing trucks and locomotives. The first steam locomotive was built in 1919 and by 1922, 13 locomotives had been manufactured.
Quite obviously, our bona fides in relation to rail right throughout Australia are very genuine. The submission continues:

From its inception the Ballarat Workshops has been a major manufacturing centre for Victorian Railways and, more recently, the Public Transport Corporation. In line with developments in rail transport, the main function of the workshops has changed and diversified over its history.

After the earlier concentration on the manufacture of steam locomotives, it became a major repairer of carriages and wagons in the 1940's. By the 1950's, the Railway Workshops was producing the large bogie type wagons, such as cable carriers and louvre vans. This continued into the early 1980's, when the conversion of purpose built wagons to three-pak container wagons, as well as various other wagon modifications, were added to the types of work undertaken at the Workshops.

Following a review in the early 1980's, strategies were developed to modernise all rail workshops and make them more competitive in the open market. It was decided that the Ballarat Workshops would become the Public Transport Corporation's manufacturing and commercial centre. The emphasis would be on quality.
Indeed, quality is something that Ballarat has a very proud history of. The submission continues:

To this end, all the old buildings to be retained were refurbished, and those no longer required were demolished. Some new buildings were erected and an upgrading of plant and equipment was also carried out.

The Ballarat Workshops is one of the few workshops which meets the Australian Standard (AS3903) on Quality. It is also one of even fewer workshops which has gained Defence Department supply approval. Consequently, tenders for work have been successful with the State Electricity Commission, VicRoads, Clyde Engineering, Comeng, the Australian Army and South Australian Railways.

A large amount of work is currently being undertaken. It was my privilege and pleasure to be given a tour of the Ballarat North workshops three months ago. On a personal note, although I was unable to come to terms with being called `comrade', I did enjoy my time in the workshops. It is now a very high quality operation. The railway unions in Ballarat, the Ballarat City Council, the Ballarat Regional Board, others and I are anxious to ensure not only that that work continue but also that we get a slice of the action—for want of a better word—out of the proposals coming through this Bill.

PARA.TAB: I know that the Minister is also aware of our very great desire to participate in that. I am not saying that we should participate simply because it is Ballarat. We are not resting on our laurels; there is no doubt that it is justified on the quality of work we are producing there. I am very proud of the work that is coming from Ballarat. It is imperative that we not only retain that work, but that we also be given the opportunity to tender after the process is finished in due course. I have no doubt that we will tender successfully for that work.
Regrettably, the Ballarat work force is now down to 280 employees, which is a significant reduction from its peak of some 700 employees during the 1960s. The submission continues:

SPEECH.PARA: However the Workshops continue to be a valuable training ground for the Ballarat workforce. Over the last decade, more than 100 apprentices have been employed across a range of skilled trades; including boilermakers, blacksmiths, electricians, carpenters, fitter and turners, painters and upholsterers. Many successful Ballarat businesses are now run by people who gained their basic training as local Workshop apprentices.

If I may diverge slightly to another matter, what we have seen in Ballarat over the last 10 or 15 years, regrettably, is a withdrawal of those exceptionally skilled trades men and women that Ballarat was renowned for. I have been told on numerous occasions that if someone from Ballarat applied for a job—I am sure the Minister would be interested in this—outside Ballarat, whether he was trained at the workshops or at one of the other large manufacturers, this was really a ready entree to a job anywhere within Australia. The skill levels were so high that one really did not need to sit down and do any sort of test. If a person had been trained in Ballarat, then he had been trained properly and, therefore, would move straight into a position.

PARA.TAB: The quite horrific decline that I have seen in my region over the last 15 years has had a dramatic impact. The skill levels of those who have been trained in Ballarat have not in any way reduced but it causes me a great deal of distress to see that the numbers of people being trained are reducing quite significantly. As you may be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, I am fourth or fifth generation and my two-year old son and family are either fifth or sixth generation—I have not checked up. I am very close to the region and it breaks my heart to see what is happening. But, in saying that, I still believe that the situation can be addressed with a positive attitude. The sorts of things I am talking about are enormous skill levels, with a very vibrant manufacturing sector. I think that, if we use our brains, make the right decisions and have a commitment right across the board, we can return to that former situation. I now turn to the freight strategy. On this proposal, we state:

With adequate facilities, it would be possible to attract all current containers to a road/rail terminal. This would require a terminal located in the outlying area with a gantry facility, as well as three phase power. With three phase power alone, V/Line could attract 3,000 or more containers from McCain Foods. Currently these containers are road freighted ex Geelong.

It is therefore proposed that the current rail/road container terminal and the fast track small freight terminal at the Ballarat Freightgate in the centre of the city be transferred to the "Redan" line, which is a spur off the main Melbourne-Adelaide line.
The land required is available and the terminal would complement the siding currently under negotiation with the Mars company for its Australian distribution warehouse.

SPEECH.PARA: The plans are fairly well down the track—that is perhaps a poor choice of words, given our present debate. The plans are under way and there is a commitment from local municipalities to address that.

PARA.TAB: I have not seen a full copy of the Booz-Allen and Hamilton report to the PTC. The Minister might have a copy that I could obtain from his office in due course. I gather the options canvassed in that report are as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.standard gauge Yaapeet, Hopetoun, Portland lines
2.dual gauge west main line Ararat-Dimboola
3.dual gauge Ballarat-North Geelong, standard gauge Yaapeet and Hopetoun
4.alternative service west grain lines
5.mainline via Geelong, dual gauge west main line Ararat-Dimboola

My friend and colleague the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) and I initially discussed this question on an extremely bumpy ride on the plane coming up on Monday night. We could not eat, we could not have a glass of soda water, so we were actively involved in discussions about this matter. We had further discussions in the corridor yesterday. I know that the honourable member for Corio is as concerned as I am about the final decisions that are made in relation to this matter. I do not mean only the freight question, but also the passenger side and the freight link-ups. They have very long term ramifications for Geelong and Ballarat. If we do not get it right now, I have no doubt that another opportunity will never be presented to us, because the infrastructure costs will be so prohibitive that they would not, in my view, be changed in your lifetime, Mr Deputy Speaker, or my lifetime or the Minister's lifetime. So the decisions we make at this stage in relation to this matter are extremely important.

PARA.TAB: I was an active and keen supporter of the decision that was ultimately made by Mr Butcher as to where the route should be. I am not saying that I have necessarily cooled on that option, or that decision, in effect, but I have great concern that if we are potentially going to cut the State in half—and again this is a matter that the honourable member for Corio and I have discussed—the long term ramifications of cutting the State in half with grain lines, et cetera, are matters that I do not think can be simply glossed over with the statement, `Well, we will look at that and address it in due course'.

The PTC report specifically addresses those proposals, but there are still a number of options. I want to ensure that those options maximise and retain as much as possible of that transport infrastructure that country Victoria has relied on for a lot longer than I have been on this earth. I presume that that reliance will be there. I will be an active pursuer of that reliance gaining pace, as opposed to reducing, because, if that infrastructure were to break down, the ramifications for our road network would be fairly disastrous. I do not believe that any government of any political persuasion is going to have the funds to repair or replace that road network. We have to be very careful that the ramifications of the decisions that are made now are looked at extremely carefully.

I have not at this stage had the opportunity to read in detail the comments made on Monday by the Premier of Victoria in relation to the regional development plans, but for many years Ballarat has been targeted as a growth centre. It is a growth centre that I certainly want to see eventuate. Leaving aside the potential costs of infrastructure that will obviously be associated with an enormously expanded population, there is also the question of relocation to Ballarat. But of equal importance is the opportunity for Ballarat people to live in Ballarat and work in Melbourne. I presume the honourable member for Corio will let me know if I am wrong, but I presume that thousands have accepted the option to travel from Geelong and some of those coastal areas to work in Melbourne. As I said before, obviously the quality of life question would determine that sort of movement away.

If the Ballarat-Melbourne passenger service is put at any risk or, given the pressures of modern day living, if it becomes a non-viable option time-wise, my great concern is that the potential for growth in the Ballarat region is going to be significantly diminished. I know the Minister is well aware of my views on this matter as I have discussed those views with him, as have a large number of others, and he is aware of my concerns and the concerns of others that we retain for Ballarat, as a minimum, an efficient and reliable passenger service, because without that Ballarat will not develop to its full potential.

I believe there is enormous opportunity for the community of Ballarat to attract a significant population increase by making all those options available to those who are presently crowding themselves into metropolitan Melbourne. Having been down there last Friday and having seen that haze hanging over an otherwise very pretty city, I can understand that they would be pretty anxious to get out of the place, but they will only be anxious to get out if all those things are in place and if it is a viable option, economically, time-wise, quality of life-wise, to move from those areas to Ballarat. In my view, it will only be viable if we can retain a rail network that is delivering those efficiencies, and is delivering them effectively.

I have addressed most of the matters I wish to canvass today. I compliment my shadow colleague for the matters that he raised yesterday. I am sure that they have not been lost on the Minister. There is no doubt that if we are going to retain and expand what is a desperately needed rail system throughout this country we have to start doing things a hell of a lot smarter than we have done in the past. It has to be an efficient service that can justify itself economically.

As Mr Butcher has said, he will only make decisions on the basis that they are commercial decisions and they are economically viable. I applaud him for approaching the matter in that manner, and I am sure the Minister is equally keen to see that happen, as is the shadow Minister for land transport, the honourable member for Wannon. We cannot carry into the next decade or the next century the inefficiencies that have ravaged the rail systems throughout Australia, both at an Australian and a State level. I accept and support the Bill, but I wish that those very real concerns that I have from my region are taken into consideration when the decisions are made at the end of the day.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak on the National Rail Corporation Agreement Bill, I express some pleasure at the opportunity to speak on a national initiative in respect to rail services. Last night I heard the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Beale) talking about the fact that it took 10 years for this Government to get around to doing something about the national rail services and the need for corporatisation. The father of the honourable member for Bruce was a member of this Parliament some 40 or 50 years ago. At that stage only one initiative had been taken on rail services since Federation, and that was the building of Transrail by the Fisher Government in about 1910 or 1911. It opened in about 1917. When dealing with our rail problems we need to go beyond that back to the colonies. I suppose our present legacy is a legacy of the interference of the British Colonial Office in decisions which should have been made on the basis of the needs of Australia rather than by someone in Whitehall or wherever he happened to be located.

PARA.TAB: The history is well known. New South Wales decided to build rail services at a certain level; Victoria actually started to build rail services; New South Wales did not build any but changed its mind. The Colonial Office agreed, ordered the Victorians to change again, and did it a third time without New South Wales putting down one sleeper.

On the third occasion the Victorians said, `I think that's enough. We are spending our money. You're just making decisions on the basis of what you might do'. So we ended up with a piebald rail system; it was inefficient and inappropriate. But this did not really show up as such until 40 or 50 years ago. The transhipping and such were not as important as they are now. We had ports everywhere; we had coastal shipping. The movement of freight on an interstate basis was not necessarily by rail. For the benefit of the honourable member for Bruce, I might say that this Government is the first Labor Government in peacetime since Federation to have been in office for a period longer than four years. If one has to negotiate anything complex with the States, four years is not going to work. But there were some opportunities for the conservative governments had they wished to take them.

The most significant move in this direction took place during the period of the Whitlam Government. It sought to take over the State rail services which were then ridden with debt, as they are now; they were inefficient; and in the case of Victoria, and I think all other States for that matter, one has to say that they were not having appropriate money spent on them to modernise and maintain them or to enable them to compete in what was fast developing; that is in the areas of competence and expertise of rail services which were not as pick-up carriers, but rather as bulk long term haulers.

I think it is also grossly unfair, if not improper, to try to make comparisons, as some do, between rail services in Europe or the United States and Australia, and more particularly between Japan and Australia. I heard someone make a statement on how, in certain circumstances, the European rail services are able to operate with much higher efficiencies and lower losses than Australia can. The Japanese system is always held up as an example. I think that in 150 miles in Japan there are seven cities with over two million people. It can run a passenger service. In fact, air transport is uneconomic. The only two cities in Australia in similar circumstances are 600 miles or 1,000 kilometres apart. There are virtually no large cities in between to provide pick-up and put-down services. There is no comparison between the economics of those sorts of operations.

I think the charter of the national rail service is too narrow. I think the original Booz-Allen report relating to the Melbourne-Adelaide standardisation—and it is arguable whether it is necessary at all, but nevertheless the decision has been made that it shall be built—was sloppy and incompetent. It took account only of the narrowest view; that is, what would be the outcome if the National Rail Corporation were able to do what it wished and ignored the consequences of what it did? `Ignored the consequences' is the crucial point.

The honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson) has already mentioned the severing of Victoria by the standardisation of the Melbourne-Adelaide line. A lot of the network of rail services in Victoria was built to sell land in Melbourne for land speculators in the 1880s. This is a problem which the Victorian taxpayer has lived with for 100 years. There have been some people in this Parliament, of very recent vintage, whose fortunes were founded on that land speculation and the building of railways. There are three railways lines up into the Mallee, where one would have well done, even in the 1880s. But the land prices were good once the railway line was put in.

Leaving that aside, Victoria is divided by the Melbourne-Adelaide line. It goes north-west through Victoria to Serviceton. All of the services which cart wheat, for instance—which is the major freight element of rail services in that area—cross or travel on the proposed standard gauge line for some period. They are all five foot three lines and none of them could be economically changed to a standard gauge line with any prospect whatsoever of commercial viability. The original Booz-Allen report leaves the Victorian Government to bear the total cost of that.

The honourable member for Ballarat has mentioned the Melbourne-Ballarat proposal. In the original Booz-Allen report, the Melbourne-Ballarat proposal would have discontinued all passenger services, commuter services and others between Melbourne and Ballarat. It ignores the extensive and long gradients, and the time taken between points where changeovers can take place. It is a computer model without any actual input into the total traffic. Its viability is based on the elimination of all non-interstate traffic. At the moment, the interstate traffic travelling between Melbourne and Adelaide uses two routes—not one. The up trains are the ones going down to Melbourne. The up trains would normally go through Ballarat and down through Bacchus Marsh. It is downhill; it is quick; it is easy; and it is shorter.

The trains which are carrying freight to Adelaide normally travel in the small hours of the morning. They go through Geelong, Maroona and on their way to South Australia. They can carry at least one-third more freight because of the lack of grades, and it is much faster. This is not taken account of in the Booz-Allen report. As the honourable member for Ballarat mentioned, it has not taken account of the fact that there is now a large commuter service provided by the Victorian railways, VicRail, in the areas out of Melbourne where people have chosen to go and live because of the lifestyle effects. From everyone's point of view, it is better that they commute by rail rather than having more buses on the road.

If, in fact, the consequences of the Booz-Allen report were to put that traffic which they are eliminating from rail on the road, we would have to restructure almost every major road in northern Victoria, north-western Victoria and the Mallee. There would be no way that wheat traffic could get to Portland or Geelong for shipment overseas. It is a straight barrier. I do not think that is competence. I think that should be drawn attention to. I do not think one can say, `If we take over these lines and to hell with the consequences, it will pay'. That is not a proper consequence.

I do not believe that Geelong or Ballarat—and I differ with the honourable member for Ballarat on this—is going to gain one iota or one cent of commercial activity as a result of these lines passing through. What will happen in Ballarat when the interstate freight goes through—if there is a guard on it, and there may not be—is that they may wave to someone on the side of the line, but they certainly will not stop. Similarly, the trains already go through Geelong in the middle of the night, and 99 per cent of people in Geelong do not even know it. There is certainly no commercial benefit. They will not have any effect on the Ballarat workshops, although there are other factors which have been built in largely by the Victorian Government which will give some work to those workshops.

I agree that Ballarat, Bendigo and Newport have been important training grounds, as was Telecom until a former Liberal Government decided that in future it should not subsidise the training of apprentices. But those three institutions have trained half of the Victorian apprentices and the best tradesmen in that State over a number of years. It has been a cost to the Victorian railways and the taxpayers of Victoria which has been borne because it had certain benefits to the State, and those benefits will not flow with commercialisation.

I go back to the National Rail Corporation. There are currently three propositions; none of them can be divorced from the need to deal with the problem of moving wheat in Victoria and other freight which comes from Mildura, Maryborough, Hopetoun, Warracknabeal, Echuca and those areas. They all cross the standard gauge line; they all use lines which could not be incorporated in the National Rail Corporation's proposals. It seems to me that one cannot have those lines converted to the standard gauge. Whilst it is nice, it is enormously expensive and there is no justification at this time in our history to spend that sort of money. Certainly, they could not be commercially viable.

There are two routes that I understand are now possible. The Victorian Government has given an undertaking that it will finance the conversion to Portland and the conversion from Ballarat-Geelong. I say that on its own Ballarat-Geelong is useless. It would be an absolute waste of money and an incompetent decision. Built into a Geelong-Ballarat-Melbourne loop it probably is a reasonable proposition, although it is further, with no real benefit to the National Rail Corporation.

If those lines are converted, they must add to the cost of carting wheat, and there is no return for it. I think there is little necessity for that. If a separate broad gauge line was provided between Horsham and Ararat, which is a distance of about 90 miles, and if there was a separate broad gauge line between Ballarat and Geelong, we could cater for all the broad gauge lines in western Victoria. There is provision on the Ballarat-Geelong route for a double line. There was a double line between Ballarat and Geelong until 1931, but it was pulled up to save money. Wheat going to Portland and Geelong would be able to feed onto the broad gauge line somewhere between Horsham and Ararat and it could go down the Maroona or the Portland lines to the ports of shipment. That option seems to me to be quite viable. It is not an extensive length of railway line involved. It also opens up the possibility of the movement of the sands to the north of Horsham which have been mentioned.

The other proposition is that of Geelong-Ballarat. If a broad gauge line is maintained there, the Maryborough and Swan Hill lines are automatically connected to the port of Geelong, and they have a course of action which will allow them to operate without extensive cost. Because Geelong is a major port and a major bulk port, it should be connected into a standard gauge network. The proposition that the standard gauge line should go from Melbourne through Geelong to Ballarat is the most politically accepted, even though it may not be the most commercially viable. Certainly Melbourne-Ballarat as a direct route would be an incompetent decision, and the cost of it would be enormous. It would cut off the northern and north-western parts of Victoria from Melbourne because none of them have standard gauge facilities which would enable them to join the Melbourne line and utilise that line.

Some of those areas may have alternatives through Bendigo. But once we put in a standard gauge link which goes through Ballarat and chops out the Ballarat link as well, there is virtually nowhere to go. The trains would have to come down through Geelong and back up to Melbourne, or something like that. I believe the most practical option—not necessarily the most commercially viable—is for the Victorian Government and the National Rail Corporation to come to some arrangement with respect to the Geelong-Ballarat link with Melbourne for national freight. It is slightly less in grade, and therefore there would be greater speed, and there is the prospect of greater loads because the Bacchus Marsh bank is one of the worst in Australia. It certainly should not be tolerated on a main line, but we are not about to alter it.

I believe that if we are going to use that line for the purposes we are now talking about, many of the viaducts would have to be renewed at enormous cost. Anyone who has travelled on trains on the loop out of Bacchus Marsh, as I have, will know that it is awfully slow going, especially on diesels. It takes 50 minutes to get from Bacchus Marsh to Ballan, and that is only about 10 miles. Having said that, I think I should say that there is a real need to pursue a policy whereby rail freight is seen as national freight—and I do not only mean interstate freight—where the alternative of rail is adequately available for bulk freight carriage in Australia.

We have heard a lot of pie in the sky things about railways overseas. We have heard about how we can hire trains and such. I would like to put something to the Minister that I have been suggesting for a long time. In my maiden speech in this place just over 24 years ago I mentioned the need for a standard gauge link between Geelong and Melbourne. At that stage daily trains were running through to the Ford Motor Co. In my earlier career I had worked at Wodonga, where we pushed trucks in and out of sidings at Albury all day so that they could be transhipped by inland wharfies. It was one of the most wasteful exercises one could imagine. The situation has improved since then, but the transhipping still has to take place wherever the standard gauge stops.

In looking at these aspects we should also look at other things that the railways can do. In the early 1950s a commissioner of the Commonwealth Railways decided that carrying passengers on the transcontinental line with two or three carriages was a waste of engine power. He took the decision to load fast freight vehicles on the front and to piggyback road vehicles on trains using that route. It was commercially successful. I do not know how long it stayed commercially successful. People could drive onto the transcontinental with a semitrailer at Port Augusta and drive it off at Kalgoorlie. Subsequently the standard gauge went from Kalgoorlie to Perth and that may have made a difference.

It is obviously worth considering interstate flat-car trains running express between Melbourne and Sydney carrying semitrailers at a reasonable freight rate. A train could start at Campbellfield or Liverpool, or wherever is more appropriate in Sydney, where trucks could drive on and be bolted down. The drivers could sleep in their cabins or in a carriage at the back, but I think they would want to stay in their cabins. When the train is full with, say, 20 or 30 semitrailers, it could pull out and go to Sydney on a straight through basis. Such a system would take 20 or 30 trucks off the road, and it would save wear and tear for owner-drivers. I do not think it would be much dearer than the cost of petrol and wear and tear on the roads and the transports themselves.It is something which I think is viable, and it ought to be examined.

One thing that is happening and will continue to happen is that the quantity of freight being moved will increase. The use of sea has almost disappeared. The roads cannot be upgraded on a continual basis at a rate which will enable that freight to be safely carried. We only have to look at the bus smashes and the blockages that occur on our highways. The Hume Highway was blocked for seven hours the other day. According to the Victorian Government, it is proposed to put 100 truck loads of chemicals on the Geelong-Melbourne road every day. It is a road on which it will be extremely dangerous to carry volatile chemicals. If we can utilise the rail system in an efficient and commercially viable way—and I believe piggybacking trucks is one way—we will do a service to motorists and to the Australian community. I think it is well worth looking at.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid The Hon N.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to contribute to this debate on the National Rail Corporation Agreement Bill. It is significant that the preceding two speakers, namely, the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) and the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson), and I represent the three largest provincial cities in Victoria. They are cities that have had long established links with rail for the greater part of its history. The port of Geelong, which is represented by the honourable member for Corio, has played a very significant part in the export of wool and grain and other commodities from the rural sector. I know of the honourable member for Corio's long interest in rail, and I recognise his superior knowledge about a lot of rail activities. I understand that he was employed by the rail organisation in Victoria. I am not sure of its name then; it has had so many name changes in its history.

PARA.TAB: I also mention the contribution by my colleague the honourable member for Ballarat. I refer to the role that Bendigo and Ballarat played in the establishment of a rail network. We had the establishment of rail workshops at both Ballarat and Bendigo. Bendigo played a significant part in the dispersal of railway traffic out of the Riverina area, where wool and grain were trafficked down originally by river to the railhead at Echuca and then down through Bendigo and subsequently to Geelong for export.

I think that what the Government is doing with the establishment of the interstate rail freight service on a commercial basis is very important, and I stress the words `commercial basis'. The Bill before the House sets out the purpose of the establishment of the service, and the agreement is set out in schedule 1 of the Bill. The parties to that agreement agreed that the company would be established for the purpose of conducting interstate rail freight operations in Australia on a commercial basis. One of the most important tests for the Government is going to be ensuring that it meets the commercial criteria that other commercial organisations adhere to.

The principles of the Bill set out that the company will operate on that strictly commercial basis. It will also have access to the requisite assets that are involved. It will operate under labour agreements that reflect the best international practice in productivity standards, and it will be able to contract activities where appropriate and provide access to its network and facilities to public and private sector operators. It will also be able to provide services to governments on a strictly commercial basis and will not be in any way responsible for redundancies that may arise in rail authorities resulting from its formation and operation.

The principles are set out very clearly in the Bill, and the Bill provides that the National Rail Corporation will be subject to rates, taxes and charges. I am pleased that the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) is at the table at the moment because I am not sure whether in fact it is indicated that the National Rail Corporation will be subject to local government rates for any enterprise that may be established on land within a local government area. The Minister might respond to that at some time during the debate. Certainly, the objective to perform on a commercial basis should be adhered to, and in fact the Corporation should meet the requirements that would be faced by road operators in similar circumstances where they may have a road users depot established on local government land. Of course, they would pay full local government rates, taxes and charges applicable to the establishment of that depot.

The financial impact is very important, and quite a few comments were made about that impact particularly as it relates to the establishment of the National Rail Corporation. The Corporation is expected to have an impact on the deficits of State railway systems and Australian National. The total losses on interstate rail freight were estimated to have amounted to $377m in 1989-90. The National Rail Corporation is supposed to break even within three years and to be fully self-sufficient within five years, which is a notable objective. One can just hope that the Government is able to perform to that timetable and is able to get the National Rail Corporation to operate within that type of financial framework. That will depend greatly, of course, upon the industrial relations negotiations that will be undertaken prior to the establishment of the body itself. I understand that those negotiations are taking place. But the whole key to the establishment of this Corporation largely hinges on the introduction of best practice in productivity standards and satisfactory enterprise agreement awards so that the industrial relations part of it is set out very clearly before we embark upon this project. It would be senseless entering into any agreement which may lead to the sorts of practices that we have seen in the Victorian railway system over a long period of time.

There are inefficiencies in the system, and people within the rail system in Victoria are the first to acknowledge some of those inefficiencies. The inefficiencies seem to have become entrenched and have been extremely difficult for any government in the State of Victoria to overcome. We certainly would not want to enter into a situation where they could be prolonged or included in the establishment of the National Rail Corporation. I note that the Minister is listening and agrees that those problems need to be solved for this venture to be successful.

From the coalition's point of view, this is one of the most important factors in the establishment of the Rail Corporation. It will enable the Corporation to compete and to carry the sorts of freight and commodities that are best able to be carried on rail. Some of those, of course, include bulk commodities such as grain, coal, iron ore and fuel. The practice of using the roll-on roll-off vehicles that we have seen in other countries throughout the world needs to be encouraged here in Australia so that we have the ability to cater for that type of traffic on the freight side of the National Rail Corporation's activities.

The honourable member for Corio mentioned the carriage of fuel and chemicals. I believe that rail is very well equipped to handle this type of commodity. Given that the proper procedures are followed, these commodities can be carried very safely. There is always a risk transporting fuel and toxic chemicals from State to State, and it is important that the safety aspects of that carriage be ensured. What better way to do that than to have it carried in bulk and carried on rail where it is free from a lot of the other traffic that perhaps could subject it to risk when carried on road?

But once again, of course, the industrial relations side of it needs to be right, and the commercial practices need to be right so that we have true and open competition between road and rail. There needs to be equality with regard to taxes and land charges so that one group, for example the Rail Corporation, does not have an advantage over the rest of the transport industry in that respect.
One item in the Bill, on page 13, causes me a little concern. It reference to the directors who will be appointed to the National Rail Corporation, section 4(4)(a) of the schedule states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . three Directors nominated by the Commonwealth, one being the Chairperson of the Board of Directors and one, as a matter of Commonwealth policy, being a nominee of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, not being a member of a union directly associated with operations of the Company . . .

I think that might be the true parliamentary language, but although it says that it is Commonwealth policy the nomination of an Australian Council of Trade Unions representative is in fact Australian Labor Party policy. It just happens to be that that Party is in government, so it has become Government policy. I am not quite sure that it is a matter of Commonwealth policy, and I think that the term is really a bit of a misnomer. I pursue that issue because I believe it is important that the employees who become involved in the National Rail Corporation have the opportunity to take up equity in the Corporation.

PARA.TAB: I do not see any provision for it in the way the shareholding is constructed. It may well be that the employees can buy shares on the public market. The Minister may be able to correct me if I have a misunderstanding about whether there is any provision for employees of the Corporation to have a share in the equity of that organisation. I am of the firm belief that if employees have a stake in the operation, are treated as though they are part of that organisation and have a profit motivation, they will want to do the correct job and be involved with the National Rail Corporation. If the staff want to be involved in the shareholding and the equity of the company, they should have the opportunity to do so. It is similar to what was done with the Commonwealth Bank float where employees were given the opportunity to take up shares. I understand that many of the employees of the Commonwealth Bank decided to do just that.

There are concerns about what will happen to the intrastate lines. In Victoria particularly the National Rail Corporation will take over some of the major lines, but what will happen to some of the other lines within Victoria? I am particularly concerned about that. I want to receive assurances from the Minister and from the Government that many of those very good lines which service areas such as Bendigo and Ballarat are not interfered with and left out as the poor relation because I understand that V/Line would still have an involvement in the operation of those lines; I am not sure exactly how V/Line will manage them and how it will operate under the charter of the National Rail Corporation. If those lines are operating profitably and carrying freight, it is important that they be kept up to a very high standard. I encourage the National Rail Corporation to take some of those lines over, maintain the standards that are being set for the interstate transmission, and apply those standards intrastate so that they are kept at a high level and provide the sorts of services that the clients and customers would want to see in those areas.

I have outlined a number of concerns in my contribution, but I want to express another concern: I visited the Bendigo railway workshops at the invitation of Mr Ivan Kitt. I had discussions with the union representatives there. These workshops have gone through an upgrading of their equipment and have very good skills in many areas which are particularly related to the establishment and conduct of the National Rail Corporation and its activities. They are desirous of competing for much of the maintenance work and the new construction work. They particularly have the ability to compete in general engineering, an area in which they have many skills. They also have skills in the construction of rolling stock and its maintenance. They have done some very good projects over the years, which I have had the opportunity to observe. I have also observed the quality of the work these workshops are able to produce. Naturally, that level of expertise would not want to be lost with the establishment of the National Rail Corporation; it would need to be retained. The workshops are keen to compete, and have the ability to compete, for that work. I noted the comments made by the honourable member for Corio indicating that the Victorian State Government had made provision for this. I would be interested to hear what that provision was. Obviously they would have to compete on a commercial basis; they would have to be viable and efficient. I believe that they are and that they have the expertise which has been built up over many years.

One thing that causes me great concern is the fact that much of the existing rolling stock that was already owned in Victoria was sold off by the Victorian Government and then re-leased back by it. I fail to see the economies involved in that. The taxpayers already owned rolling stock—much of it had been in the ownership of the taxpayer for many years—and it was sold, purely and simply to prop up an ailing Labor Government in Victoria, and then re-leased—again at the taxpayers expense. I find that management technique to be especially abhorrent because all it does is place a greater financial burden on the Victorian and Australian taxpayers. One would hope that that exercise is not repeated by the National Rail Corporation.

I acknowledge the fact that the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) is at the table and is very interested in this topic. He would be well aware of the Bendigo railway workshops, as he is with the Ballarat railway workshops, and the important role they may be able to play in the future not only in constructing and doing general engineering but also producing rolling stock and providing maintenance for the National Rail Corporation. I commend that to him.
