I would be interested to see how the provisions that were mentioned by the honourable member for Corio regarding the Victorian State Government's involvement in the matter will ensure that those areas do receive some work. We would want to see it done on a commercial basis.

I believe that the employees at Bendigo would respond very well to the challenge. I am sure that the quality of their work would be unsurpassed. As I say, I have expressed a number of the concerns I have. I trust that the Minister will be able to answer them at the appropriate time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall Mr R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown), when presenting the second reading speech for the National Rail Corporation Agreement Bill 1991, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill represents another major step in the implementation of the Government's micro-economic reform program which is directed at creating a more productive, efficient and flexible economy.

One wonders why it has taken nine years for this Government to come to this reform. It was definitely on the back-burner when the Minister and his colleagues were playing footsies with the entrepreneurs in the mid-1980s in this community. It is only now when we are facing the question of economic survival in this country that the Government addresses one of the most important questions in the Australian economy. Important it is. In his speech he quotes the Industry Commission, which estimated that in 1989-90, if proper attention were given to the transport systems in Australia, it could realise an additional $6 billion in gross domestic product every year. Of this, $4.4 billion was attributed to the refurbishment of the rail system in Australia.

PARA.TAB: When we look at the history of the development of rail in Australia, we see in the latter years—and certainly since Federation—one of the darker sides of Australian systems of government: an inability of States to provide a national interest in the formulation of their own regional proposals. As I have said, it has taken a very long time, at this late hour in the economic challenge to Australia, to get States to agree with the Commonwealth to do something about this enormous dereliction of duty in the management of Australian rail.

I have gone back to a few historical points to help my appreciation of what has occurred. I will read just a few points of past history; there are a few across this great panorama of development of rail in Australia. They indicate, I believe, where we have come from and where we have got to.

For instance, in Adelaide it was reported that it was not until October 1851 that the Government assumed financial responsibility for the first rail in South Australia. The construction commenced in 1853. In 1856 the broad gauge line was opened as the first steam operated railway in that State. It was from Port Adelaide to Adelaide. After the completion of that line, the northern line to Gawler was constructed in 1857 and extended to Kapunda, a copper mining town, in 1860.

During the 1870s a number of comparatively short narrow gauge railways were constructed—a horrifying feature, as it turned out, in subsequent readjustments to the rail gauge that were required. The narrow gauge railway from Port Pirie had been extended to Peterborough by 1881 and its further extension to the New South Wales border at Cockburn was authorised in 1884. By 1887 this railway was completed and in 1888 the line beyond Cockburn linked Broken Hill by rail with Port Pirie and Adelaide.

Of course, whilst one must decry the fact that those different gauges were built, there is no doubt that the railway played an enormous role in the development of the primary industries of Australia. The completion of the line to Broken Hill commenced an ongoing connection between Broken Hill and South Australia and provided the essential link for the export of the ores from Broken Hill. Services commenced to Perth in 1917 following the Commonwealth Railways construction of that line to Western Australia.

I looked on from that early mention of the development of railway in South Australia to a letter to the South Australian Minister of Transport, Mr Blevins, in 1990 from his Federal counterpart about the closure of the regional passenger services in South Australia. We had come full circle since 1856 until 1991 when the State closed its last passenger service. It did so on the basis that the costings outlined in the Minister's letter indicated how impossible it was to maintain that service. The Blue Lake service, for instance, had a full cost of $3.37m per year and revenue of $O.62m, a cost recovery of 18.4 per cent. Other examples were given on other remaining regional passenger services of a cost recovery of 21.2 per cent and, as low as 16.6 per cent to Silver City. The letter from the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) ended with the paragraph beginning:

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to authorise AN to close these services by the end of 1990.
Indeed, that was a full circle as far as South Australian passenger railways were concerned. I read from the Australian Encyclopedia of another aspect of railway development in Australia :

Following the presentation of a report on rail standardisation to the Federal Parliament in 1956, a number of projects were conducted with a view to standardising the gauge on the major mainland trunk routes. The longest of these is the 3961 kilometres Sydney-Perth line and, as nearly 68 per cent of this was of standard gauge, the decision to adopt standard as the uniform gauge was taken. A standard gauge line between Wodonga, on the Murray River, and Melbourne, was opened in 1962. Six years later a standard-gauge line reached Kalgoorlie . . . to link with the existing Trans-Australian standard-gauge line from Port Pirie, and the Port Pirie to Broken Hill . . . link was completed. In January 1970 the first freight train crossed the continent, from coast-to-coast, without a break of gauge.
I read about another development under the heading `Private Railways'. This excerpt goes on to say:

They have the following features in common: location in the remote Pilbara region of north-western Australia, single-purpose iron ore haulage, single-track diesel operation, very high axle-loads to 35 tonnes, very long trains (up to 240 cars for 30,000 tonnes gross), and very modern technology . . . The traffic density on the Pilbara lines is up to 70 million gross tonnes annually over a single track and their productivity, as measured in haulage cost . . . is believed to be among the lowest of any railway anywhere.
Another excerpt, going back to July 1975, states:

. . . the Commonwealth Railways became the Australian National Railways. Also in 1975, agreements were reached between the Australian Government and the Tasmanian . . . Government for the transfer of the Tasmanian Railways to the Australian Government . . .
I will read one last except from this collection. It is from a media release from my Leader, who in February this year drew attention to the losses in the Australian railway system. He said:
In Victoria the rail system is currently losing over $5 million per day. . . . Sydney's urban line loses $2.5 million per day.

The interesting point from all of this collection of mismanagement of Australian railways and the failure to take a national view among regional interests is the description of the railways in the Pilbara where, when a specific purpose had to be served and State governments were not involved and industrial relations were not a hindrance, we have a spectacularly successful transport of those essential products overseas for Australia.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that this establishment of an Australian National Rail Corporation is a movement away from State interests to the national interest. Yet, of course, the two absolutely coincide. We are not separate kingdoms; the success of a National Rail Corporation will be the success of State transport organisation.

In many ways it has been the politics of States that has prevented them from modernising their railways. I know, from personal experience, how difficult it has been for State governments to face the political backlash of closing down inefficient rail services within their own territories. When we consider that many State governments over the years, because of the political process, have survived simply by a majority of one or two, and that one or two can be lost by altering the railway system in particular electorates, we can see how difficult it has been for them to take brave and firm action in this matter.

There is no doubt that the labour movement has used the rail systems of Australia for some of the most extreme featherbedding in this nation. I think one of the speakers from this side of the House mentioned yesterday that there are still 40 manually operated rail gates in Victoria. Can one think of greater featherbedding in this technological age than to have 40 manually operated rail gates? It is a ridiculous situation!

I have watched the success of Australian National in local areas of South Australia since it has taken over the country rail lines. One watched the spread of efficiency in the manning of the rail stock and, in particular, in the staffing levels on many of the railway stations throughout the State. It may be unfortunate for many local communities that so many local rail stations have been closed. That has been difficult for local towns. However, it has been one of the facts of life that no longer could staffs of two or four or six remain in small country towns to serve a decreasing patronage by railway passengers.

The Commonwealth, by the very spread of the political risk as well as its national viewpoint, has been able to move very directly and effectively to remove the featherbedding that used to occur in the South Australian railways. Indeed, Commonwealth Railways—renamed, as it was in 1975, Australian National—has shown what can be done when the political incapacity of a State government is broached as it was then by the Whitlam Government.

Of course, the other States, as I seem to remember, were all offered the opportunity to purchase their railway systems by the Whitlam Administration. Only South Australia and Tasmania responded. It was unfortunate that the South Australian Government under Mr Don Dunstan squandered the money it got from the Commonwealth in duties, many of which should have been performed in social areas by the Commonwealth in other ways. But that is another matter and is quite subsidiary to the success of the sale or the transfer of ownership of the South Australian railways.

I imagine that the Whitlam Government was not deft enough, if I can use that phrase, and was not cooperative enough to envisage a corporation such as has now been envisaged. It ought not to offend the sensibilities and sense of proprietorship of States about their railway systems. They all have input through the Corporation and, in a sense, they are not selling out, if they take that parochial view, their rail interests.

I reflect on the funding of roads in relation to railways. I refer to the excerpt from the Minister's speech in which he referred to the Industry Commission's reference to the increase in domestic product that could be obtained by better management and better funding of road and rail systems. The bulk of the advantage came from the refurbishment of rail systems. One can ask generally why Federal governments have paid so much attention to the funding of roads, yet been so neglectful of addressing the burden of rail. Has it been that rail has been seen simply as unnecessary or ineffective or a sideline operation in the transport question?

Under this Labor Government the motorist in Australia has become a milch cow for taxation. The Minister for Land Transport, who is sitting at the table, would know what dramatic increases there have been in the excise on fuel. I do not have the figure to hand, but I think it was something in the order of 9c or 10c a litre when the Government came to office and now it stands at about 25c. I mention this in relation to overall funding of transport because there is no longer, and there has not been for a long while—because the Hawke Government and the Keating Government destroyed it—any relationship between the collection of taxation from fuel and its expenditure on roads. The Government quite destroyed the relationship. As the Minister knows, 6c or 7c from the sale of each litre of fuel is spent on roads. So of the 25c which the Government collects, 19c do not go back to be spent on roads; only 6c or 7c go to roads. It would seem to me that there is no relationship.

The Government therefore says, `We will have a road program of such and such an amount', which has been inadequate. The Government has not provided what it ought to have provided for the road program. It has simply looked at roads. Until now, nine years into office, it has basically ignored the rail system. One has to ask why it took so long.

Of course, I can go back further than that, and I do not put that wholly on this Government. National governments have ignored the sensibilities and the importance of rail, this Government more than any other, and at a time when it has made an art form of milking the motorist. I do not know that any other taxation has increased so much and with such a dramatic effect in Australia. I suppose it is almost the first priority of this coalition to address this question of the cost of transport.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—The shadow Minister sitting at the table, the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), in his very able address in this debate explained fully the attitudes of the coalition in this regard. The taking away of excise—which is quite the opposite of this Government's implementation of it, which as I said is an art form of taxation—will revitalise road transport and at the same time will put an even greater emphasis on the need to make rail competitive, because road will be more competitive. Therefore this is an even more urgent proposition under coalition policy than it is for this Government.

PARA.TAB: In closing, I again make reference to what have been the problems with Australian rail. It is intended that the Corporation break even in three years and be self-sufficient in five years. That is enormously rapid progress. I wish it well and I hope it can achieve that, but looking back over its problems I must say that it will require management of the highest order to achieve these objectives.

Australian rail has been caught in a time warp with residues of our development as colonies, with an ineffectual system of Federation to develop a national rail plan and with the States' subservience to their political survival when making decisions to effectively rejuvenate rail. Above all, there has been the industrial featherbedding obtained by the union movement in all the railways of Australia except Australian National. These were the impediments in the round in the past, and for this Corporation to be successful they all have to be broken. Indeed, this has to be a green fields operation. Problems in the national scene, the industrial scene, will all be remedied and rectified so that we will have a new day and we will move away, as I said when I began, from the darker side of Australian politics where our type of federation has prevented the development, for decades, of the essential rail transport that we need. I certainly hope that the Corporation succeeds.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—First of all I want to thank all honourable members who have participated in this debate on the National Rail Corporation Agreement Bill 1992 and to indicate as well how greatly I have been encouraged by the positive responses that we have heard. There have been differences on matters of detail, but in general there has been a very clear indication of support and a very high level of commitment from both sides of the House, as there should be.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) referred to the fact that this Government has been in office for nine years. The Australian Labor Party was in office in the postwar period, say, for only the last four years of the 1940s and for only four years in the early 1970s, and it did not come back into government until 1983. That is typical of the period in which the Labor Party has had the opportunity to govern federally since Federation. The honourable member knows, because of his own involvement, particularly in the government of South Australia, that the greater part of this century has seen the Federal Parliament dominated by conservative parties.

I do not want to draw the obvious connections, but I will say on this occasion that the most significant initiatives as far as road and rail transport is concerned have been undertaken by Labor governments. The other major initiative was undertaken by another Labor government during the early 1970s, and it would be derelict on my part and ungracious in the extreme if I did not draw attention to and pay credit to the great vision that Gough Whitlam had about the possibilities of Australian rail. As the honourable member for Boothby indicated, had it not been for the fact that only South Australia and Tasmania responded to that offer, we certainly would not be considering this initiative now. But we are considering it and, as I say, it is of great importance and will become of increasing importance. I appreciate enormously the level of support which has been apparent from honourable members on both sides of the Parliament.

Whilst I am disappointed that I was not able to be here personally to hear some of the outstanding contributions to the debate, including your own, Mr Deputy Speaker, I can assure you and the other honourable members who participated in the debate that while I was not in the chamber I heard most of it on our internal monitoring system. My responses will indicate that I am very conscious of the points that were raised and of the need for me to respond to them.

The overall benefits as far as the Australian community is concerned have been indicated by some of the studies which have been undertaken. This Government's commitment has not just been empty rhetoric: we have backed it with national taxpayers' dollars. Our initial commitment to the National Rail Corporation involved a funding commitment of those national taxpayers' dollars of about $300m. In addition to that, under the One Nation statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) another $450m was allocated.

We recognise of course that they are national taxpayers' dollars. I have not heard one person criticise that. Those commitments have been universally endorsed, welcomed and applauded. People know that there is a need for us to re-examine the role of rail as one of the important land transport modes. The rail reform generally has been indicated by the Industry Commission to have the potential to add every year to gross domestic product $4.5 billion of that $6 billion, to which the honourable member for Boothby and other honourable members referred, which could result from reform including the achievement of world-type standards across the whole area of land transport.

While that $4.5 billion could be added to gross domestic product, the annual operating deficit for all rail services—both freight and passenger, intrastate and interstate, across Australia—is running at the rate of about $4 billion a year. The national community is becoming increasingly conscious of that and increasingly concerned about it. Governments have a responsibility to respond not only because the national community is concerned, but also because governments should accept the responsibility of doing something about it; and of course we have.

The establishment of the National Rail Corporation—again based on the analysis by the Industry Commission—has the potential to add, by itself, $1.4 billion every year to gross domestic product. That is a significant benefit and it is something from which no government worth its salt would ever turn away.

Compliments have been paid from both sides of the House to AN and the way in which it has been able to establish a method of operation which is commercially oriented, efficient, aggressive and successful. I endorse all of those comments. I make the point that since 1983, AN has reduced its call on national taxpayers' dollars by 70 per cent in real terms. That is a very significant improvement. It has shown what a commercially based rail operation is capable of doing. To a very large extent, our willingness as a Commonwealth government to become involved in this area has been underpinned by the success of AN and the fact that it has shown what can be achieved.

I also want to pay tribute to all of the departmental officers who have been involved in this exercise for the advice they have brought to us, the negotiations they have undertaken with officers at State level, and for all of the effort that has gone into what is recognised quite clearly as a difficult exercise: to bring together State systems with all of the inherent safeguards of a Federal system and to get coordination, cooperation and effective operations of the kind that we are now putting into place.

I want to respond to a couple of matters before I go on to some more general responses to issues that were raised. The honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) asked whether or not the National Rail Corporation would be subject to local government rates. The answer is yes; like any other corporation, it will be responsible for all charges and all taxes. It will be treated just the same as any other corporation. The only difference in its structure and its legal responsibilities is the fact that it is owned by governments on behalf of the Australian people and on behalf of the constituencies of the various participating State governments.

This is relevant then to one of the questions asked by the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris). He asked whether the break-even position at the end of the three-year transition period would involve the Corporation in covering all of its costs. The answer is yes: not only operating costs but also any debt servicing and depreciation, and so on. All of the costs attributed to the operation of the National Rail Corporation should be covered by the annual revenue after three years. At the end of the five-year establishment period it should be able to stand on its own feet, funding also its investment programs and so on. As we know, the total investment program—including our contribution—will be something like $1.7 billion over 10 years. All Australians will get the benefits of that.

You can understand, Mr Deputy Speaker, how personally delighted I am to have been involved in this process. I do not want to denigrate any governments or any of those people who have had responsibility for this area in the past. It is always very easy for us to look back and say what should have been done. The important thing is what we are doing now.

But it was just a matter of three or four years ago that one had to look hard to find anyone on the ground who had any interest in rail or rail reform. They were very thin on the ground. Rail was becoming irrelevant. As has been pointed out, there was that $4 billion in total operating deficit for all of our rail systems each year. It included the annual combined deficit for interstate freight systems of almost $400m. We will knock that out within three years. I expect it to be knocked out because no-one has challenged the methodology upon which those forecasts were based—including those people who at the present time have the responsibility for the carriage of this.

I also want to include in my credits the work that was undertaken by Ted Butcher; Vince Graham, who is now the chief executive; all of the board members and all of the people who participated in any way. It really has been an excellent outcome. To a large extent, I suppose it continues the vision of Gough Whitlam. He was a great enthusiast of rail reform—not in the sense of being a rail buff, as many of us are; but in the sense of being a rail analyst: a person who understands and has always understood the potential of this nation and the things that we can achieve. Gough has continued his interest in this area and I know that he endorses the efforts we are making to continue to pursue the sorts of objectives that he set in place—even if we do it in a slightly different way.

A number of other matters have been raised in the debate and I want to clarify as many of those as I have the opportunity to. With the creation of the National Rail Corporation, rail is now clearly entering a new era. It is not more of the same in a different guise. As the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) pointed out during his contribution, the problem is not one that has appeared since this Labor Government came to power. This Government realised that something had to be done and, as I have said, it has now done it. The National Rail Corporation is the beginning of that new era; it is the new start that rail needs if it is to be an efficient transport operator in the Government's integrated transport strategy.
A number of honourable members have referred to the need to get the industrial arrangements right. The Government agrees with that absolutely.

TALK.START.PARA: —World best practice.

—The honourable member understands that we are talking about NRC standard practice identified on the basis of the quality of the capital that we have to work with. The rail unions asked whether or not they should be expected to provide a silk purse with a sow's ear. When they talked about a sow's ear, the honourable member knows that they were talking about the quality of that capital investment and often the quality of management—the over-manning, the work practices and a lack of commitment on the part of people who are responsible for those services. This has been made perfectly clear: we expect the best to be achieved with the quality of material which is available. Until all of those things are put into place, we will not be making any of those capital commitments. That has been made perfectly clear; there is no question about it.

PARA.TAB: In establishing the National Rail Corporation, the Commonwealth and the States agreed that to be successful the Corporation would need the right mix of commercial management, capital investment and a greenfields industrial enterprise award. This award, which is currently being negotiated by the Corporation and the rail unions, will incorporate best practice industrial arrangements which reflect the most efficient work and manning practices, determined by the technical capacity of the equipment and by obvious commercial considerations.

The Government's commitment to getting these arrangements right was reiterated in the One Nation statement, which was delivered by the Prime Minister in February. The Government will be seeking firm commitments to a greenfields enterprise award from rail unions and from States to accelerate rail reform in their rail systems. A question was also asked about what are the best practice industrial arrangements which the NRC is required to attain. These are precisely defined in clause B of the recitals to the agreement and are, as a minimum, those identified by the National Rail Freight Initiative Task Force in attachment 1 to its report of 21 March 1991.

As my colleague the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) pointed out earlier in the debate, it is not just that industrial arrangements need to be right, but also that management practices in the rail industry need to change, and there must be additional investment in rail infrastructure. This Government has supported these initiatives as well.

A new management team is at the helm of this new rail company. In addition, the Government will be injecting capital funds to allow the National Rail Corporation to undertake carefully targeted, high return investments that will improve efficiencies and reduce costs. In addition to the equity the shareholders will be providing, the Prime Minister announced Commonwealth funding for a standard gauge rail network from Brisbane to Perth, including connections to ports. More efficient and reliable rail services will bring wider benefits to the community. This is a key factor in improving our overall competitiveness.

The major projects under that proposal have been indicated. There will be improved intermodal connections to the ports of Brisbane, Melbourne, Adelaide and Fremantle. They will increase the efficiency of the interface between road, rail and sea. This will benefit shippers not only by reducing transfer times and costs but also by stimulating greater competition between Australian ports. I assure the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) that a standard gauge railway between Brisbane and Perth is commercial. I am surprised that the doubt was raised.

If it was not for the initiative of the Labor Government, this proposal would not have been undertaken for at least the next few years. However, I expect that improving transit times and the reliability of the rail network will be key commercial goals of the NRC. The NRC will take on the interstate functions and associated assets of the existing rail systems. The remaining functions will remain with the existing rail systems and it will be up to each government to consider what it intends to do with its residual railways. I cannot speak for the Victorian Government, or any other government, but the Commonwealth Government will be considering this matter in relation to Australian National, its prime responsibility, in the near future.

During the debate, it was suggested that the capital base for the NRC is inadequate. That is incorrect. Perhaps the cause of confusion is that voting shares are set in the first five years. In this period, voting shares are set at the level agreed by the shareholders and set out in the schedule to the agreement. Cash and assets contributed are reflected by the issue of A convertible shares. At the end of the establishment period, these are converted to ordinary voting shares.

Further, the NRC's capital program will be complemented by the $454m I have already referred to as arising from the Prime Minister's One Nation statement of 26 February. In addition, the shareholders' agreement allows the shareholders to make additional equity payments should these be required. As this would be done via the corporate plan process, any dispute among shareholders would be settled by the special mechanism set out to resolve disputes over the corporate plan. Honourable members have referred to concerns that the referral of power by States to the NRC to engage in intrastate trade should be irrevocable. I agree with those honourable members that it would place the Commonwealth in an awkward position if, after referring a power, States were to turn around and revoke it; but that is the nature of the Constitution.

Honourable members opposite also referred to the mechanism for resolving disputes, particularly in relation to the transfer of assets to the National Rail Corporation. The point they were trying to make was not perfectly clear to me. I emphasise the fact that the National Rail Corporation is subject to the same laws and commercial practices as is any other company operating in the marketplace; there are no, nor should there be any, special arrangements for the NRC. The mechanism is clearly set out in the shareholders' agreement and all parties have agreed to this process. The process is to try to resolve any disputes, first, by way of conciliation and, if this does not succeed, then by arbitration.

Concern was also expressed about the 49 per cent cap on any individual shareholding. There is in place a mechanism whereby it is possible, as a result of the development of shareholding and arrangements between the participating shareholders, for a single shareholder to acquire more than 50 per cent of the total voting stock with the concurrence of the other partners. The approval of the corporate plan is clearly provided for in the shareholders' agreement and that will be the way in which the Corporation will proceed.

As the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil) and the honourable member for Shortland pointed out, the fact is that the Commonwealth policy is not to favour one mode of transport over another, but to encourage each mode to undertake the tasks to which each is best suited. The emphasis in rail is therefore on the long distance carriage of bulk freight with assistance being provided to the National Rail Corporation to carry it out.

There were some other particular issues that I would have liked to have responded to, but if honourable members who have participated feel that my response has been inadequate on any of the particular issues that they have raised, I would be more than happy to respond to them personally, directly or by letter. I repeat my appreciation for the way in which people have participated in what has been an historic debate in this Parliament. (Extension of time granted) That is a very generous gesture on the part of the shadow Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —You always need a bit longer.

—As my friend says, on occasions the Opposition is capable of being both gracious and generous. I refer to the question of the resolution of disputes. I indicated that the process is to try to resolve any of those disputes, first, by way of conciliation and, if this does not succeed, then by arbitration. The intention was to avoid any lengthy, costly, legalistic or bureaucratic processes and of course that has now been built into the processes that have been agreed to.

PARA.TAB: I also referred briefly to the approval of the corporate plan. I went on to say that the approval requires 75 per cent of the vote for the plan to be successfully approved. However, if for some reason during that establishment period one of the shareholders seeks to frustrate the approval process, a deadlock breaking mechanism can be invoked. That mechanism provides that, if the plan is not approved within 30 days, it can be approved if all shareholders, bar one, agree, irrespective of the number of shares each shareholder has. Given the need for shareholders to earn a return on their investment in the National Rail Corporation, it is unlikely that any two members would seek to frustrate a commercially driven corporate plan.

The issue of privatisation was raised as well. Some people suggested to me in the early stages of this process that the Federal Government was seeking to develop a successful national rail system in order to sell it off to private enterprise. I said that, if private investors came hammering at my door for a share of the action, I would applaud their attempt because that would show that we had been successful. At present there is no way in the world that private investors would seek to have a share of a loss-making operation. But when they start hammering at the doors of future governments to have a share, to be given the opportunity to invest in it, then governments will be able to say that the venture is successful, that it is profitable and that it has a future.

Of course, that includes the question that was raised by the honourable member for Bendigo about whether shares would be available to employees. The answer to that is that some time in the future it is likely that they will be. But again, the same issue applies: would anyone at this stage, apart from governments acting on behalf of the nation, be particularly interested in pursuing it?
Finally, I would be happy to respond to any further questions later, but I appreciate the opportunity that was provided to me by the Opposition to complete those few remarks.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Robert Brown) read a third time.
