That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are about to commence debating the Asian Development Fund Bill. It provides for Australia's contribution to the Asian Development Fund for the period 1992 to 1995 and it amounts to $350m. Out of a total membership of 47 countries, 32 of them being regional, that is, within the Asian region, and 15 non-regional, Australia is the fourth largest donor to the Asian Development Fund and has been an active supporter of it since its creation in 1973.

PARA.TAB: The bank was created with the principal objective of encouraging economic growth and development in Asia and the Far East including the South Pacific. To this end, the bank promotes investment in public and private capital for development purposes; it provides loans for the encouragement of growth; it coordinates the economic development plans and policies of its member states; it provides technical assistance to help prepare, finance and implement development projects and programs; and, of course, it cooperates with relevant United Nations agencies.

Whilst the Asian Development Bank has the objective of assisting all developing countries within its region, it pays special attention to the smaller and the least developed of them. To this end, the bank provides technical assistance to generate more projects for the Asian Development Bank financing, it provides a greater share of funds to less developed countries, it provides loans at highly concessional terms, and it finances local currency expenditures by lending foreign exchange to the recipients concerned.

The Asian Development Fund, as distinct from the bank, was established in 1974 as a means of financing loans on concessional terms to the most needy members. In general, the lower the debt repayment capacity of a country, the greater the need for what they call a soft loan under the Asian Development Fund. Accordingly, countries have been divided into three groups. Group A includes Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Butuan, Burma, Cambodia, the Cook Islands, India, Kiribati, Laos, the Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan, Solomon Islands, Sri Lanka, Tonga, Vanuatu, Vietnam and Western Samoa. Group B includes such countries as Indonesia, Papua New Guinea, Philippines and Thailand. Group C includes Fiji, Hong Kong, Korea, Malaysia, Singapore, Taiwan and China.

The bulk of Australian development assistance is largely multilateral and it takes the form of contributions to international financial institutions such as the Asian Development Bank. The second reading speech of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Martin) indicates that Australia intends to consolidate this approach by increasing its international financial institutions payments as a share of the total aid budget from 8 per cent, as it was in the mid-1980s, to over 18 per cent.

Whilst not opposing the commitment of funds to the Asian Development Bank—and this Bill will obviously have our support—we are concerned about the increasing proportion of the global aid budget going to development banks at the expense of bilateral and other multilateral aid programs. Multilateral aid agencies, principally banks, have a charter which directs them to promote programs aimed at more directly reducing poverty, narrowing income disparities and creating employment in developing countries. The extensive literature assessing the role and performance of multilateral banks, however, suggests that they have been less than successful in fulfilling that charter.

A number of studies have indicated that the multilateral banks have, to a limited extent, been able to direct their programs to the poorest of the poor while numerous others suggest that they have not been able to channel their loans to the lowest income groups. You would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, that members of this Parliament have been raising these matters, particularly in relation to one of the other organisations, the World Bank and its fund, for exactly this reason. Other studies have claimed that multilateral aid programs, in fact, significantly contribute to perpetuating the economic relationships which are in place and which are at the root of so much of the rural poverty that we see not only within our own region but elsewhere in the world.

Virtually all research, however, indicates that the reorientation of programs of multilateral aid agencies towards poverty alleviation has encountered severe political and organisational constraints and raises questions on how these constraints can be overcome. The Asian Development Bank itself came under severe criticism in the 1980s for emphasising the annual expansion of loan approvals while, at the same time, disregarding developmental, technical and economic aspects of its projects.

The Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, which I know that you have taken a good deal of interest in, Mr Deputy Speaker, has noted that there have been occasions when the bank has forgone the scrupulous adherence to the highest standards in its preparation of project appraisals. For the time that I was a member of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade—and we looked at aid questions—the Asian Development Bank was a matter of some considerable comment and concern. Our ability to influence the bank and its policies was constrained by the fact that very often the representation that we had was at a Treasury level. The aid emphasis was obtained largely on a consultancy basis from Australia's specialised staff in AIDAB. Of course, when it came to looking at matters relating to the staffing of the bank, those countries that had perhaps greater contributions were able to play a disproportionate role in the selection of staff and their management.

At the time that members of this Parliament, through the parliamentary committee structure, had some comments to make about those matters and when complaints were made, it was very difficult for Australia to play a role in ensuring that those matters were satisfactorily reviewed. This arises when one is making contributions to agencies in which other countries and their people employed in those organisations also have a role. Wider sensitivities need to be taken into account.

The bank's lack of cooperation and response to committee inquiries led to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade noting that Australia demands the highest standards in accountability and disclosure and, if this is not forthcoming, continued support for the bank's management cannot be assumed. That is a matter on which members of this Parliament have had a view and they have put it strongly.

In relation to these matters, a panel of experts was established to look into the operations of the bank in the 1990s. I understand that it has made some progress. Relations between Australia and the bank, I am informed, have improved significantly as a result of those efforts.

If the Asian Development Fund has been able to achieve some of its goals and objectives, Australia should continue to make a significant contribution. Only by doing so will we be able to have more influence over the direction of the bank and priority of its projects.

It needs to be understood that while the Government has been proportionately increasing the amount of aid that is funded through the World Bank and through the Asian Development Bank—in other words, through the international financial institutions; as I mentioned earlier, with the increase from 8 to 18 per cent—I understand that Australia's share in relation to the Asian Development Fund and to this particular replenishment is lower in proportionate terms than the replenishments that we have contributed to earlier.

Obviously, that is a reflection not only of our commitments to the World Bank but also upon Australia's economic circumstances and prospects. In other words, we need to understand that Australia's ability to contribute these very substantial amounts of money—and we are talking about $350m over a three-year period—is constrained by our own economic success or otherwise in this country. Our very ability to influence the direction and success of development aid through the bank is more constrained and limited when the contributions that we are making are proportionately diminishing.

In this worsening economic climate and with further reductions to the overall aid budget, Australia has to look at whether, when it is operating through other agencies, the funds that we do have available are best maintained in organisations such as the Asian Development Bank and the World Bank. We also have to ask ourselves whether the contributions between those two organisations—the Asian Development Bank and the World Bank—are appropriate. Obviously the World Bank is a larger body in which our influence would be correspondingly smaller than it is in the Asian Development Bank, where we are the fourth largest contributor, as I mentioned. The coalition sees quite clearly that Australia's economic and political future lies in the Asia-Pacific; hence our support for the Asian Development Bank. Our influence over its activities ought to increase in the future.

In a moment I will talk about foreign aid, but I do want to take up this question in relation to our influence within this region. This matter has been the subject of very considerable comment in recent days. Honourable members would be aware that the Prime Minister—who has in the past taken an interest in these matters largely through his involvement as Australia's representative in relation to many of these financial bodies such as the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank—is only now, through the official visits that he is paying to countries within our own region, taking an interest in these relationships.

It is a matter of concern to us that these latter-day interests are developing. We are not critical of their developing but we are critical of the fact that they have been so long coming. In fact, in the past the Prime Minister has spent more time flying over Asia than he has spent in Asia representing Australia's interests, familiarising himself with the situation of the countries within our region and developing relationships with them.

This is not a new matter for the Opposition. Well before the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) became a member of this Parliament, he had extensively visited the Asia-Pacific region both privately and in the capacity of his previous employment. On assuming the role of Leader of the Opposition in the early 1990s, he paid official visits to eight countries in the Asia-Pacific region: Japan, Korea, the Philippines, Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia and Papua New Guinea. By pulling out a copy of the address that he made upon his return from that visit, I reminded myself about the breadth and depth of contact that the Leader of the Opposition had. He met with numerous heads of state: President Aquino in the Philippines; in Singapore, the then head of state, Mr Lee Kuan Yew; in Indonesia, President Suharto; and in Papua New Guinea, Mr Namaliu. In addition, he had discussions with the first Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Goh Chok Tong, in Singapore, and with the Prime Minister of Korea, Mr Kang Young-hoon.

He also met with foreign Ministers in South Korea, Indonesia and Papua New Guinea, as well as deputy foreign Ministers in Thailand and Malaysia. He had discussions with defence Ministers in Japan, the Philippines, Malaysia, Indonesia and Papua New Guinea.

One can see that the Leader of the Opposition had a wide range of contacts and associations upon which he was able to draw. On his return, he emphasised the importance of the relationship between economics and foreign policy. In relation to the visit he undertook to China, he was able to talk about not only our relationships but also Australia's interest in human rights issues. He was prepared to take that up in a very forceful way with a good deal of success from the point of view of an Opposition raising these matters rather than the Government of Australia.

Equally, the Leader of the Opposition looked at the wider issue of refugees in Indo-China. He spent a good deal of time assessing the question personally in relation to Cambodia, assessing our ongoing relationship with Vietnam and, of course, assessing the interest that other countries within our region took in these matters.

Spelt out very clearly by the Leader of the Opposition—right from the time that he assumed these responsibilities—was his commitment to this region. The time that he spent in Papua New Guinea, well in advance of the recent particularly important anniversary celebrations, gave him an opportunity to emphasise Australia's—particularly the coalition's—strong support for Papua New Guinea and our ongoing commitment to it.

It was at that time that the Leader of the Opposition said that we should have a `year of Asia' in Australia. He reiterated the theme of the Opposition's aims to implement policies which would make Australia a major political and economic force in the Asia-Pacific region by the year 2000. He emphasised that we had set ourselves this goal because, notwithstanding the importance of our ties with Europe and the Americas, we believe that our future lies in the Asia-Pacific region. He was talking about the maintenance of our traditional friendships and the ongoing task of developing the important relationships within our region. They can complement each other; they are not exclusive. One does not have to terminate one to be able to commence another.

This is an extraordinary time for Australia. At the moment, we are seeing an emphasis upon the region—a new emphasis as far as the Prime Minister is concerned—that is predicated upon terminating other relationships, abandoning old friendships.

Another matter explored—this has come up in other contexts but it is very relevant to this—is the respect that countries have for a person who takes his domestic disputes before them. A very good and dear friend of mine—a migrant from China who has been quite successful in business in Australia—asked me whether I could obtain for him an Australian flag to hang proudly in his premises. He could not understand why anybody would want to take a family dispute out and exercise it amongst one's neighbours. Yet, we have had the Prime Minister of this country, in the first major visit that he has paid to a country in the Asia-Pacific region—our nearest neighbour, Indonesia—taking an Australian domestic situation before it in a way which I do not think countries within our region would ever do with us.

This brings me to the point that I really wanted to make in the context of Australia's ability to continue programs of support within this region. One cannot have support in programs of this sort without a strong Australian economy. If one is going to have influence within the region, one cannot expect to have it without a strong economy at home. The Asian Development Bank is a marvellous case study, because the principal country that influences that body is, in fact, Japan. Not so long ago Japan invaded many of the countries within this region; it was an occupying force. The commemoration in Papua New Guinea during the last few days was about our involvement 50 years ago.

Japan has had to develop its influence within this region notwithstanding the impact that that invasion had. It has been able to do so, not because it is an easy path for it to tread—it is much easier for Australia, which has never been an occupying power—but because of the force of its own economy. Countries in the region ultimately have to deal with Japan if they are going to be able to get support through programs directly on a bilateral basis or multilaterally through agencies like the Asian Development Bank.

If Australia is going to have influence in organisations like the Asian Development Bank—if it is going to have influence within our own region—first and foremost, we have to see that we have restored the international competitiveness of our economy. History, our culture, our constitutional structure or our flag will not determine the respect that other nations have for us; the respect they will have for us will be there if we are a strong, internationally competitive economy. That is really the crux of it.

If we are going to be one of the economically dynamic countries of Asia, it is not a matter of our trying to coat-tail on their success; it is a matter of our being able to maximise our opportunities through our own success. That has to be achieved by our undertaking the reforms necessary in our own economy to achieve that growth. We need to become an outward looking international economy rather than an inward looking economy, constrained by all of the problems that we are so familiar with: our trade unions and our labour market; the vision of Australian entrepreneurs and Australian management; and the very considerable costs that governments impose on doing business in Australia. All of these matters need to be addressed if we are to restore growth and dynamism to the Australian economy. This will ensure that other countries within our region have respect for us.

This is nothing new. This is a matter about which the Opposition has been talking for a long period. The fact is that under the Hawke Government—and largely with the current Prime Minister, but then as Treasurer and Deputy Prime Minister—foreign policy in relation to this region was never given the priority that it deserved. One can go back and look at the situation in relation to Malaysia, where our Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) found himself persona non grata. The same problem existed in relation to Fiji. There were problems in relation to the South-Pacific Forum meeting in Vila where the Prime Minister irritated Pacific Island heads as a result of his tactless attempt to twist arms to accept the US proposals for chemical waste disposal. Quite significant problems within our region have been perpetuated by this Government.

On behalf of the Opposition, I make it very clear that we do have a commitment to the importance of Australia's foreign aid program to alleviate human suffering and underdevelopment in the world. It is important to focus on the quality of our aid program as well as on its quantity. If I had more time to speak on this matter in this debate, I would cover those aspects in greater detail.

Finally, I mention that it is also important to recognise that Australians ought to have a proper view on human rights issues in relation to development assistance. That is an important question which, if we look at the attitude that Australia has taken recently in relation to China and more recently Indonesia, should be of continuing interest and concern to the Government of Australia.

In the context of this Bill, I draw attention to those matters. We, in the Opposition, support the legislation and will continue to monitor carefully the way in which the funding is provided. We certainly emphasise the importance of bilateral aid as well as the multilateral contributions that are made through organisations like the Asian Development Fund.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Order! It being past 12.45 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Bruce Chapman, the Government's consultant on Austudy, has predicted that 400,000 Australians will have been out of work for more than one year by 1994 if unemployment remains at current levels for the next two years, which is what One Nation predicts. How will changing the flag help the 400,000 long term unemployed?
—You are going to put them off after nine months.
—Order! The Leader of the House!
—You have the gall to ask about the unemployed when you want to send them—

PARA.TAB: Mr Broadbent interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You really have the gall. This guy trotted off into private life in 1983 leaving 11 per cent unemployment behind, and now has a policy of saying that after nine months the unemployed can go and fend for themselves down at a distress agency.
—That's not true and you know it.
—Order!

—That is your policy, but you do not even have the courage to own up to it. That is your policy. You keep trying to avoid it on radio stations, television stations and everywhere else. You do not have the guts to own up to the fact that after nine months you want to turf people onto the street. Then you are up asking about unemployment. As if you crowd ever cared about the employed! The Leader of the Opposition refers to Austudy and the young unemployed. You were quite happy to have three children in 10 complete secondary school in 1983. Kids after primary school wandered out without an adequate education into the labour market.
—They had jobs to go to.
—Yes—11 per cent unemployment. Kids were leaving school at 15 without your even putting them through—

PARA.TAB: Mr Tim Fischer interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the National Party will cease interjecting.

—We have turned those participation rates up from three in 10, 30 per cent to 70-odd per cent, moving to 80 per cent, and have added 50 per cent of places to universities—the equivalent of 12 universities with an average campus size of 10,000—into the system. And you have the hide to ask us about young people. You never did anything for them, other than simply regard them as factory fodder or leave them out of school hanging round the milk bars or skateboard riding at some shopping centre. That is your idea of what kids should do. Now you have the temerity to be talking about the unemployed.
—What about the flag?
—Let me make this clear about the flag.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

—I will tell you about the flag. Nearly 80 per cent of Australian exports go to the Asia-Pacific area and 60-odd per cent of imports come from there. The more this country is psychologically stripped down to trade, the more it is prepared and wishes to trade, the more it invests for exports and goes to these markets wanting to do business and integrate with those societies and businesses, then and only then will the current account be entirely settled as an issue. Employment growth and the growth in the economy that we have seen from net exports in the last year or so will come as a result of those sorts of policies. It is that sort of policy, taking Australia out to the world, that this Government alone pioneered through the 1980s.

PARA.TAB: You guys commissioned the Campbell report but never had the courage to do any of the things set out in it. You never had the courage to remove exchange controls; you never had the courage to float the exchange rate; you never had the courage to put tariffs down, you only put them up; you never had the courage to cut the public sector back; and you never had the courage to radically alter the tax system. You never had the courage to do any of the things that would give Australia a chance as a nation to trade out there in the world on its own freight and on its own fat and also hold its head high. You have got no concept of what Australia's capacities are in the region or in the world.

You are quite happy to keep us, a frightened little place, shut up by a tariff wall, managed exchange rates, exchange controls, sitting there as you always do arguing for the status quo. That is all you are good for—arguing for the status quo. It is always better later. Will we have a republic? Oh yes, inevitably, probably—later.
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much noise.

—As long as it is later. Do you think the flag will change? Probably, inevitably, but later. Do you think we ought to float the Australian dollar? Yes, but later. Do you think we ought to restructure the economy? Yes, but later. Everything is later. That is the thing about the Liberal Party. It has had to be dragged to every progressive reform in this country by the Labor Party, by the only vehicle of social change, by us—it had to be dragged screaming. The only reason you had a free ride was our division of the 1950s, which kept your founder, who nearly saw us slip under the waves of the Japanese, in office for 16 years.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Oh! Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.
—We know all about you. You are basically unable; you are basically incapacitated; and you have always been the same.
—I would like to ask the Treasurer a question of economic importance to Australia. I promise not to mention the flag.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.
—Will the Treasurer advise the House of the economic significance of today's CPI figures for the March quarter?

—Of course, there has been a great deal of talk about zeros, particularly from the other side of the House. It might have been an opportunity for the old Captain Zero over there to actually ask a question.
—Order! The Treasurer will refer to the Leader of the Opposition by his title.
—Yes, the Leader of the Opposition, otherwise known in some quarters as Captain Zero.
—Order! The honourable member for Corinella will cease interjecting.

—This is a zero worth having. This is a big O. This is a zero worth having for Australia. It is just another indication of the kind of improving fundamental base which will underpin the forecast economic recovery as outlined by the Prime Minister in his One Nation statement. The CPI figure also supports recent revised official forecasts of reduced inflation in 1991-92 and, most importantly, in 1992-93.

PARA.TAB: The March quarter CPI of zero per cent means that inflation over the past 12 months is just 1.7 per cent, a slight rise on the 12 months to December because of the negative impact of the CPI figure in the March quarter 12 months ago. The underlying rate, which excludes volatile and seasonal factors, has declined from 3.4 per cent in the December quarter to around 3 per cent for the March quarter. This sets another record low since this series was first constructed in 1971. The consolidation of low inflation and of lower inflation expectations means that inflationary expectations should now be 3 per cent or lower. Of course, this is a further indication of the fundamental basis on which a recovery can proceed.

We also have retail sales continuing to improve, motor vehicle sales have shown steady improvement, even if last month's strong growth is discounted somewhat for the effects of the cut in sales tax. Of course, the housing sector continues to improve as well. In relation to the official inflation estimates, there has now been a revision of the 1991-92 figure, down from the 2 1/4 per cent which was included in One Nation now to 2 per cent for this year. The inflation estimate for 1992-93 has been revised down a full percentage point from 3 1/2 per cent to 2 1/2 per cent for that year.

This provides a very important measure of the Government's policy flexibility and it has an implication for monetary policy. Of course, inflation is not the only factor which informs our deliberations and those of the bank in relation to monetary policy. But this provides an opportunity for some relaxation of monetary policy, the extent of which is to be determined in the course of consultations between the Government and the Reserve Bank during the next few days. This will provide an opportunity to return to the people of Australia a dividend for the improved position as far as inflation is concerned.

It is interesting to hear the Leader of the Opposition deciding to turn his attention towards employment. As each of these statistics comes out and as each of these indications of progress and success comes about, he is reduced to a more and more constrained field of attack. But how could he possibly attack us on the question of economic performance? When we go back to the period, which the Prime Minister referred to, of nine years ago, we see that the Leader of the Opposition was advising the then Government in relation to economic policy. The only zero that it could find then was a zero that had a one in front of it in relation to inflation and unemployment.

Let us look at what happened in relation to inflation in the 12 months before our election. In the period going up to March 1983, we had, in March 1982, inflation of 10.58 per cent; the next quarter, we had inflation of 12.32 per cent; we then had 11.01 per cent; and we had 11.54 per cent in the March quarter of 1983—the time when there was a change of government. In that quarter—the quarter where there was 11.54 per cent—we had unemployment just a touch under 10 per cent, and it rose to 10 per cent just after that. These people on the other side of the House are the ones who were able to achieve that appalling result of double digit inflation coinciding with double digit unemployment. That is the great difference between now and then. We have inflation down to its lowest level since 1971, providing the context in which we can see a return to growth and an improvement in the labour market.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. The One Nation statement predicted that unemployment would stay at around 10 per cent for some time into the future. How will changing the flag help to reduce this crippling rate of unemployment?
—Do you only discuss one thing in your Party meeting?
—Order!

—I understand, given the limited cerebral capacities of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, that one subject at a time is about all that he can comprehend. If one actually brings up another subject, it is quite simply a haze on the screen; he is fazed out. He cannot comprehend a few social issues along with economic issues. It all has to be one track. If he is going to Bourke, he is not going to Condobolin. There is just one place for him. He was programmed in his office. He used to talk about unemployment—chuff, chuff, chuff, chuff, chuff—and unemployment it was; that is all there was. No other issue was going to distract him. When it comes down to it, the fact is that the coalition has no real confidence in Australia. It has never understood what Australians are capable of.
—Order! The House will come to order.

—The coalition has never wanted to give us an identity of our own. It always wanted to see us as a derivative culture of somewhere else and forelock tugging to somebody else. If anyone said, `Let's get out there and get at them'—
—Order! The House will come to order.

—What do we find? It hung back in social and economic policy right across the board. In the torpor of the 23 years that it was in office, we lost the opportunities of a generation. We find now that we have successfully crossed the Rubicon in Australia—we are now looking at the rest of the world as a major market. For the first time, we are looking at the rest of the world as a major market.
—Order! The House will come to order.
—We are looking at the Asia-Pacific, in particular, as the principal market.
—Order! The honourable member for Bass!

—It helps us when we go to that market to say, `We go as Australians. We don't go as surrogates for somebody else; we go as ourselves'. That is why it is going to matter in terms of investment in Australia; that is why it is going to matter in terms of investment by Australians in those countries; that is why it is going to matter in trade, such as with Indonesia, which has grown 50 per cent in the last two years to $2 billion of trade and $1 billion of investment.

PARA.TAB: It is going to matter in terms of job opportunities for Australians. It is going to matter in terms of employment. It is going to matter in many other respects. That is why the business community can see the opportunities around the region. The only people who cannot see it are members of the Liberal Party.
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—Unlike the major companies and the other people in corporate Australia who have some life in them, members of the Liberal Party are the only people who cannot see the advantages and who believe that we should basically stay at home and try to maintain living standards and employment from a small domestic base and that if we go to the world, we should hop on the plane and go somewhere other than where we are actually going to produce some real investment and some real employment.
—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Can he tell the House whether there are economic indicators which suggest that a recovery is under way in the Australian economy?

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—If so, do they indicate that such a recovery will be sustainable?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The one thing the Opposition does not want to hear about is the recovery. The doomsayers over there want to hear nothing good coming for Australia. All the bad news is greeted with applause, and all the good news is greeted glumly.
—Order! The honourable member for Gilmore will cease interjecting.

—The fact is that recently we have seen motor vehicle registrations up by 9 1/2 per cent in March, to be 19 per cent above levels a year earlier. Retail trade has been picking up also in recent months with trend growth in the year to February at 4.2 per cent, noticeably above the inflation rate. Similarly, housing finance approvals rose in February to be 26 per cent above levels a year earlier. Building approvals are 18 per cent up on the number over a year ago.
—Some of them were refinancing.
—Building approvals are not refinancing.
—The honourable member for Forrest will cease interjecting.

—Various inputs into production such as iron and steel and electricity and gas are also strengthening. But, of course, the labour market remains weak, as it will, as it is always a lag indicator of activity.
—Yes, very weak.
—The honourable member for Bruce will cease interjecting.

—That is, of course, before many of the major initiatives in the One Nation package are having their impact upon the economy, which will be a beneficial impact. Today, as the Treasurer has said, we have seen a remarkable gain on inflation. We have seen the consolidation of low inflation, by a Labor Government, for the first time in two decades. We have seen this Government do what the conservatives were not able to do, and that is break the back of double digit inflation. These people say they were the party of business, the people who were able to manage the rest of us, but when the oil shocks came along and inflation and wage growth came along, they were unable to do anything about it. As the Treasurer said, they left office with unemployment at levels similar to today's but with inflation at 11.4 per cent instead of, as we have it, at 1.7 per cent—1.7 per cent, in similar circumstances, to 11.4 per cent. This is a huge national achievement, with an underlying rate of 0.4 per cent for the quarter and 3 per cent for the year—the lowest rate since statistics were first recorded in 1971. Those low levels have been preserved through the Accord which the Government established and by the operation of monetary policy.

PARA.TAB: In contrast, the Leader of the Opposition wants to wreck that result. He wants to introduce a consumption tax that will add 5 to 6 percentage points to the price system. Not content with the lowest inflation rate in two decades, and with it the lowest interest rates that we have seen since, he now wants to take something which has taken us two decades to achieve by reductions in real wages, by changes in productivity, by a total change in the way in which the economy operates. He wants to sabotage the inflation rate by the addition of an ideologically, maniacally driven proposal to tax the food and clothing of Australians and their services and to drive the inflation rate back towards double digits. That is the contribution that he intends to make.
But the Leader of the Opposition ought to be measured by his words in the recent past. In February 1990 he said:

ANSWER.PARA: Double digit inflation. If you can't control and reduce inflation, you can't and shouldn't govern Australia.

The corollary of that is that if you can control and reduce inflation you should govern Australia. He has got his head down; he is ignoring that one. He is studiously ignoring that one. Poor little fellow, he cannot get an answer up.

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—He continued:

ANSWER.PARA: For the sixth time in seven years the Treasurer —
has failed to deliver an effective anti-inflation strategy—
All the way down to 1.7 per cent—as the Treasurer said today, to zero—but I failed to deliver an anti-inflation strategy! The third paragraph states:

The Treasurer has obviously given up on inflation control. Accord mark VI announced today will lead to higher inflation and higher interest rates. It will increase the likelihood of a major collapse in the Australian dollar. The likely economic consequences: 7—8% inflation.
At the very least it will yield more of the same, 7 to 8 per cent inflation.
Home mortgage rates stuck at 16 to 18 % business loans of 21+%. However, the `high risks' are double digit inflation, the risk of a major exchange rate crisis, a consequential rise in interest rates.
He was doing the same thing then in February 1990, just two years ago—this person who claims economic credentials, this elitistly educated, highly educated person.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

—The professor forecast double digit inflation. He forecast inflation of 16 to 18 per cent with business loans at 21 per cent plus and a major risk to the exchange rate. In fact, he has been wrong on all counts. That was the response that he put out to accord mark VI. I simply say to the public, to the House and to the journalists that nearly everything this person produces by way of what he claims to be a view of the future in relation to the economy is fallacious and inspired by his own gloomy view which wants to visit onto this economy more hurt and contumely than the place ought to tolerate or ought to stand. But not to be outdone, and still at it in November of 1991, he talked in the same terms. Then this year, on 27 February, he said:

ANSWER.PARA: I reckon we'll have a major exchange rate crisis if this policy is going to run.

We knew what you reckoned, but you were wrong again. You are wrong again. You have always been wrong. You were wrong with your policies in the seventies and the early eighties. You were wrong with your forecasts. You are wrong with your policy proposals now. It would be a sin to sabotage the national inflation rate; it would be a sin to put this major inflation gain asunder—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Corinella will cease interjecting.
—all in the interests of a manic determination to impose a new tax on Australians—
—One million unemployed and you are right, are you?
—Order! The honourable member for Kooyong!

—and to transfer wealth from the low paid to the high paid in satisfaction of the miserable and narrow objective you have always pursued as a party. Today's zero inflation for the quarter and 1.7 per cent for the year is a policy triumph and a great benefit for the people of Australia to give them a permanently lower inflation rate, low structural inflation, low interest rates, and with them the prospects of sustainable economic growth into the 1990s with low inflation.
—He is claiming your scalp.
—Order! The Minister for Immigration!

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I ask the Minister: is it a fact that senior members of the Government bargained for a public office with senior ACTU official, Miss Jenny Acton? Did Miss Acton voluntarily step aside from a guaranteed position as the Labor candidate for Hotham at the 1990 election in favour of the present Minister for Primary Industries and Energy on the understanding that she would be provided with a position on the Industrial Relations Commission at a future suitable time? Did this deal have anything to do with Commissioner Turbet's recently strongly worded resignation, rubbishing the Prime Minister and your colleague the Minister for Industrial Relations, in which he, inter alia, deplored the stacking of the Commission with ACTU nominees?
—Order! The Leader of the House will cease interjecting!

PARA.TAB: Mr Grace interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. The honourable member for Fowler will cease interjecting.
—You should not be here, Simon.
—The honourable member for Bass will cease interjecting.

—Mr Speaker, it certainly is ironic, in the context of what is happening in New South Wales, to hear Liberals talking about stacking. But let me say in relation to the question that has been asked that I know of no such agreement. Miss Acton, I must say, at one stage was on my staff and was a very good staffer for me. But she has been back with the ACTU for quite some time, and would doubtless perform well in whatever area of the industrial relations system she was operating in. The Commission, of course, has been changed over the years. There has been an increase in the number of union oriented people who are members of it.

PARA.TAB: Mr McLachlan interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Barker!
—This is because under the previous Government there were virtually no people appointed from the union side of the industrial relations system.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Rubbish.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

—There were, Mr Speaker, the odd one or two token appointments and some reasonable people were appointed to those very few positions that were made available to the union side. But amongst the presidential members, there were virtually none. In fact, off the cuff I cannot think of any who were there at that time who came from the union side or even who were lawyers who had been operating at the Bar but appearing for unions, apart from those who may have been appointed at the time of the Whitlam Government.

PARA.TAB: Mr Smith interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Bass and the Leader of the House!

—So what had happened over many years is that the Commission had essentially represented at the presidential level lawyers who had operated overwhelmingly for the employer side of the system. There was very little representation at that level of people who appeared for the union side. What has happened under this Government is that there has been a balancing up.

PARA.TAB: Mr Sharp interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I warn the honourable member for Gilmore.

—There have been appointments made to the Commission at the presidential level which have meant that there is now a reasonable balance between presidential members who came from the employer side, or represented it being members of the Bar, and those who have come from the union side. At the commissioner level, similarly, there has been a balancing up. That is as it should be. We make no apologies for that, because it is appropriate that the Commission reflects in its make up the nature of the parties who are appearing before it. It is absolutely wrong to do as Liberal governments did for decades and stack the Commission with people who represented one side of the system only—particularly at the presidential level, but even at the commissioner level. It is absolutely right for us to have corrected that imbalance and to have made the Commission a much more balanced body in relation to the parties who appear before it than it ever was in the previous days of the Liberal-National Party Government.
—Who gets the next vacancy?
—Order! If the honourable member for Bass interjects again, I will name him.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Will he advise the House of the importance that the Government attaches to regional economic development, particularly as it relates to the canegrowing areas of rural Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. The Government does consider the question of regional economic development as crucial to economic development generally in this country. What we are aiming to look for is greater economic diversity in regional economic centres providing for sustained levels of growth in those centres and, obviously, increased job opportunities.

PARA.TAB: What it really means, and it has been a theme that I have been pushing from this portfolio for some time, is not that we become less reliant on our commodity base but that we do more with it. That is particularly the case in relation to the sugar industry. Reports that have been referred to over recent days demonstrate that there is enormous potential for value adding in the sugar industry.

But it is not going to happen on its own. That is why, quite apart from the broader economic settings that this Government has developed, there are specific programs that can assist industries such as the sugar industry but are not limited to it. Those programs include the marketing skills program; the innovative agricultural marketing program, of which the sugar industry, I might add, has been a recent beneficiary; local government development initiatives that are developed through the office of my colleague the Minister for Local Government; and RIBES, the rural industries business extension service, which was giving to the rural sector what the urban sector had in NIES—and together with that scheme there was introduced in the last Budget under my submission a business advice for rural areas scheme.

I might add that these are the types of programs that Fightback would abolish in the Opposition's desperate desire to cut back on its government expenditure proposals. Those programs highlight our position when it comes to regional economic development and recognise the need for consultation and working with industry, identifying the impediments to those industries and using programs, such as the ones that I have mentioned, to facilitate genuine development; in other words, they recognise that there is a legitimate proactive role for government in working with industry to get these initiatives going.

Let us contrast where the coalition stands when it comes to regional economic development. Where does it stand in relation to the sugar industry? We had the opportunity to address this in part yesterday. The coalition has not asked a question on it, I might add, despite the furore it has caused within its own ranks. It is locked into a zero tariff position which will be determined by the Industry Commission's report. We already know what the draft report is; we will have to await the outcome of the final report.

As the events of the last week have demonstrated, the leadership of the National Party will do and say anything to shore up the Liberal's position and to get behind the Fightback document. Yesterday we saw the honourable member for Dawson resign his position. He has now been replaced by the honourable member for Maranoa.

Whilst I repeat publicly what I have said to him privately, that I congratulate him on his appointment, the question we have to ask ourselves is: what has really changed? We have, in the place of the honourable member for Dawson, a member of the National Party and a Queenslander. He does not have a sugar seat but what did he have to say earlier this week on the sugar tariff question? I will quote an article in the Australian of 21 April by Tim Stevens and Kevin Meade:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . Mr Bruce Scott, said he did not support a drop in the sugar tariff on July 1.

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—An article by Robert Garran in the Australian Financial Review of the same date states:

ANSWER.PARA: Queensland MHRs Mr Bruce Scott and Mr Warren Truss said yesterday they would support moves to suspend the tariff cuts.
I simply say that what we have got in this place is the same horse but a different jockey. The question we have to ask ourselves is: what has changed on your side of politics—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Banks will cease interjecting.
—What has changed on your side of politics that enables you to hold that seat on the front bench, given the resignation of the honourable member for Dawson?

PARA.TAB: The final point I would go to is the question of the Leader of the National Party. I emphasise the point that the Leader of the National Party will do and say anything to shore up his coalition partners. The Leader of the National Party was interviewed by Laurie Oakes last weekend. In response to a question from Laurie Oakes, he said:

ANSWER.PARA: Ours will deliver massive cost benefits, cost reductions, through abolishing payroll tax, sales tax, fuel excise tax to industry, including the sugar industry.
But, I mean, sugar farmers don't pay payroll tax. They use diesel in their tractors, not petrol, and they get a rebate on their wholesale sales tax so there is not much in it for them, is there?
The Leader of the National Party said:
I am pleased to see you have done your homework.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: that is absolutely wrong. Treasury, and your own document, have said that Fightback will save $288m of sales tax, $679m of fuel tax and over $150m of—
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the National Party will contain himself for a moment. The House will come to order.
—I am just reminding him of what Treasury said.
—If the Deputy Leader of the National Party continues to interject, I will deal with him.
—I know they are sensitive, Mr Speaker. They deserve to be because they are caught out every time the analysis continues.

PARA.TAB: In relation to this great gain, those opposite hide the fact that every percentage point increase in inflation will add a $1,200 cost increase to each farmer. You go around trumpeting these great savings that this package of yours will produce. Apart from the fact that very little of it applies to these farmers, we have a position in which we have been able to indicate today that our policies have produced an annual inflation rate of 1.7 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —How long are you going to talk for?
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Mackellar!

—Your figures will inflate it back up to double digits. That is a great proposition for farmers who are looking for cost reductions! Where is your strategy in terms of the canegrowers and regional economic development? It involves zero tariffs; no support for the industry, without any consultation with it; increased inflation and, therefore, increased costs; negligible tax benefits—and a consumption tax to boot!

PARA.TAB: I simply conclude and advise the new member to the front bench on the other side that I am very interested in what coalition really stands for, when we have seen the division over the past couple of weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Selective quoting.
—Order! The Leader of the National Party!

—I looked in the dictionary and found that the definition of `coalition' is a temporary combination of parties that retain distinctive principles. Mr Speaker, that says it all. We have the old protectionists over there. We have a bunch of ideologically driven free traders in the Liberal Party, which the leadership of the National Party blindly follows. That combination is very temporary. The lemmings are lining up behind the honourable member for Dawson at the cliff face.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of members, including Ministers, have inadvertently left information off the register. The registrar has periodically written to them and they have corrected the situation. Senator Richardson wrote to me today saying that he apologised for failing to note his directorship of 2HD on his pecuniary interests forms. He went on to say:

ANSWER.PARA: I want to emphasise that the omission on my part was not motivated by any attempt to conceal knowledge from yourself or the Parliament. My directorship was well known by Cabinet colleagues, the party generally and was a matter of public record.
I am not aware of any instance when a conflict of interest may have arisen.
I accept both the apology and the assurance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I ask the Prime Minister to table the document from which he was reading.
—Was the Prime Minister quoting from a document?
—Yes. I was quoting from a document which I am quite happy to—
—Is the document confidential?
—Well, it is to me; but I am quite happy to table it.
—The Prime Minister has tabled the document.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Does the Government intend to introduce legislation encouraging the making of enterprise agreements, and should employees lose award entitlements if they do not enter into those agreements?

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Surely a question to a Minister asking whether the Government intends to introduce legislation is requesting an announcement of policy, and the question is then out of order.
—Order! There is a distinction between asking about policy and about the introduction of legislation. In the past there have been many questions asking Ministers about introducing legislation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we outlined in our One Nation statement, the Government will introduce legislation to facilitate the making of enterprise agreements. I believe that through changes to the workplace and particularly through agreements and arrangements which will be encouraged by such agreements, we can enhance productivity growth and improve the pleasure of work.

PARA.TAB: I want to emphasise very strongly that it is not the policy of this Government to force employees off awards and into agreements, which is now the real agenda of the Opposition. The honourable member for Bennelong likes to assure people that they will have a choice, under the policies of the coalition, of remaining under awards or entering into so-called voluntary agreements. But the Leader of the Opposition let the truth slip in Perth in January and in New Zealand recently. In Perth he said:

ANSWER.PARA: If I could have my way, almost immediately no more wage increases, unless they are negotiated at a workplace by workplace level, all around Australia. No more centralised wage determination. That is the fundamental of the process of change. You can do it.
He then made it clear in New Zealand when he said:

The Federal coalition is flirting with a plan for swiftly deregulating the labour market by scrapping the awards that provide the real underpinnings of Australia's wage and industrial relations system.
The piece went on to say:

The Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, alluded to a radical change in the coalition's policy and a sharp differentiation from the Government's approach to labour reform during his tour of New Zealand.
But every time the Leader of the Opposition steps out of line, the honourable member for Bennelong jumps in with a fix. This time, he says:
Our policy is to give people the choice to allow people to go outside the centralised wage system if they wish. If they want to remain within the award system that is okay.

But at the same time he says that he will abolish centralised wage fixation. The fact is that under this policy, 80 per cent of Australian employees who work under awards would find that they had lost their entitlements to rates of pay, penalty awards, annual leave and working hours. All of the things which have been built up under awards over generations would be just wiped away by such an approach.

PARA.TAB: We found the Australian Chamber of Commerce coming out to support this proposal. In a statement, Mr Brent Davis said:

ANSWER.PARA: Reported plans by the Federal Opposition to scrap Federal awards are worthy of further debate and should not be dismissed out of hand. While this radical idea has been much discussed within employers' circles and derives from reforms achieved in New Zealand, it is the first time it has been promoted by a senior politician/political leader in this country.
Dr Hewson's big bang approach would certainly destroy one of the major impediments to the necessary quantum shift towards bona fide enterprise bargaining outside the centralised tribunal.

Big bang is right. This is the policy setting: in the unlikely consequence of a Hewson government being elected, first of all there would be the addition of five to seven percentage points in the price system to inflation. Overnight the inflation rate would rise towards double digits; overnight the floor under inflation would rise and interest rates would rise with it. Very quickly there would be the big bang in industrial relations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. You just ruled that it was proper for the Prime Minister to announce new Government legislation, which was the purpose of the question. Surely, consequently standing order 145 applies. Somehow or other the question as to whether such legislation would be introduced has got us to a speech on inflation and the effects of other tax measures. Can the Prime Minister either complete his answer as to what his Government intends to do or sit down?
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat. The Prime Minister was asked a question about enterprise agreements and about whether people should be—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Honourable members on my left will cease interjecting. The Prime Minister was asked a question about enterprise agreements and legislation and about whether people would be taken off awards in that area. The Prime Minister is answering the question. He has digressed, and he might come back to the question.

—Such a big bang approach would see the greatest confrontation between labour and business that we have ever seen in this country. Instead of having an approach where there is a national effort to keep inflation down and a focus on productivity—
—Do you think being unemployed is better?
—Order! The honourable member for Moore will cease interjecting.

—Instead of a focus on productivity to lift productivity through enterprise agreements—instead of lower inflation and higher productivity—simply confrontation, division, argument, nastiness and viciousness at the workplace would all be part and parcel of the agenda of this ideologically motivated party opposite.

PARA.TAB: While all of that was happening, we would see a consumption tax introduced which would raise just on $30 billion, when now the total taxation revenue of the Commonwealth is of the order of $70 billion. That is almost a 50 per cent equivalent of the current revenue of the Commonwealth levied on every Australian's necessities of life—food, clothing, services, et cetera. That is the sort of big bang that Mr Davis refers to in his article, and the big bang that would put Australia so far back in terms of the cohesiveness of our society, in terms of getting along and in terms of going after the main chance: jobs, growth, product and exports. Instead of all of that, we would go back to the fruitless confrontation we saw in the late 1970s when the Leader of the Opposition was advising the then Government. That is what his statements in New Zealand mean.

All Australian workers who feel comforted by the protections they have under award classifications for such things as rates of pay, annual leave, penalty rates and the rest—nearly a century of industrial effort—would find it all swept away in an ideological binge which would put the nation further behind than we could possibly imagine, in a clash of interests the likes of which we have never seen in recent times.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Prime Minister, relates to the Minister for Transport and Communications. The Prime Minister would be aware that Senator Richardson was a director of 2HD from 20 September 1990 until today, according to records of the ASC. Did Senator Richardson participate in the 1991 Cabinet decision to reduce licence fees by $8m to the radio industry? What was the benefit to the radio station 2HD? Did Senator Richardson reveal his pecuniary interest in the matter during the Cabinet meetings? Would the Prime Minister agree that the last sentence of the letter that he has just tabled, in which Senator Richardson says, `I am not aware of any circumstances when a conflict of interest may have arisen', is false? Does the Prime Minister still hold to the view that no disciplinary action is required?

—He was appointed to the post on 21 September 1990. He was appointed Minister on 14 January. On 20 January he signed and dispatched letters to the New South Wales Labor Party resigning his directorship.
—Labor Party?
—Yes; it is owned by the Labor Party. That is, for a period of six days, from 14 January 1992 to 20 January, he was Minister for Transport and Communications.
—He was a Minister in the Cabinet.
—He was a Cabinet Minister during the period.

PARA.TAB: Mr Smith interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Bass will resume his seat.
—His directorship of 2HD, and his stewardship of that station, has extended over a period of nearly two decades. That is known to practically everyone in public affairs.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Prime Minister, I think you have missed the point.
—Order!
—The question is: he was a member of the Cabinet—
—Order! There is no point of order.
—Without revealing his pecuniary interests. Do you believe there is a matter of discipline?
—Order! The honourable member for Bass will resume his seat. The Prime Minister has answered the question.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. I warn the honourable member for Kooyong. I might say to honourable members on both sides that the next step after a warning is to be named.

PARA.TAB: Mr Broadbent interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I warn the honourable member for Corinella.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training in his capacity as representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Can the Minister advise the House of the progress the Government has made in bringing about micro-economic reform in road, rail and on the waterfront? What prospects are there for bringing about an effective interface between land and sea transport for the first time in this country?

—I am delighted to have that question from the honourable gentleman. I know from experience in the portfolio when I held it that he was a very active man in this area. I understand he has recently been taking some councils and other people interested in regional development in his electorate around the airport, the freeway, rail yards and the waterfront showing them the changes that have been taking place.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will cease interjecting.

—The question is particularly relevant, given the comments being made by the Leader of the Opposition on what is required of Australian statesmen as they visit our neighbours and people further afield. Evidently, what he considers an adequate performance is to present them with a copy of Fightback! as they sit down and to say, `This is what we intend to do on the waterfront'.

PARA.TAB: It was of passing interest that he should have recommended that to the Prime Minister in Indonesia. If he had told the Indonesian President that he thought it was a really terrific idea to put the soldiers in against the Australian watersiders, he might have triggered a memory of when the Indonesians had some reason for considerable gratitude and expressed it to members of the Australian waterfront.

The nub of the question goes to the heart of what is micro-economic reform in this country. That is, you can take the process so far with changes in work practices on the waterfront or anywhere else in the transport industry and then you come up to an irreducible minimum. If you are really going to lower costs to people who wish to use those facilities for export, and if you are really going to achieve something for the Australian national economy, you run up against an archaic infrastructure. You cannot get around that.

The reforms we have introduced on the waterfront have more than exceeded the targets set in October 1992 when we expected that there would be a cut of one-third in waterfront labour. We have already achieved 40 per cent, and waterfront labour will be halved. The productivity gains have been even greater than anyone had expected. Accordingly, the costs are falling to those who utilise the waterfront. Those reforms will be in place over the next 12 months. Those will be the reforms that are required as far as work practices are concerned on the waterfront. What you then run up against is the fact that you cannot get competition between Australian ports because the infrastructure of our rail transport around the country is archaic and the road-rail interface with the waterfronts is also archaic.

The One Nation statement went right to the heart of that. It provided $30m for the standard gauge rail link to Fisherman Islands to enhance the ability of the port of Brisbane to operate land bridging services and hence provide greater competition to southern ports on Pacific basin routes; $20m for the upgrading of Melbourne's Dynon terminal to facilitate the standardisation of the Melbourne-Adelaide railway to allow for improvements to services to Sydney and Brisbane and also to allow the port of Melbourne to compete more effectively with other ports; and $5m for a direct connection between Swanson and Appleton docks and Dynon rail terminal to reduce double handling of containers, reduce cargo handling time and allow the port of Melbourne to compete more effectively with other ports.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's closed today with strikes.

—My friend, if you get into office it will be closed with trenches, not with strikes. The statement also provides $8m for the construction of a rail loop at Outer Harbour in Adelaide which will form part of a $100m upgrading of the port. This will provide more competition between ports and involves an innovative approach to reducing delays and costs at the sea-land interface; $13m for improving the Fremantle-Kalgoorlie line to enhance the ability of the port of Fremantle to operate land bridging services to the eastern States; and there are others for the port in Townsville.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that anybody who knows anything about the essential elements of micro-economic reform in this country knows that, unless those infrastructure issues are addressed, all promises as far as micro-economic reform and what it might well deliver via the transport sector are concerned are irrelevant, non-attainable. Everybody in the car industry knows this. Everybody in industries that are attempting to export knows that. They know that, when they are presented with options, such as the tariff proposals in the car industry that the Opposition puts forward, and when the Opposition says, `But you will have these other benefits', it is baloney; they know it is nonsense. That is why they are developing this hostility at the inability of the Opposition to understand that it is not going to deliver what it talks about. The Opposition's position on every one of these propositions that I have put forward is to oppose them.

There will be a requirement in the future to address further issues. As far as the infrastructure of rail and ports is concerned, this is not going to be the end of the matter. There is absolutely nothing in Fightback which addresses this in terms of enhancing those capacities. All there is in Fightback and in subsequent statements is a decision not to proceed with them and to criticise the Government for doing so. This means that the micro-economic reform position of the Opposition in the transport sector falls flat on its face.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a filibuster.
—Order! The honourable member for Gippsland will cease interjecting.

—The Opposition will be able to deliver absolutely nothing in micro-economic reform to producers in this country. Even though past loyalties, as far as the Opposition is concerned, amongst the business community would indicate—

—Another three minutes.

—On a point of order, Mr Speaker.
—Order! I call the Prime Minister on a point of order.
—I warn the honourable member for Gippsland.
—I did no such thing. I did not require the Leader to lengthen his reply.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Order!
—I was quite prepared to take other questions. I will now not take them and ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Order! The House will come to order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Forrest will cease interjecting. The House will come to order.
—He is walking out.
—Order! If the honourable member for Gippsland interjects again I will name him. I call the Leader of the National Party on a point of order.

—First, I have a point of order. If he is going to get as technical as that, he has not required the end of Question Time in the time-honoured fashion. I therefore put a question to him. I ask the Prime Minister—

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The continued domination of Australia's industrial relations system by the ACTU as exemplified by Mr Ken Turbet's resignation from the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just as we saw at the conclusion of Question Time today a monumental exhibition from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of this country of the contempt in which he holds the Parliament of this country, so it is that over the past few days we have had from a man who has spent 40 years of his life devoted to the broad labour movement in this country the most extraordinary denunciation of the conduct of industrial relations that has ever been delivered by somebody who has held some of the highest positions available in the labour movement. Before I come to the substance of the domination of industrial relations in Australia by the ACTU, and before I come to an analysis of the reasons for Mr Turbet's resignation from the Industrial Relations Commission, let me pick up some words that were uttered by the Prime Minister during Question Time when he rather laboriously, unable to rapidly read a pre-typed answer, tried to denigrate the industrial relations policies of the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: He tried that old Labor favourite of saying, `If you elect the Liberals you are going to have industrial relations confrontation. You are going to have brother against brother, Australian against Australian, and you are going to divide the country right down the middle'. Not only does that pass rather strange from the lips of a man who has done more over the last weeks to divide this country than any Prime Minister since the end of World War II, but it is also redolent of the fearmongering approach that is adopted by the Australian Labor Party towards anything associated with industrial relations. No matter how scurrilous the claim, no matter how insubstantial the allegations, the clarion call of the Labor Party and the leaders of the labour movement between now and the election campaign will be, `If you elect the Liberals there will be industrial mayhem and confrontation. There will be a wholesale destruction of working conditions', and so on.

The only thing the Labor Party has for sale between now and the next election is fear, loathing and lies. That is all we will get from the Labor Party. From now until the next election there will be no serious putting forward of an alternative policy prescription for this country and there will be no attempt to address the fundamental weaknesses of the Australian economy. There will be lies about our taxation policy; there will be lies about our industrial relations policy; there will be further lies about Australian history. And from now until the next election we will have a campaign of fearmongering and loathing, the like of which we have not yet seen—all in the name of uniting the Australian nation! After all, the supreme obligation of any Prime Minister of this country is to heal and unite, not to wound and divide. Yet this man has done more to wound and divide the Australian community and he is going to do it in relation to industrial relations, as he has done it in relation to the flag, as he has done it in relation to Australian history, and as he is doing it in relation to the goods and services tax.

When the Prime Minister talked about confrontation and about industrial mayhem, I was reminded of a discussion that I had in 1977 with the then President of the ACTU. I must say that he was not turned out as well then as he subsequently was as Prime Minister of Australia; nonetheless, there he was as the President of the ACTU. I met him in company with the then head of the Public Service unions, Mr Paul Munro—who, incidentally, is now a deputy president of the Industrial Relations Commission and a man with whom, I should say, I attended the Sydney University Law School between 1957 and 1960. I am very happy to make his reacquaintance at reunion dinners of students in that particular year. I hold nothing against the man personally; he held a very high union position in this country in the 1970s.

The relevance of that meeting was that I, as the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, was then responsible for putting into the Parliament section 45D of the Trade Practices Act, which went on to become the most effective weapon available to the business community in Australia against predatory union conduct. I still remember Bob Hawke, as President of the ACTU, jabbing his finger in the air in a very excited way, saying, `Howard, if you go ahead with this, there will be blood in the streets, there will be Australian against Australian, and you will divide the country down the middle'.That was the warning that Hawke gave. That was the measure of the exaggeration of the then President of the ACTU. I put in the same category the claims made by the Prime Minister today. The reality is that after the next election the ACTU will work with the elected government of this country. It will fulminate and fume and rant and rave between now and the election, but come the verdict of the Australian people installing a coalition government—as surely as it will at the next election—those leaders of the ACTU will be knocking on the door of the new Minister for industrial relations on the Monday morning and wanting to sit down and have a discussion with us.

My response, if I happen to be that Minister, or the response of whoever the Minister will be, will simply be, `Yes, we will deal with you. We will treat you as an important element in Australian society, but we will not invite you in as a member of the Government. We will not hand over to you the administration of industrial relations'. We will not create the sort of thing that Ken Turbet resigned in protest against, and that is an industrial relations system run by the ACTU, of the ACTU and for the ACTU, because that is the industrial relations system that this country has.

I have no doubt in my mind that over the last year we have seen an even greater increase in the power of the ACTU, to the neglect of the Industrial Relations Commission—which, for reasons that I will explain in a moment, is of no great concern to me—and, importantly, to the denigration of the responsible Minister of the Crown.

When Bob Hawke was the President of the ACTU, he had a rather endearing description of Bill Kelty, who was a research assistant before he became Secretary. He used to call him the sorcerer's apprentice. I think it can fairly truthfully be said that the apprentice has now become the sorcerer, and far from the Minister becoming the apprentice, I do not think he has even reached the status of being on work experience. If ever there was a devalued, denigrated, irrelevant Minister for industrial relations, it is the current Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook).

Industrial relations in this country is run by Bill Kelty and Paul Keating. They are the two who decided a year ago to reject the national wage case decision of the Industrial Relations Commission. My Government friend sitting on the front bench knows as well as I do—because he does know something about the background of the industrial relations system in this country—that one of the greatest mistakes the Government ever made in industrial relations in this country was to reject the decision of the full bench a year ago. What the Government was doing was kneecapping its own umpire. It was kneecapping the best friend it had. It was destroying the authority of the self-appointed umpire in the Australian industrial relations system.

That did not trouble me, because we quite openly want to reduce the role of the Industrial Relations Commission. We are quite unashamed about that. We will ask the Parliament of this country to reduce the role of the Industrial Relations Commission. We will ask the Parliament of this country to create a situation which effectively abolishes compulsory arbitration. There is no argument about it; there is no secret about it; we are not coy about it. We believe that every worker and every employer in this country should have the right, if they so choose, to make a voluntary arrangement right outside the industrial relations system. We believe in writing a law that will give people an incentive to go outside the system. We will preserve the right, if both parties want to remain within the system, to have their terms and conditions of employment, work practices, hours of work and so forth governed by industrial awards.

The Prime Minister falsely alleged that workers will have their conditions driven down. They will not. There will be a minimum wage calculated on an hourly rate. There will be minimum requirements regarding such things as annual leave and sick leave. But let me make it abundantly clear to all members of the Government, in case there is any doubt on their side, that we believe that such matters as penalty rates, the length of the working week, overtime, holiday loadings and all of those things that are holding back the needed flexibility in Australia's industrial relations system ought to be matters for negotiation between employers and employees. We do not shy away from that. We do not walk away from it for a moment.

The truth is that if 300 overseas tourists arrive in this country at 12 midnight at Tullamarine Airport, they want the same service as that given to 300 foreigners who arrive in this country at 11 o'clock on Tuesday morning.
