But under the ridiculous industrial laws of Australia, it costs about 15 or 20 per cent more to provide those services at 12 midnight than it does at 11 o'clock on Tuesday morning. That situation has to change.

At the moment we are witnessing the destruction of the authority of the Industrial Relations Commission within the existing industrial relations system. Whilst that in a sense aids the case of the Opposition, it is taking place in circumstances where power over industrial relations is passing more and more to the ACTU. When Ken Turbet resigned he gave three reasons. Remember that Mr Turbet had been appointed to the Commission in 1977. He was appointed by Tony Street when he was the coalition Minister. Ken Turbet had run one of the largest public sector unions in Australia. He has been a supporter of the labour movement for over 40 years.

The first reason he gave for resigning was one that would be familiar to all of us and familiar to most Australians—he did not trust the word of the Government. He said, `I don't trust you'. This is a man of 40 years experience in the labour movement, a man steeped in the tradition of industrial labour. He knows where the bodies are buried. No wonder he wrote to the Minister and said, `I don't trust you. Your word can't be relied upon'.

The second thing he complained about was the increasing power of the ACTU. He did not mince words. He said that effectively industrial relations in Australia is run by Kelty and Keating and nobody else, and the idea that it is a consensus is a complete joke. The third thing he complained about was the ignorance of the Minister regarding the constitutional role of the Industrial Relations Commission.

One of the extraordinary things about the debate initiated by the Prime Minister about our cultural identity is that every so often the Prime Minister says, `The trouble with you blokes over there is that you want to hang onto everything British'. The thing is—and it occurs in the context of industrial relations—that we do not want to hang onto everything British; we want to hang onto only those things British that are good and are working, such as a system of constitutional government, a liberal press, the cultural values that we have inherited and are working, and the most comprehensive, evocative language in the world. They are the things we want to hang onto. But I can tell you, brother, that the things British you want to hang onto are the things that are not working—outdated trade union notions. That is the crazy thing. Every Australian would know that over the last 20 years, anyone who turned on the television set and heard a whingeing shop steward would think not of Belgrade, Rome, Athens or Philadelphia, but of Manchester or Glasgow.

Why does the Prime Minister not break his cultural cringe to British trade unionism? Why does he not end it? Why does he not understand that we do not want to hang onto things British just because they are British. We want to hang onto things British that are worth preserving. I make no apology for that, and I think we are a better country for having the fortitude and the capacity to pick the good from the bad.

The Prime Minister's problem is that he is locked into a pre-world War I industrial relations system and he is locked into trade union attitudes that owe more to our British connection than to anything else. Can I please ask him: why does he not throw out the bad things British and hang onto the good things British?

TALK.START.PARA: —That was an extraordinary contribution from the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) which had little, if anything, to do with the supposed subject of the matter of public importance. Anyone listening to this debate should bear in mind at the outset that, if we are talking about industrial relations in this country, then we are talking about one area which is absolutely unarguably an area of great success for this Government.

PARA.TAB: We know that there has been a marked change in the whole industrial relations environment since this Government came into office. The whole vogue of confrontation, which was the way industrial relations were pursued by the parties, by the Government, in the period until we came into office, was one of massive confrontation. The unions and the employers confronted each other heavily; the Government continually made confrontationist noises and it took confrontationist approaches to the unions. It carried a big stick but got beaten around the head quite often by the trade union movement. It was totally unable to control either industrial relations or the wages outcome.

All that has changed since this Government came into office. We have seen a dramatic change in industrial relations. That whole confrontationist approach has gone. That is not to say, of course, that there are no disputes; of course there are disputes, but the basic attitudes of the parties have changed remarkably. There is much more of an air of cooperation in the workplaces of this country now than there has ever been in our history, and it shows up in the industrial dispute figures. There has been a 60 per cent reduction in the level of industrial disputation since this Government came into office in terms of working days lost per thousand employees against that experienced under the previous Government. That is a remarkable reduction in industrial disputation.

If we look at the wages outcome we see that it has been much lower under this Government. Despite all the confrontation, despite the antagonism, the average wage increase under the Fraser Government was 11.4 per cent; the average wage increase per annum under this Government has been 6.4 per cent, which is remarkably less. The result of that is that we have been able to get costs down compared with what they would have been under the previous Government.

There has been an inflation rate reduction. Today we have seen an inflation rate of zero for this quarter, an annual rate of 1.7 per cent. A few years ago, in the late 1980s and the beginning of the 1990s, we went through a very high level of activity. Normally we would have expected wages to have an absolute blow-out as they did in the early 1980s, but what happened? We had no wages blow-out at all. The wages policy being pursued by this Government and the industrial relations arrangements which were in place were such that it enabled us to have a very good wages outcome, given the level of economic activity. As we have moved into recession, that level of wages outcome has dropped even further.

We are seeing very responsible wages outcomes and greatly reduced levels of industrial disputation enabling a much greater increase in efficiency. Now there is a move to enterprise bargaining, which is a major change in the system of industrial relations in this country, and which has been brought about by agreement between the parties and the Government, with the endorsement, eventually, of the Industrial Relations Commission. This means that we are now moving into an area where industrial relations is being focused much more heavily at the workplace than was ever the case before.

There is general agreement around the nation that that should happen. Employers and unions have agreed that that is the way things should move. It is the view of both parties in this House. Both the Government and the Opposition agree that that is the way things should go—although the Opposition wants to take a far more extreme approach. At least industrial relations is moving in the direction of the enterprise level in a quite unambiguous way. That is happening under a system which has been pursued by this Government.

Of course, despite all those successes, nothing ever goes entirely smoothly in industrial relations. There have been some difficulties and differences between the Government and the Commission in recent times. Presumably that is the basis for this matter of public importance raised by the shadow Minister for industrial relations, the honourable member for Bennelong—although he hardly referred to it. That difference between the Government and the Industrial Relations Commission stems essentially from two items: one is the national wage decision of April last year; the other is the salaries of members of the Commission.

Let me say that it is indeed unfortunate that we have had those differences. We have had a very harmonious relationship during the period until that time. I will just go quickly to the reason for those differences. The decision in April last year was a great disappointment to this Government, and I would have thought it was also a great disappointment to the Opposition. The Commission refused to move to a system of enterprise bargaining.

At that time a case was being argued in which most of the unions, most of the employers, most of the States and the Federal Government all said to the Commission, `Let us move to a system of enterprise bargaining', and the Commission said no. That was a great disappointment to all the parties. Subsequent to that decision the Government indicated its disappointment with it. Some reasonably tough things were said, but basically the Government was expressing its disappointment about the Commission's not making a move which was generally seen as the right move to make. The fact that some of the Commission's language in its decision was derogatory to the parties did not help in the reception of its decision, either.

At the end of last year we had a decision which brought in enterprise bargaining. In a sense, as far as we are concerned, that is behind us. We have now got that decision. We are moving to that system quite rapidly. The Government is pleased that that is happening. Obviously there was a problem which was referred to by Commissioner Turbet in his letter of resignation at about that time and obviously some continuing hurt has been felt by some members of the Commission about comments made at that time by the Government in relation to the decision.

There has also been the matter of salaries. This is an issue which, again, is an unfortunate one that has caused such angst. The House should be aware that this is not an issue of dispute between the Government and the Opposition. The Opposition, through its spokesman, the honourable member for Bennelong, has made clear that it supports the Government's approach to this issue, which has caused considerable antagonism with the Commission and led to some of the comments made by Commissioner Turbet.

When Commissioner Turbet said that he could not trust the Government, he was saying that he could not trust the Government because we would not accept the decision of the Remuneration Tribunal, a decision which said that the old system of relativities should remain and that we should not change the nexus that existed for decades between the salaries of members of the Commission and the salaries of those in the Federal Court. That meant equality for the presidential members of the Commission and the judges of the Court, with the salary of the commissioners of the Industrial Relations Commission being 70 per cent of that of Federal Court judges. We said that that nexus should be broken, and we were supported by the Opposition. When Commissioner Turbet then criticised us and said that the Government could not be trusted to keep its word because we broke that nexus, the Opposition seized on that and said, `You cannot trust the Government'. But the Opposition supported our decision that brought down that criticism from Commissioner Turbet. What a ridiculous position those opposite are in on this issue!

Of course, the decision of the Government to break that nexus was an important one. That decision was taken quite consciously because we believed that it was inappropriate—at a time when wage and salary earners throughout this country had been through quite a number of years of very tight wages policy and a reduced level of real wages and at a time when we continued to be faced with a very tight wages policy—for the Remuneration Tribunal to decide in 1990 that there should be a 14 per cent increase in the incomes of the presidential members and commissioners of the Industrial Relations Commission. That was way out of kilter with what members of the work force were getting, the people whose wages are largely set by the members of the Commission. So the Commission would have been setting wages principles which gave wage and salary earners much less than 14 per cent, but would have been getting 14 per cent for its members. We believed that was quite inappropriate and that, therefore, in those circumstances we should change that nexus.

We set about doing that. It was a long and complicated process and I will not bore the House with the details. Essentially, it meant breaking the Remuneration Tribunal's original decision. Eventually, a committee of review—the Gleeson Committee—made recommendations about a new structure. We asked the Remuneration Tribunal to set salaries in accordance with that structure. It refused to do that and said that it wanted the old nexus back. So in those circumstances we felt that we had no alternative but to introduce a Bill into this House which would put in place what the new nexus should be. Essentially, it will give presidential members of the Commission 95 per cent of the salaries of Federal Court judges. It will also mean that in the current circumstances they will be getting a wage increase which is more or less equal to that of the rest of the work force.

I believe that is an entirely appropriate decision by this Government. It is not easy to break longstanding relationships of salary, but it has happened from time to time in various decisions of the Commission itself. The Commission has to accept that the Government has decided that that is the appropriate way for salaries to be restructured. This continuing hurt and agro that seems to be coming from some quarters of the Commission is really very unfortunate in those circumstances.

Of course, this has led to some changes in the Commission. There have been some resignations. We have seen the resignation of Deputy President Russell Peterson, who has gone to the New South Wales Industrial Commission, and now Commissioner Turbet has resigned. Those resignations are unfortunate and the Government regrets that they have occurred. But it in no way means that the Government feels in any way compelled to move away from the decision we made in relation to a proper salary structure for the members of the Commission who, after all, will still receive salaries, as presidential members, in the order of about $135,000—which is not too bad and is well above that which the vast majority of people in Australia can aspire to. Even the commissioners, who are on 70 per cent of that rate, will receive a quite substantial salary.

It is quite unfair for the Commission to imply—as it does through Commissioner Turbet's letter, if he is speaking on behalf of others—that it has been singled out in some way. The Government has rejected decisions of the Remuneration Tribunal in relation to a number of other areas—most particularly in the area of politicians' pay, where the Remuneration Tribunal's decisions have been rejected on several occasions. They have also been rejected in relation to other people, such as vice chancellors and some others who do not come to mind readily. There has certainly been no singling out of the Commission, to have commissioners' salaries rejected whilst others get the Remuneration Tribunal's decisions in full. That is not what has happened.

I believe the Commission has a continuing and important role to play in Australia's industrial relations system. It has been crucial to the implementation of the accord, for which I believe the Commission deserves considerable praise. It has made its independent decisions and it has seen that the approach through the accord between the Government and the ACTU is likely to bring about very sensible industrial relations outcomes. It has played a very substantial role in enabling those outcomes to be implemented. When it did not do that there were some difficulties between us, but we have now moved to enterprise bargaining, as not only the accord parties but also the employers and the Opposition want. So there is virtually a unanimity of view that that is the way things should go.

What is ironic about Opposition members' comments on this MPI is that in trying to say that the Commission is being harshly dealt with by the Government, they are also in a position of wanting to do great damage to the Commission. Opposition members say that the Commission would continue to exist; but there would be no centralised wage increases, according to the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), so those who would stay and try to hang onto award rates would not have much to hang onto, because they would never increase.

According to the policy announced by the Opposition shadow Minister, workers can get award rates only if both the employer and the employee agree; otherwise they have to enter into a voluntary agreement. If the Opposition gets into office, there will be very few people on award rates, the Commission will be of complete irrelevance, and far more damage will be done to people on award rates. These people will need defence against the Opposition more than they would ever need defence against any actions of this Government. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anderson Mr J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the great observable facts about this Government is that the more extreme and the more strident its rhetoric, particularly from its leader, the further from reality we can assume the talk will be. For example, we constantly hear from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that it is time we were a more truly independent nation and that we must break away from our colonial past. The reality is that, just as long ago in the real world we stopped tugging the forelock to London, we now dance to the tune of the money markets, because during the Prime Minister's term as Treasurer we were driven so deep into international hock. Now he talks of greater independence, at precisely the same time as we slide into a situation in which the bankers tell us what we can and cannot do.

PARA.TAB: When the Government swears, hand on heart, that it is not out to destroy the integrity and independence of the Industrial Relations Commission, we again need to look very closely at the reality of what really is happening. The Government's actions, as opposed to its words, plainly reflect its determination to ensure that the IRC is a mere rubber stamp.

The gulf between rhetoric and reality extends to Labor's championing of the ordinary working men and women of this nation. Despite the Government's frequently repeated claims of dedication to the rights and dignity of those people it claims to have a monopoly on representing, the reality is that Labor remains patronising and authoritarian in its attitude towards the Australian people. Not for Government members a commitment towards the sort of workplace choice and freedom that ought to be part and parcel of a nation such as ours! The evidence abounds. Labor appears determined to keep its subjects well and truly under control. It will determine, so far as it is possible, what options are available to Australians in their workplaces and what options are not.

The accord process developed by our previous Prime Minister in the early 1980s was supposedly borne of a commitment to consensus—that was the buzz word we heard a lot of eight, nine and 10 years ago. Employees, unions, industrial tribunals, governments and employers were to negotiate outcomes and arrive at a consensus reflecting what was fair, achievable and appropriate. But, somewhat like the characters in Orwell's Animal Farm, some players soon found that they were not as equal as other players.

Firstly, the employers discovered that their interests were not always seen as terribly relevant. After all, they simply paid the wages. That was their role, often regardless of whether they really had the capacity to do so or whether it was in the nation's interest. Then some of the smaller unions around the place discovered that they were not particularly wanted either. To that, we can witness the 10,000 minimum membership rule and the whole push associated with that thrust of policy development. There was little concern for the rights of individual employees to either join a union or exercise what ought to be the democratic right not to join a union. The closed shop remains a feature in far too many Australian workplace situations.

Then there was the minimum membership rule, and with that the right to belong to the union of one's choice—if one wanted to belong—began to dissipate. The choices started to contract. Where is the freedom in that? Recently, as we have heard today, having dared to show a little independence some 12 months ago, the IRC, of all the players in the barnyard, found that it, too, was seen as less than equal in the new barnyard pecking order.

The accord process is plainly not the animal that it once was. It is now about the political coordination of policy between Mr Kelty and the Prime Minister. There is not much respect for the Commission's independence there, as confirmed by its most recent and unhappy retiree and his recent and, I would have thought, very embarrassing comments on political interference and the domination of its role by both the Government and the ACTU.

While lip-service at least is paid by the Government of the need to devolve industrial relations, the reality is that the Government—or at least the Prime Minister and the ACTU's Mr Kelty—believes that it must maintain control. That is what it is all about—maintaining control. Even if there is to be enterprise bargaining, it must be monitored and controlled: do not trust the workers, they might not actually know what is best for them.

We see a refusal to make the up-front and very necessary changes to the legislation governing the Commission that would allow employers and employees to freely negotiate their own workplace agreements regardless of the desires of those participants at workplace level. The Labor movement, of course, is very keen to obscure the potential benefits to employees of effective and genuine enterprise bargaining. This is to the detriment of employees, productivity, our economic performance and, ultimately, as we are seeing only too clearly now, to Australia.

We see the Government clutching at every indication that things are turning the corner. Today it is inflation. As a farmer, somebody who is involved in a productive exercise—at least outside this place—I am very relieved to see that those inflation rates are down. But let us remember Max Walsh's comment to the effect that inflation is always down in a depression. They are his words, not mine.

The slide in our living standards is confirmed by OECD reports in recent weeks: burgeoning international debt and the tragedy that up to a third of our young people are not able to find jobs. There is a whole group of people out there who are becoming very dissatisfied with the sort of community that we have given them.

The tragedy of all this is that all these considerations are apparently deemed appropriate for the role of a mere back seat in the interests of retaining the position of both the Prime Minister and Mr Kelty. That concern is clearly reflected in the recent brawl over Troubleshooters and the upshot of all that mess. The campaign by the building unions to drive Troubleshooters out of the commercial and industrial sectors of the building industry had nothing to do with union membership because, after all, one cannot get a ticket on a building site without being a member and all its workers had union tickets; it was, in fact, about the right to work as independent contractors on commercial and industrial building sites.

The problem for the unions and for Labor relates not so much to pay levels—which are apparently quite satisfactory—or to membership, it appears to lie in the fact that those who work for themselves are a threat to unionism as it operates in Australia today, regardless of whether those people are in fact members of a union. They are hard to organise, after all; they are hard to control; they are capable of working harder and more effectively, and of doing so without regard for union directives. What is more, they might

SPEECH.PARA: expose the reality that subcontractors are often better paid in return for more efficient work practices—a vitally important principle and one that ought to be clearly established in Australia. It is interesting to note that the national social science survey indicated that 75 per cent of Australians now believe that remuneration ought be based on individual merit and those who work harder and better should be paid more than average.

PARA.TAB: The last thing that some of our more intransigent union leaders appear to want is for Australians to realise that freely negotiated contracts might well achieve better results for employees than unions in conjunction with the Industrial Relations Club, or what is left of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at SPC.

—Witness, of course, SPC, where employees saved not only their jobs by behaving in a mature and sensible fashion and by exercising choice that ought never have been denied them in the first place. They are now seeing the return of the dividends that they sacrificed as a reward for the efforts that they put in.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, in this debate over control—that is really what it is a debate about: control over people's lives and their workplace involvement—the unions involved, having exhausted both the industrial and legal channels open to them, have found a new champion—the Federal Labor Government. Senator Cook, who is a former member of the Building Workers Industrial Union, has declared the law an ass and is now seeking, as we well know, to achieve via legislation what could not otherwise be achieved.

This needs to be set against the background where less than 30 per cent of the private sector work force in this country choose to belong to a union and 15 per cent of those are no longer really financial. Plainly, ordinary Australians are voting with their feet to leave those unions which they regard as irrelevant or not working in their interests, or they will when they can. One can only speculate what would happen if we had true freedom in this area.

That is what we are about—giving people a choice. In fact, we will give them a great deal of choice: the right to belong or not to belong to the union of their choice and the right to work under an award or not to work under an award. I put it to the House that those things constitute freedom and are, in themselves, the mark of a mature, sophisticated, independent Australia. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis Mr A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two things at the kernel of the debate on the MPI today: firstly, the independence of the Industrial Relations Commission; and, secondly, the future direction of industrial relations in this country. Let me first dispense with the question of the Commission's independence and the attack which the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) has launched today on that point.

PARA.TAB: Let us go to the composition of the IRC: there are 15 presidential members—five of them are from the union movement, precisely a third. That is roughly in keeping with the sort of distribution one would find in any industrial tribunal in State or Commonwealth jurisdictions. If we look at the commissioners, other than the presidential members, of which there are 30, we see that the number is larger. There are 13 union representatives amongst the commissioners, but there are 12 employer representatives; in other words, roughly even Steven. The reason for that has to do with the different nature and role of presidential members as distinct from commissioners in the IRC. It is a nonsense to peddle the sort of tripe which the Opposition has in recent days over this matter on the composition of the IRC.

It appears that one of the things that was at the hub of this problem over the independence of the Commission was what happened to the pay of the industrial commissioners and the presidential members. The Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) has already dealt with that matter. I would have thought that the honourable member for Bennelong would have had it clearly in mind, given the role which he has played in this place in debates affecting the remuneration of members of this House and senators where we have overturned decisions of the Remuneration Tribunal. He has played a key role in those decisions, overturning the Remuneration Tribunal's determination, with the support of both sides of the House, reducing the remuneration that would otherwise have been made available to members and senators.

It is not an improper thing for the Parliament to enter that arena; indeed, the Constitution quite expressly provides that power to this place. Section 72(iii) makes clear the Parliament's authority to determine the remuneration of judges. It is absurd for anybody to suggest that it is not proper for this Parliament to determine the remuneration for members of the Industrial Relations Commission or other similar tribunals. To come into this place and suggest that, because the Parliament exercises that constitutional power it somehow limits the independence of the IRC, is patent nonsense.

Let us look at where the real threat to that independence comes from. The honourable member for Bennelong raised this matter of public importance today. A couple of days ago he put out a press release, which states:
The Liberal and National parties will not guarantee the security of tenure of future appointments by the Keating Government to the Industrial Relations Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: If that is not an attack on the independence of the Industrial Relations Commission, what is? The honourable member has come out and baldly said in advance, `Don't worry about the independence of the Commission. We are going to look at anyone who gets appointed from today on and we might turf him out'. That is the position the honourable member for Bennelong has adopted in public; he is on the record as having said it. Now he turns around and says that because the Parliament exercises its constitutional authority concerning remuneration that the independence of the IRC is threatened. What patent nonsense.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition has adopted this approach not just with the IRC. Some members might recall that, a few months ago when the Fightback package was released and various analyses were being done, in a doorstop interview the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), was questioned about the role of some of the Treasury officials in analysing that package and the role of Tony Cole, the head of Treasury, was raised. On 26 November last year, in answer to one of the journalist's questions during the doorstop interview, the shadow Treasurer said:

SPEECH.PARA: Well, Mr Cole and other senior members of the public bureaucracy ought to take very careful note of what I say. Thanks very much.

There is not much doubt what he was talking about. If that is not an implied threat to the independence of the bureaucracy, the public sector, what is? Yet the honourable member for Bennelong has the gall and the hypocrisy to come in here and raise a matter of public importance built around a letter and a bit of media hype. It really is a sad case of selective morality on the part of the honourable member for Bennelong and those who are supporting the MPI.

PARA.TAB: The Government's decision in these matters is totally justified and appropriate. Of course, the real agenda is what future direction industrial relations in our country will take. The honourable member for Bennelong and the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) have made their view very clear. They intend to eliminate not just the right of workers to have industrial trade unions—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, give them a choice.

—The honourable member wants to have enterprise unions. He has opposed the existence of industrial unions. In addition, the honourable member has said that the workers of this country should not of right have recourse to an industrial commission; they should not of right have the opportunity to have their grievances arbitrated by an independent third person—an umpire—to determine the rights and justice of the case. The honourable member has said that the only time they can do that is if the employer agrees. Imagine the absurdity of that. A work force in a particular plant in dispute with the employer could say, `Listen, we want to get this matter arbitrated; we want to go off to the Commission'. The honourable member is saying to them, this is his freedom, `You have no freedom to go to the umpire unless the employer agrees. This is his freedom'. How absurd is that in the real world? It is a nonsense; it is a camouflage.

PARA.TAB: The freedom the Opposition speaks of in its policy is the opportunity for individuals—without the opportunity to have union negotiators present, without the opportunity to have union representation in the Commission, without the opportunity to go to an independent umpire—without all of those things, to sit down with their boss and somehow try to negotiate an increase or improvement in their conditions of employment. Those opposite call that freedom, when they know as well as everybody in this place that the net result in 99 per cent of cases will be a reduction in the conditions of employment. They have quite openly declared that that is their intention. They have made it clear that the only thing that will be guaranteed is a minimum wage. I hope it is not the New Zealand brand of minimum wage which, it is worth noting for the benefit of people in Australia, stands at approximately $245 per week. That is the adult wage; and that is the only thing they are entitled to in New Zealand. They get that but they do not get any other entitlement.

TALK.START.PARA: —You didn't listen to me.
—They get sick leave and they get annual leave.
—That's generous.

—That is right. Those opposite expect the workers to turn around, having lost their rights to maternity leave, having lost long service leave, having lost their annual holiday loading, having lost a 38-hour week—the Opposition is on the record as saying there should be a 40-hour week immediately; in fact, the honourable member wants it retrospectively if he has the chance—having lost all those things, and negotiate with their employer on a one-to-one basis. And they call that equitable negotiation!

PARA.TAB: But to ice the cake, those opposite do not even require that there be genuine bargaining. At least the American system, which is somewhat modelled on this free bargaining approach, places a legal obligation on the boss to negotiate meaningfully. He cannot just turn around and say, `Here is the offer, take it or leave it; if you don't like it you are sacked; and there is someone outside waiting to take your job'. Those opposite do not even impose that rigour on the employers of Australia. And they call that a free and fair system! It is absolute nonsense; it is hypocrisy. They camouflage it by talking of freedom and calling it a voluntary employment agreement. If ever there was a misnomer, it is that: voluntary employment agreement. There is not much that is voluntary about it.

If we talk to most of the people who suffered under VEAs in Queensland when Bjelke-Petersen had the opportunity to introduce them, with very few exceptions there was nothing voluntary about them. It was put to workers, `Here are the conditions; take it or you are on the street without a job'. That was the voluntary nature of it. That was the fact of industrial relations when Bjelke-Petersen was Premier in Queensland. And there are only a couple of exceptions to that. I do acknowledge that there are some.

That is the sort of industrial relations policy which the honourable member supports. Let there be no doubt that that is exactly what he supports, because in June of last year in a wonderful article in the Current Affairs Bulletin there is an article about John Howard—and a beautiful picture—which tells us about the Opposition's policy in detail. I do not have time to go through it, but it is very clear. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Introduction of VEAs has been the fundamental plank of the Federal Opposition's industrial relations platform since 1986.

The fundamental plank! The honourable member is on about not just reducing the independence of the tribunal, of the umpire; he is on about eliminating the umpire from the process altogether. He does not want there to be a third party in the process, he does not want the workers of this country to have the opportunity to go to an umpire and have their grievances arbitrated and a third group to sort them out. Finally, I draw to the attention of the honourable member for Bennelong and those opposite who are wedded to these things a couple of very plain facts when we look across the ocean at other countries. Japan has—(Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—I call the Clerk.
Mr Fife—Mr Deputy Speaker—

TALK.START.PARA: —I have called the Clerk. Perhaps you would have the courtesy to tell me what it is you want to raise. For the next item on the blue business sheet, I call the Clerk.
—No. The Manager of Opposition Business well knows that I always extend courtesy to the Opposition, but I need to know beforehand. I have called the Clerk.

PARA.TAB: Mr Fife—Mr Deputy Speaker, I exercised the courtesy by going to you and saying that the Leader—

TALK.START.PARA: —Thirty seconds ago.

PARA.TAB: Mr Fife—Yes, but before the Clerk was called. I said that the Leader of the Opposition was seeking the call, and you said you would call the Clerk. I said, `Well, that will bring on new business'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, and it will bring on new business according to the blue sheet.

PARA.TAB: Mr Fife—And I said that the Leader of the Opposition needs the call before new business is brought on.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Chair has determined that the Clerk has been called. I call the Clerk.

PARA.TAB: Mr Fife—Mr Deputy Speaker, I do not know how—
Mr Tim Fischer—This is getting absolutely out of hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Resume your seat. The Manager of Opposition Business has the call.

PARA.TAB: Mr Fife—I just say to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that you are unfair and that you are not treating the Parliament with respect.

TALK.START.PARA: —No—

PARA.TAB: Mr Tim Fischer—A point of order, Mr Speaker.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will hear the Leader of the National Party.

PARA.TAB: Mr Tim Fischer—Mr Speaker, in support of the honourable member for Hume: he has now signified to the House that he did alert you before you called the Clerk. That makes it a double crime in passing over the Leader of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the National Party will withdraw that.

PARA.TAB: Mr Tim Fischer—I withdraw the word `crime'. That makes it a double breach of convention in jumping over the Leader of the Opposition who has a perfect right to seek the call with or without notice to the Speaker. But you were given notice. You have admitted to the House you were given notice, and you have still gone the wrong way. I submit that in fairness, and appealing to your fair side as a Deputy Speaker and Chairman of Committees, in all the circumstances arising, and given that the honourable member for Hume did give you notice and you indicated that to the House, you review that decision and give the call to the Leader of the Opposition in accordance with correct parlance and operations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have heard the Leader of the National Party. The Manager of Opposition Business approached me momentarily before I was about to call the Clerk and said, `Would you give the Leader of the Opposition the call?'. I said, `No, I will call the Clerk, according to the business paper. I will call the Clerk'. So I have called the Clerk. We will proceed.

TAB.EMPHASIS: The order of the day having been called on—

PARA.TAB: Mr Sinclair—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the Parliamentary Secretary, I will hear a point of order from the right honourable member for New England.

PARA.TAB: Mr Sinclair—Mr Speaker, I point out to you that as far as our proceedings are concerned there is no precedent given them if a member is on his feet. If you have noticed or if you have been given notice that a member is on his feet, then that takes precedence over anything that is on the Notice Paper. There is absolutely no priority given to the Notice Paper. The blue sheet in particular is there for the indication of members only. I would put to you that you are quite outside the powers exercisable by you in denying the call to a member on his feet, of whose rising you had notice. I would suggest to you that in normal circumstances it would be a matter that could lead to a motion of dissent from your ruling, and I do not think that is an issue that you would seek.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the right honourable member for New England. The right honourable member should know that the Chair had not recognised the Leader of the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: Mr Sinclair—You have to. You have to in the circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Chair had called the Clerk and we will proceed. I call the Parliamentary Secretary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Deputy Speaker's ruling be dissented from.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, you and the Speaker have made a total mockery of fair practice in this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Chair requires the Leader of the Opposition to submit the motion of dissent in writing.

—I just sign it and submit it. As I was saying, Mr Deputy Speaker, the Speaker and you are reducing this Parliament to a total mockery. It is blatantly unfair that the procedures of the House are generally disregarded to our disadvantage in the rulings that you and the Speaker give from time to time in debate in this House. This is a classic case which has obviously been prompted by the fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) today scurried out of this Parliament, completely flummoxed by the fact that he could not answer the question.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. This is not a motion to censure you. It is a technical discussion of whether or not your ruling is correct. The Leader of the Opposition is broadening the debate by taking it outside that technical discussion of whether you have acted within Standing Orders, and he is not entitled to do it.

—I will hear the Leader of the Opposition. I am sure that he is aware that the debate is to be confined to the question of the decision that the Chair has made and not other matters before the House. I am sure that he is aware of that.

—The fact is a very simple one. The fact is that the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Fife) had informed you that I would be seeking the call. He did what you asked and what you subsequently said that he should have done. He simply went to you and said that I would be seeking the call. It certainly has standing when Mr Deputy Speaker himself said that, if that had been pursued, he would have adhered to that ruling. The blue business sheet has no standing. There is no priority here in the calling of the Clerk, particularly when we wanted to move before this Parliament at this time what is obviously going to be a major motion about the behaviour of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and one of his Ministers. The very important motion that was to be put before this Parliament concerns the fact that the Prime Minister was unable to answer a question in Parliament today. He got completely flummoxed, panicked and ran out of here like Groucho Marx instead of staying and completing the processes of Question Time.

PARA.TAB: Mr Deputy Speaker, you were obviously aware that we were going to come back into the Parliament and demand that the Prime Minister return to this place to give a full account of the circumstances of that question and the issue at hand—the behaviour of one of his senior Cabinet Ministers and a matter of great impropriety. The procedures in the House are being abused by your ruling so as to prevent that debate. You are trying to call on the business of the Parliament so that we cannot proceed with the debate.

So it is for that reason that I am moving dissent. It is indicative of what has become a trend in this place, to the total destruction virtually of the significance of this institution in the eyes of the Australian people. That is a very serious event. As recently as the occasion on which I censured the Speaker at the end of the last days of sitting of this Parliament, I drew attention to the fact that Question Time, in particular, had become a mockery, with the number of questions having been dramatically reduced—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition is now moving beyond the specific matter before the Chair.
—The specific matter is absolutely clear cut—you sought notice from us—
—Which is not required, formally.

—It is not required. But you were given notice from us by the Manager of Opposition Business that I intended to move a motion. You disregarded that and proceeded to call the Clerk. It is for that reason that I am moving dissent.
—Is the motion seconded?

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. In so doing, I want to point out the chronological sequence of the events which occurred here this afternoon, because they go to the core of parliamentary democracy. Not only are there the formal requirements of the House as expressed in the Standing Orders; there are also many conventions and courtesies which exist in real terms, which are all about giving people on both sides of the House a fair go. Mr Deputy Speaker, they relate specifically to your ruling this afternoon in calling on the Clerk at an inappropriate time, given all the circumstances.

PARA.TAB: That is why I made my point of order in support of the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife) and the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). Perhaps on reflection, Mr Deputy Speaker, you could have avoided this dissent motion by simply giving the call. You deliberately looked down at the time, which made it even worse. You looked down and called the Clerk in the knowledge clearly that you knew that the Leader of the Opposition was jumping up at that time. That is the order of batting. Honourable members need to understand exactly what happened; members of the public need to understand exactly what happened.

The Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Fife) in the House came in and approached your chair in the time available—and it was a short time. He did not have to do that. But he did approach the chair and said to you that the Leader of the Opposition would be seeking a call—and he need not have said any more than that. He advised you, as a matter of absolute courtesy only, that the Leader of the Opposition would be seeking the call. I think I understand, from what the honourable member for Hume says, that he went on further to say that the Leader of the Opposition would be seeking to move a motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said `seeking the call'.

—Let us keep it at that. That is exactly an extra courtesy which was being afforded by simply signifying that before the House. So you, Mr Deputy Speaker, were informed by a person whose advice you have every reason to respect. He has a particular function on the floor of the House which is denoted by the title of Manager of Opposition Business. You received that information.

PARA.TAB: At that time, or shortly thereafter, the fourth speaker on a very important matter of public importance moved by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and seconded by the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson) came to the conclusion of his remarks. At that stage, as I said, you looked down and called the Clerk in the knowledge that the Leader of the Opposition would be seeking the call. What we have is a double breach of convention, a double breach of procedure. It is one which I personally find very upsetting. The Opposition was of the view that you might make a much better Speaker than the current Speaker. But I know that I am not allowed to dwell on that path other than to say that this matter was put to you in a very fair way.

Worse still, you then affirmed that chronology of events. After the honourable member for Hume and I took points of order you advised the House formally that you had been given notice prior to your calling the Clerk that the Leader of the Opposition would be seeking the call. I repeat that: you affirmed to the House, as Deputy Speaker of the House in charge of business at the time in the House, that the Leader of the Opposition would be seeking the call. A further, albeit short, period of time then elapsed before you in fact called the Clerk. Before you did that, the Leader of the Opposition was on his feet. Other members present will verify my eyesight from a couple of metres—it may not be the best eyesight—that the Leader of the Opposition was on his feet; he had given notice; and he was properly and legitimately seeking the call to raise an important matter.

I say to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that you have failed in terms of this specific matter—the subject of this specific, very serious dissent motion. I think it is a good period of time since we have had a dissent motion in the House to a specific ruling. It is one that is not moved lightly. But you have gone too far. We gave you the chance to come back in the interests of the proceedings of this Parliament being kept on an even keel, in the interests of a fair go, and in the interests of merely some 45 minutes or whatever the other item on the blue business sheet might have taken. The item on the blue business sheet, of course, has a limited status before the House.

I have to put in a second point, which I think is even more serious. We are talking about the Leader of the Opposition, not just a member of the House, seeking the call. Whilst all 148 of us would like to think in a sense that we are equals—we are certainly all members of this House of Representatives—there are procedures and longstanding conventions which say that, when the Leader of the Opposition seeks the call, he is given a measure of priority; he is given a measure of courtesy. That is laid down in various practices of the Parliament and, to a lesser extent, admittedly, in the Standing Orders.

So on two counts, Mr Deputy Speaker, you have failed in that the ruling you gave was incorrect and is deserving of the dissent of the House. I appeal to the two Independents, who are not in the chamber at this time. This goes to the core of all that they would have us believe about their service in this House, championing the rights of parliamentary democracy and the rights of people to get a fair hearing. I ask them to come down into the House, listen to this debate and vote accordingly when we get to the voting stage.

You, sir, have breached the courtesy extended to you; you really have. You confirmed to the House that the honourable member for Hume gave you notice with regard to the Leader of the Opposition jumping and, secondly, you have breached the convention associated with the proceedings of the Parliament in failing to give the call to the Leader of the Opposition.

The third point I would make is a critical one. I have great respect for the Clerks at the table, and I do not involve them in the debate. To do so would be totally out of order. But I point out that the Clerks of the House are just that: they are the Clerks of the House. They do an enormous amount of work behind the scenes. They give good advice to both sides of the House. They have a proper and functioning role to continue in their work. But they do not take precedence over the Leader of the Opposition. They do not take precedence, for that matter, over the retiring honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr John Scott). They do not even take precedence over the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil). Well might I choose those two members, because they have both had enough and they are jumping ship. They have announced that they are retiring from the Parliament, along with the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand).

I come back to the specific point that the Clerks have their ordained role. There is one fragile moment in the proceedings of the Parliament when in fact the Clerk has an even more elevated role, and that is during the election of the Speaker of the House at the start of each parliamentary term. But equally, I say to members of the House, and members of the gallery who witnessed this chronology of events, that the Clerks are just that—the Clerks of the House. They do not take precedence over the Leader of the Opposition.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I appeal to your sense of fair play and I appeal to the sense of fair play of members on both sides of the House and the Independents. On this occasion there is cause for us to give you the benefit of the time that has elapsed since you made this ruling. If you signify that you are prepared to reverse that ruling in the light of the information which has been presented, we equally would be prepared to withdraw the motion that is before the Chair. Events do happen quite quickly, and human error can occur. It is a genuine appeal, and the whole proceedings of the Parliament would be greatly helped if you took that course of action. I am an optimist; but let me say in black and white terms why, in the absence of that, every member in the House should, on this occasion, vote for this motion.

Firstly, the courtesies were observed. You, as Deputy Speaker, were advised that the Leader of the Opposition would be seeking the call, and you have confirmed that on the floor of the House. It has been exposed. You have been caught red-handed. On the first count, all courtesies have been observed. Secondly, the absolute convention has been observed inasmuch as the Leader of the Opposition jumped, and jumped ahead of you as Deputy Speaker calling on the Clerk. That was clear cut and was observed by a number of people in this House. The Leader of the Opposition said, `Mr Deputy Speaker'. I concede that a short space of time was involved there. The third point I make is that no Clerk has precedence over any member of the House, and particularly over the Leader of the Opposition.

I ask that you recognise the particular priority of the Leader of the Opposition, who sought to move that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) provide a full explanation to the House as to why he has failed to discipline the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Richardson) for a clear breach of his responsibilities to disclose his interests and to declare a relevant interest in matters decided by Cabinet. That is a truly relevant matter, given all the proceedings on the floor of the House this day.

So, Mr Deputy Speaker, I once again appeal to your good nature and to your past track record—perhaps not always perfect, nevertheless a track record on which we were prepared to give you the benefit of the doubt—to recommit this matter. It is within your jurisdiction and your capability, with the indulgence of the House, to recommit this matter in a way that would allow the Leader of the Opposition to proceed with his quite proper motion in all the circumstances.

In the absence of that, for all the reasons that I have advanced I commend to all members of the House the motion constructively and carefully moved that this ruling be dissented from, because you have made a monumental error. You have confessed that error in as many words. You have much to answer for, and this ruling should be reversed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the Leader of the House, the Leader of the National Party did invite the Chair to respond to a matter. It was the Chair's intention to call the Clerk and proceed with the first item of business—Notice No. 2—after which, the Chair, having ascertained from the Manager of Opposition Business what was intended, could easily have called the Leader of the Opposition and saved us all this difficulty.
—Mr Deputy Speaker—

—The honourable member for Hume will resume his seat. The Leader of the National Party has asked me to clarify a matter. I am clarifying it. That was the intention of the Chair. However—and I will say this to the Manager of Opposition Business—you were so determined to have your way that you would not let the Chair clarify the matter beforehand.

—On a point of order, I submit to you that there is no obligation on any member to advise you of what is going to be said when a member is called. As a matter of courtesy I indicated to you that the Leader of the Opposition would be seeking the call.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Tuckey

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker, I draw your attention to the Standing Orders in relation to this matter. I draw your attention firstly to standing order 59, above which is the heading `Manner and right of speech'. There is a series of Standing Orders going down from 59. Standing order 59 says:

PARA.TAB: Every Member desiring to speak shall rise and address himself to the Speaker.

INTERJECT.PARA: I put it to you on a point of order that that in itself does not say, `any member or any Clerk'; it says, `every member'. It clearly designates the right of a member to attract your attention and consequently to be called upon to speak.

PARA.TAB: I put it to you further that, because this standing order makes no provision in respect of the Clerk, the process of calling the Clerk is to call on Government Business, and that can only be done if a member does not desire the right to speak. The only way the Government can prevent that member from speaking is to move that Government Business be called on. That process was not followed. Consequently, the only person—
Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —My point of order has to be heard out. The only person who stood at that point in time as a member of this House was the Leader of the Opposition, and he was therefore entitled to the call, and that is the end of the subject.
—The Leader of the House.
—You cannot take a point of order.
—Of course I can. My point of order is this: the honourable member is debating an issue on a point of order—
—I raise a point of order.
—The honourable member for Pearce will resume his seat.
—Why should I?

—Because no point of order has yet been made out by the Leader of the House, so we do not know what it is you are taking a point of order on. Just resume your seat, and we will hear the point of order raised by the Leader of the House.
—The point of order is that the honourable member for O'Connor is debating the issue. He is not in fact raising a point of order. That is the issue before the Chair.
—I consider that the honourable member for O'Connor still had some point to make, so I call him.

—I can conclude on my point of order by saying that, as there was only one member standing, it was your obligation to call that member, irrespective of the Government's desire to carry on with its business.

PARA.TAB: As the honourable member was on his feet, considering those particular Standing Orders, he had to be called. In fact, the only way the Government could prevent it was not by your, Mr Deputy Speaker, doing something, but by the Government taking a specific action of moving that Government Business be called on. It did not do that, so it was your obligation to call the only honourable member standing, the Leader of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Chair has heard the point of order of the honourable member for O'Connor. The point very simply is that the Chair has the discretion to call business as the Chair chooses. The Chair had called on business. From there it is a question of who rises, but the Chair had called on a matter of business. However, I have to be careful not to enter the debate, and I am conscious of that.
—I oppose the motion, and I do not particularly consider the last speaker to this motion as necessarily a reliable witness. He was up here in this place—
—Will you sit down. I am on a point of order.
—I am not talking about you—goose.
—Order! The Leader of the House should resume his seat. The honourable member for O'Connor has a point of order.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, if I was not the last speaker, you were. He has called someone a non-reliable witness. If he is referring to me, he should withdraw that. It is an outrageous statement—and he should sit down while I am talking. Will you ask the Minister to resume his seat?
—The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat. The Leader of the House will withdraw.

—The honourable member, who was the last speaker, asked for a withdrawal of the statement that he was an unreliable witness. I am happy to withdraw it, but that must be just about the most sensitive performance of anybody in the debate in this place who considers himself a robust performer. So I cheerfully withdraw to the shrinking violet. The fact of the matter is that the honourable member came into this place and spent a considerable amount of time disrupting the end of Question Time, which he referred to in terms of the chronology of the presentation of his argument, on the grounds that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) had not asked that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper. A review of the tapes reveals that quite clearly the Prime Minister had asked, some 10 minutes after Question Time would normally conclude, that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member, in the course of his presentation here, asked us to pass some judgment on his sight and hearing. We can pass judgment on his sight and hearing on the basis of that evidence.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order. Mr Deputy Speaker, you were pretty severe on the Leader of the Opposition when he was speaking to this motion and you drew him back to the point of the question before the House before he got anywhere near as far away from the question as has the Leader of the House, so why do you not do the same thing for him?
—I am sure the Leader of the House is aware of the constraints of the matter before the House.

—I am. I am responding specifically to a point raised in debate, as those opposite well know. Once something is placed on the table in debate, which attention is not called to on those grounds by the Speaker, an honourable member may obviously respond to it in the course of his own reply. I am glad to see that the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) is cackling away, to acknowledge himself the ridiculousness of the point he made. The point that is at debate here is this: what is an appropriate order as far as the Speaker is concerned? The fact is that the House is totally within the control of the Speaker. The Speaker can choose to recognise whoever he cares to recognise. Speakers have had that right for hundreds of years and, in the case of this Parliament, for about 90 years. If the Speaker chooses not to recognise somebody on his feet but calls the Clerk to bring on business, that is too bad for the person concerned. That is all there is to it. Those opposite can go and argue all the points they like to on that—
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo!

—But that happens to be the fact of the matter. There is no getting away from it in this particular instance. The fact that a couple of you chose to rock up to the Speaker's chair and say that you were going to do something is neither here nor there. As you rightly pointed out in your own debating points in the course of your remarks, that sort of approach has absolutely no standing at all. You happen to think that it makes you particularly courteous; well, I am very cheered to hear that.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. In view of your remarks before this motion was moved, where you said that you placed some reliance on being advised beforehand when someone gets up to make a point of order, and having regard to what the Leader of the House has just said, he has made a gross reflection on you in the chair. I ask that it be withdrawn.
—No. I call the Leader of the House.

—As every member of this House well understands, that proposition has absolutely no standing in this place at all. The Clerk is called; that brings on the business of the day—and that is it. There will be other opportunities in accordance with the Standing Orders for an honourable member, if it is possible for that member to get the recognition from the Chair, to get up and to make a presentation at whatever particular time those particular breaks in the program occur.

PARA.TAB: We have absolutely no problems dealing with the particular issue that the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) happens to raise, but we do have a problem with the persistent record that is being developed by this Opposition in harassing Speakers. The Leader of the Opposition decided in his remarks to draw attention—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, you did not on that one. You went on at some considerable length on that subject in your criticism of the Speaker and directing your abuse at this particular Deputy Speaker. Having introduced that record into the debate and not being required to close down your remarks on that, and, given also that your successor in the debate also drew attention to that and was not called upon to withdraw his remarks or cease his remarks in that regard, I am responding to what were regarded as orderly remarks as far as you were concerned when you were participating in this debate. You sought to detail what you considered to be an unsatisfactory record of Speakers in this place. The unsatisfactory record goes to your disruption, as far as this place is concerned, which has been persistent. This particular dissent motion is of a piece with it.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition has said in this chamber that as far as it is concerned it is a very unusual thing to move a motion of dissent from the Chair's ruling, to move censures of Speakers and of Deputy Speakers: I am afraid it was once but it is no longer. This happens to be our daily fare as far as the operations of this Parliament are concerned. This is of a piece with that type of contemptible behaviour. In order that we can get on with the other business before this House, the business that we must deal with, I move:
That the question be now put.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—The result of the division is ayes 68, noes 68. I cast my vote for the noes; the Chair therefore rules that the debate may continue.
Questions resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I want to add a few words to this debate because I think it needs to be understood that the dissent from your ruling revolves around a ruling made by one of your predecessors, Speaker Jenkins. It is important that the House understand that prior to Speaker Jenkins making that ruling it was possible for a motion to suspend Standing Orders to be moved at any time. Speaker Jenkins, on the other hand, decided that it would not be practical or desirable for Standing Orders to be suspended at any time. He determined that it should occur only in intervals between business, other than on matters pertaining to the business before the House.

PARA.TAB: My concern about your ruling, Mr Deputy Speaker, is that you have put at risk that determination made by Speaker Jenkins. If it should be that you want to change that interpretation—and that, of course, is up to Mr Speaker's discretion—it might well be that the ruling you made was correct. But you have not indicated to this House that that is so. Let every member understand that the right to suspend Standing Orders is one that is exercisable by a member rising in his place only in an interval between business. The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) rose in his place. It was not necessary but as a matter of courtesy the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Fife) had given you notice. In this particular instance the Leader of the Opposition—notice having been given, albeit briefly—rose and, under Speaker Jenkins's ruling, it was imperative that the Leader of the Opposition be called or it would have been impossible for the proceedings of the House to proceed. That is the case under the interpretation that Speaker Jenkins gave to our Standing Orders for the practices required for a suspension of Standing Orders to take place.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I put very strongly to you that it was obligatory for you to have called the Leader of the Opposition in a climate where the only procedure and practice available for a member of this House if he wishes to move a suspension of Standing Orders is for him to do so in an interval between business. That interval was there. You had not called the Clerk. With the Leader of the Opposition standing in his place it was obligatory for you to call him. If it should be as a result of this particular proceeding that the motion is lost, the result is going to be that you or Mr Speaker will have to make another interpretation on Speaker Jenkins's ruling, because it is a sacred right of this place that members have the opportunity to suspend Standing Orders.

Of course there is an equal right of members of the House to negate that suspension. But we are not talking about the negative of the motion; we are talking about the opportunity to speak. Mr Deputy Speaker, you are the temporary custodian of the rights and privileges of every member of this House, and, as that custodian, you and you alone have the obligation to call any member, as a ruling of your predecessor says that it is the only opportunity for him to exercise that right. If you do not pursue that ruling, you are letting down the rights of every member of this chamber; you are denying members the opportunity to exercise the privilege that your predecessor said was theirs.

So you have a choice: either you accept that your ruling was wrong and you call the Leader of the Opposition or, if the view that you have asserted is correct, you must then change the interpretation of the Standing Orders that your predecessor has imposed. You cannot have it both ways. There has to be an opportunity for the suspension of Standing Orders. It is one of the sacred rights. It is written into Erskine May and it has been adopted in Pettifer's House of Representatives Practice, updated in its various forms. Whilst it is up to the Speaker to interpret how it may be exercised, it is up to the House finally to determine whether and in what way there might be an acceptance of that suspension of Standing Orders.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I put it to you that, if you deny the Leader of the Opposition the call, you are going against the text and the intent of the ruling of Mr Speaker Jenkins in this place. That is not acceptable, because no member in this place can accept that you can impose your will in such a way as to deny a member on his feet, particularly the Leader of the Opposition, the right and the opportunity to be called. In that climate, Mr Deputy Speaker, I believe there is an obligation upon you to allow the Leader of the Opposition to speak and to permit him to move that suspension of Standing Orders. If you do not do so, I call on you to revise that interpretation of Mr Speaker Jenkins and to allow the Leader of the Opposition or any other member of this House to rise at any time to suspend Standing Orders so that that member can intrude on whatever business that particular suspension of Standing Orders might entail.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I put it to you quite seriously that it is an alternative which you are now called upon to exercise. I put it to you that the result of the division, the equality of the voting, shows that there is considerable concern in this House and that you now have a greater obligation to give the Leader of the Opposition the call than would otherwise be the case.

These are important issues. They are not matters, Mr Deputy Speaker, that you can just defer or matters on which you might think that some privilege or practice that you might like to impose can perhaps intrude. There is nothing more serious than the matter that the Leader of the Opposition wishes to raise—that is, the suspicion that a member has not complied with another standing order, that is, the disclosure of a personal as distinct from a public interest. If the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Richardson) failed to make those disclosures, he is transgressing in a way that is quite critical—

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—Order! The honourable member for Bruce will remain silent.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is clearly now well away from the matters that are the substance of the issues that we are debating here. This is no longer a debate on the dissent; this has now become a debate specifically on the substance of what it was that the Leader of the Opposition was attempting to move.
—The right honourable member for New England has the call. He is straying a bit from the question, but I took it that he was summarising his position.

—The reason I raised it is that it goes back to the interpretation of the Standing Orders of this House. It goes back to a matter of a suggested breach of the Standing Orders, which enshrine in both Houses an obligation that if a member has a personal interest, as distinct from any other member of the community, he has an obligation to disclose. We have several standing orders which are really written into the Bible of this place, and that was what I understood the Leader of the Opposition sought to address by suspending Standing Orders. I put it to you that the ruling you made in preventing him from raising that matter is even more serious because of the nature and character of that breach. I seriously say to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that unless you accept the right of the Leader of the Opposition to speak, we are all in a very difficult position.

PARA.TAB: Like the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer), I appeal to my two colleagues who are Independents to consider seriously the matters now before the chamber. They are matters that pertain to their rights as much as to those of anybody else. Should they wish to raise matters by way of motion now that there are two of them, I suggest to them that the decision now being taken by the Chair is one which affects their rights perhaps more than those of anybody else in this place. I suggest to them that it is very much in their interests. Presumably, if they meant those things that have been said, they are also matters which they would want to support in any event.

Mr Deputy Speaker, it is important that you understand why this motion of dissent from your ruling has been moved. It is because you are denying individuals a right which is there through our Standing Orders, and I trust that you recognise the consequence if that ruling is not changed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not hold the House for long. I suggest that this motion arises from a practice which has grown up in recent times in this House of denying the Standing Orders and of manipulating them for the purposes of providing the media with their 6 o'clock news bulletins. The right to the call has never been an absolute right in this House, and it is not an absolute right. It is certain that the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has privileges in the House which were largely developed during the time of Mr Speaker Snedden, I might say.

PARA.TAB: I might also say that it was not an unusual practice when the Opposition was in government and when the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), who has just spoken, was the Leader of the House for members to be denied the call when they were seeking it for the purposes of procedural or other motions. It is the choice of the Chair to determine the business of the House and to determine the manner in which it is conducted. There is some responsibility on the Chair to ensure that the House's business is conducted.

I do not think that this is a serious motion. I believe that opportunities for the Leader of the Opposition to move such a motion do occur and are ample to provide him with the flexibility within his rights as a member. I doubt whether there have been more suspensions of Standing Orders in a short space of time than there have been during the period that the present Leader of the Opposition has been Leader of the Opposition. They are part of his normal debating procedure.

This is not a special occasion, as the right honourable member for New England would have us believe; it is part of the daily process of the Opposition in this Parliament, and it is planned and conducted in that way. Mr Deputy Speaker, I believe you are entitled to the confidence of the House and I am certain that you will obtain it.
Question put:
That the motion (Dr Hewson's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Public Works Committee: CSIRO Redevelopment, North Ryde, New South Wales

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEDDALL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, there is such a big audience for a Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works matter.
—You must have something interesting to say.
—Very much so. The Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Free) will be pleased at any rate. On behalf of the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus), I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: CSIRO redevelopment, North Ryde, New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed work recommended by the Public Works Committee involves the redevelopment of a site at North Ryde, New South Wales, for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. A review of the North Ryde site was undertaken and a redevelopment strategy proposed.

PARA.TAB: The strategy involved the identification, staged development and release of certain lands for high technology business park purposes. The proceeds from the staged land release would be used to consolidate CSIRO's activities on the site and to upgrade and replace substandard facilities.
