The main elements of the proposed strategy are a rationalisation and consolidation of CSIRO's accommodation at North Ryde; the progressive release of approximately 15.8 hectares of identified surplus land in up to 11 indicative development lots to create a science and technology park; the retention of principal CSIRO buildings in good condition to form the nucleus of the redevelopment in the divisional precincts; the provision for all of CSIRO's anticipated accommodation needs for the foreseeable future in retained existing buildings, upgraded as necessary, and state of the art new buildings; provision of controlled access to the site to address urgent safety issues; an orderly, continuous redevelopment program anticipated to run for some nine years, but programmed to permit on-site research to proceed with little interruption; and the whole redevelopment to be self-funding.

The proposal was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works in September 1991. The Committee tabled its report on 31 March 1992, recommending the redevelopment at an outturn cost of $91.5m.

CSIRO has noted all of the Committee's recommendations and provides the following comments. Detailed plans for each aspect of the proposal will be provided prior to the commencement of construction and particular attention will be paid to energy efficiency. Discussions are continuing between CSIRO and the relevant State authorities about upgrading public transport facilities to the North Ryde site and, in respect of recommendations 7 to 11, which refer to the possible relocation of the food research laboratory to the Riverina region, the Director of the CSIRO Institute of Animal Production and Processing has commissioned a major review of directions for the CSIRO Division of Food Processing and related research areas in CSIRO.

The review committee will undertake visits to relevant laboratories and meet with interested parties in June, with its report being completed by the end of August. Its report will be considered by the CSIRO board shortly thereafter. The comments of the PWC about relocating the food research laboratory to the Riverina region have been noted by CSIRO and will be considered as an input to the divisional review process. I thank the Committee for its report and commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition parties have no problem with this motion. We would like to commend the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for the work it has done and we look forward to seeing the results of this development.

—The aspects of the motion which I wish to address concern recommendations 7 to 11 of the report of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works relating to the possible relocation of the food research laboratory and food processing division of the CSIRO from North Ryde to the Riverina region.

PARA.TAB: As was indicated when the Committee's report was presented to the House, I strongly support moving the food research and associated activities of the CSIRO to a rural area and preferably, as the Public Works Committee recommended, to the Riverina region of New South Wales. Accordingly, I am glad to see that, in light of the Committee's report and recommendations, the CSIRO has undertaken a major review of directions for the CSIRO division of food processing and related research areas.

I also welcome the statement by the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) that the CSIRO board will take into account the Public Works Committee's comments about relocating the food research laboratory to the Riverina when it is considering the final report arising from the current review. It is also entirely appropriate that as part of the review process the CSIRO representatives should meet with the interested parties.

But I reiterate that I still hold the view that, as the Public Works Committee recommended, the Minister should do everything within his power to ensure that the relocation of the food research laboratory to the Riverina region is approved. Having regard to the Government's responsibilities, I consider that it is perfectly reasonable for the Minister to convey a view to the CSIRO board that, provided there are no significant financial or operational disadvantages to the CSIRO, it should relocate its food research laboratory in an appropriate rural area. If the Government does not make such an assessment and advise the CSIRO of its view, it must accept that it will be seen to be negligent in the discharge of its responsibility to the taxpayers. The Government should insist that the CSIRO take a national view.

I have no doubt that the best long term benefits for the CSIRO would be achieved by relocating the food processing division in the Riverina—preferably in the Wagga Wagga area where the Charles Sturt University Riverina campus is located. Many people and organisations in Wagga Wagga, Griffith and other parts of the Riverina have devoted a great deal of time and effort to making representations and submissions in support of moving this division of the CSIRO into the region. I hope their expectations will be fulfilled, not just out of sectional interest, but in the best interests of the CSIRO and rural Australia as a whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say a few words about this statement by the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) and second the comments of the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife). The CSIRO has said that it will undertake an investigation into whether the research station should be shifted from Ryde. Along with the honourable member for Hume, I believe it should go to the Riverina, which is one of the major food baskets of Australia. On-line development can be done there and already a number of food processing operations are carried on in the Wagga Wagga, Griffith, Leeton and Narrandera areas. As the honourable member for Hume said, I think it is important not only for our region but also for Australia that the right decision be made.

PARA.TAB: Most of what I want to say has been covered, so I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate those people who have brought forward the possibility of this research centre being relocated in the Riverina—namely, the Riverina Development Board and, of course, the various shire and city councils in the area. I ask the Minister to take on board the words of the honourable member for Hume in requesting that this investigation be undertaken as a matter of urgency. Of course, the final decision lies with the Minister.

I would also like to take this opportunity to congratulate the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works—and I see that the Chairman, the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), is in the House at the moment—on its decision on this matter and for coming into our region and bringing the motion into play.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition moving forthwith—That the Prime Minister provide a full explanation to the House as to why he has failed to discipline the Minister for Transport and Communications for a clear breach of his responsibilities as a Minister to disclose his personal interests.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a matter of urgency that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) be brought back into this Parliament to give a full explanation of the activities of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Richardson) in relation to the performance of his duties as a Minister in light of evidence that has been released in the course of the last few days, mostly in the other place.

PARA.TAB: It seems, on the evidence to hand, that the Minister was the director of radio station 2HD in Newcastle—an interest which Ministers are required to declare and which he did not declare on his statement of members' interests. Therefore, this raises a host of questions as to the propriety of the Minister's behaviour, as on a number of occasions matters relating to radio stations were considered by Cabinet and by this Parliament.

By way of background, I refer to the question that I asked the Prime Minister in this Parliament today and the answer that he gave. This occurred shortly before, in response to the pressure arising from a second question and a potential third question, he ran out of this House—he did almost a Groucho Marx as he scurried out at a pace I have never seen before—rather than face the reality of further cross-examination on this matter. In those circumstances, I think it is absolutely essential that he be prepared to come back into this House and answer the questions that have been raised by the activities of the Minister for Transport and Communications.

I asked the Prime Minister today what disciplinary action he was going to take against the Minister for Transport and Communications for not disclosing his company directorship in radio station 2HD in the Parliamentary Register of Members' Interests. I asked whether there had been a breach of propriety, and why he had not stood down Senator Richardson because of that impropriety. In his answer, the Prime Minister said that a number of honourable members had inadvertently left information off things—`things' is one of the words he uses all the time; the `thing' in question was the statement of members' interests. He went on to say that the register had periodically written to them and they had corrected it. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Richardson wrote to me today saying that he apologised for failing to note his directorship of 2HD on his pecuniary interest form.
He said that Senator Richardson had gone on to say:

I want to emphasise that the omission on my part was not motivated by any attempt to conceal knowledge from yourself or the Parliament. My directorship was well known by Cabinet colleagues, the party generally and was a matter of public record.
I am not aware of any circumstance when a conflict of interest may have arisen.

The Prime Minister went on to say that he accepted both the apology and the assurance. Following that, he tabled the letters and the other correspondence referred to. I think that was a deliberate attempt to divert attention from the full extent of the breach that appears to have occurred in relation to the activities of the Minister for Transport and Communications.

PARA.TAB: The correspondence focuses on his time since he became the Minister for Transport and Communications on 14 January this year and neglects the period when he was a Cabinet Minister prior to 14 January this year. Indeed, we can go back to 19 January 1988 when that Minister became a Cabinet Minister. But I believe he was a Minister throughout the whole period of the Hawke-Keating governments. In that capacity, he has a clear responsibility to lay down a statement of his particular financial interests.
I remind the House of the purpose of the Parliamentary Register of Members' Interests. The document states:

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the. . . Statement of Registrable Interests form is to place on the public record Members' interests which may conflict, or may be seen to conflict, with their public duty.

The document says that members are required to record the details of registered directorships of companies by indicating the name and activity of the company. Although senators are not formally required to meet the requirements of that register, Ministers are. Under `Directorships', the explanatory notes say:

Ministers are reminded that they are required to resign directorships in public companies and may retain directorships in private companies only if any such company operates (e.g. a family farm, business or investments), and if retention of the directorship is not likely to conflict with the Ministers' public duty.

It is very clear that the purpose of the register is to avoid the possible conflict of interest between a Minister's private interests and his or her public duty as a Minister. That requirement exists for all Ministers.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Transport and Communications has been a Minister throughout the Hawke-Keating Government and a Cabinet Minister since 19 January 1988. He clearly has a responsibility under that register to declare all directorships. As we can see from the period in question—particularly from when he became a director of radio station 2HD on 21 September 1990—if we check his statement of registrable interests through that period after the appointment was made, he has not at any time declared that directorship.

As I understand the notes about the responsibilities of Ministers, they are required to resign directorships in companies. The Minister for Transport and Communications accepted one while he was a Cabinet Minister and failed to declare it. Subsequent to that date, there has been a number of major debates in the Parliament and in the Cabinet on matters that are of importance to a radio station.

In December 1990 Cabinet agreed to draft a new Broadcasting Services Bill—I think that was a Cabinet submission introduced by the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley)—which proposed major deregulation of the radio industry, including liberalisation of ownership to allow for more than one radio station in one city. In March 1991 there were new foreign ownership limits in relation to radio and television stations. In July 1991 a new regional radio plan was discussed by Cabinet which was designed to simplify the licensing of regional radio and to allow supplementary licences so that a radio station could take another licence in the same area. In August 1991 there was a Cabinet decision to halve the radio licence fees. In October 1991 there was the debate on the political ad ban in relation to the radio industry. In November 1991 there was the release of a new broadcasting Bill.

On the several major occasions identified there, there was a series of what obviously were Cabinet meetings in relation to the activities of radio stations, all of which carried a potential conflict of interest on the part of a Cabinet Minister. It is relevant that that conflict of interest relates to all Cabinet Ministers, not just to the particular Cabinet Minister who happens to have the portfolio of transport and communications.
Mr Beazley interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the House made the interjection that he never turned up. This is the man who has had a consuming passion, we are told, to take the particular portfolio he now holds. When the present Prime Minister had announced his new ministry, he was asked the following question by a journalist at his press conference on 27 December last year:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Keating, could you explain why Senator Richardson has gone to the Transport and Communications portfolio?
The answer was:
Well, it's an area firstly that he has always liked. It's an area which he had in the past asked for.

He goes on to talk about how Senator Richardson had had a reasonably longstanding interest in much of the subject area of transport and communications. When the Prime Minister is prepared to put that explanation on the record as to why he appointed Senator Richardson to that portfolio—and I have heard it said that the former Prime Minister had felt that he might still be Prime Minister if he had given Senator Richardson that portfolio—I would say that it does not sit well with the statement the Leader of the House just made that he never turned up.

PARA.TAB: I think there is one easy way to satisfy my curiosity in this respect and to answer fully what I believe is required as a result of the registration of members' interests. Why does the Government not tell us how many specific Cabinet meetings there were on these and other matters that related to radio stations? On what dates did these meetings occur? Did Senator Richardson attend these meetings? If not, where was he on all those occasions? (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter goes to the very heart of what good government is about in this country. It is not just a matter, as the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) tried to portray this afternoon, of a lapse of a period of six days in lodging a pecuniary interest form. It is much more than that.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Richardson) was appointed to the Ministry in July 1987 and to the Cabinet on 19 January 1988. The question that arises is: in the course of his being a Minister—that is, a Minister administering any portfolio—did he have commercial interests which, by a decision of the Government, would benefit him personally or his family? He is required, as the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) detailed, to set down quite clearly the level of interest that he has, or his family has, in the pecuniary interest form. I remind honourable members of what page 3 of the explanatory notes says:

SPEECH.PARA: Ministers are reminded that they are required to resign directorships in public companies and may retain directorships in private companies only if any such company operates (e.g. a family farm, business or investments—
Radio station 2HD is not a family farm or investment!

TALK.START.PARA: —It could be family.

—It could be family, because when we look at the detail from the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, we see that 60 per cent of 2HD is owned by the ALP branch in New South Wales. On 21 September 1990, Graham Richardson became a director of this company. It was not as if he had been a director for a long time and on becoming communications Minister he just forgot to resign. It is much more than that. He actually became a director in September 1990. Today the Australian Securities Commission advises that he is still a director. When this matter was first raised yesterday in the Senate and the detail was provided by the Minister, he wrote a letter of apology to the Prime Minister relating some detail about his resignation, his arrival back in Australia and the six-day delay. That is a smokescreen.

PARA.TAB: The central issue that I come back to is: did he vote as a Minister, or was he involved in decisions of the Government, at any time that would have benefited him and the directorship of 2HD, which he represented? The key issue that I want to focus on is what is known as the Licence Fees Amendment Bill, which the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley), who is at the table, will well know, because he introduced it into this House. That Bill was the result of the 1991 Budget. That Budget reduced licence fees on radio by $8m across the board.

Today I asked the Prime Minister: was there a benefit to radio station 2HD? Did Senator Richardson reveal his pecuniary interest in the matter during any Cabinet meetings or Budget discussions? This was a major and necessary concession to the radio industry, but it clearly benefited Senator Richardson and the company of which he was a director. Was he involved? That is the issue because, if he was involved, the benefits that flowed to 2HD flowed to him and flowed to the Labor Party, as owner of this station. That is the centre of the issue: there was $8m; how much flew across to 2HD? That is what we want to know.

We do not want a smokescreen about this narrow six-day period; we want this broader issue answered. Given the evidence that we see before us—and I think I was more than reasonable in my question today—Prime Minister, you answer this: what happened?

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely.
—Bent over backwards.

—Order! If the honourable member for Mitchell interjects out of his place, he might find himself in a lot of trouble. The honourable member for Bennelong will cease interjecting as well, or I will name him.

—What happened was that, for the first time in my period of nearly eight years in this place, we saw a Prime Minister vacate that seat and take off out of here very quickly. What this motion seeks to do is to bring the Prime Minister back in here to give us an explanation. We are reasonable people; we want the explanation.

PARA.TAB: Where is the explanation? The explanation should come from the Prime Minister. He is the one who receives from his Ministers details of their pecuniary interests. The procedure was not followed. There is prima facie a case to suggest that Senator Richardson and radio station 2HD directly benefited from an $8m reduction in licence fees; that goes without saying. We need as well to look at the other decisions in the broadcasting and communications area which Senator Richardson may have directly or indirectly benefited from by the Government's actions. We want to know whether he was present. For him to say he was not present is not enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Bass's time has expired, but I ask him to withdraw the suggestion that the Minister may have profited himself. He can only do that by substantive motion.
—I withdraw. The genre of my remarks is well understood, I am sure.
—I am grateful for this opportunity to set everybody's mind completely at rest not only on this matter—

PARA.TAB: Mr Ronaldson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If the honourable member for Ballarat continues to interject, I will name him.

—but also on some of the other points that were raised by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) in his speech. The first was the claim that somehow or other in Question Time I was filibustering and that that was under the instruction of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).
—Who said that?
—The Opposition.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.
—Where is he?
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—I will deal with that particular point because it goes to the question of whether or not the Prime Minister was attempting to have Question Time shut down. He was not. As the Opposition is well aware, we now proceed to about 12 or 14 questions each Question Time and we do not take a great deal of notice at all of that 45-minute period. In fact, if we had, this particular Question Time would have been shut off 10 minutes earlier. Indeed, the Prime Minister made it absolutely clear to me, in the intervening period after a point of order was put down on me on that particular subject, that he intended Question Time to continue.
—What has this got to do with the motion?
—Order! The honourable member for Bennelong!

—It has got everything to do with the points that he was making in his participation in this debate, for which he was not called to book. So I will answer them, thanks very much. The proposition that somehow or other the Prime Minister was particularly unwilling to field questions on this point is an absolute nonsense.

PARA.TAB: Mr Fife interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Hume will cease interjecting.

—The claim that I was actually filibustering on the point is also an absolute nonsense. I was making some excellent points in this place on a matter of some very considerable concern to members of the Opposition, as they have to get around the car industry and one or two other industries to explain how in fact their particular propositions in the transport area will not make a dime of difference to the costs that those industries are experiencing.
—Did you know he was a director?
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Mitchell.

—There is absolutely no foundation whatsoever to that particular claim. As far as the Prime Minister was concerned, as members of the Opposition had made idiots of themselves on that subject, he shut down Question Time in the appropriate way—again, contrary to the advice to this chamber of the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer).

PARA.TAB: What has to be said quite clearly about this particular issue is this: the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Richardson) has no pecuniary interest arising from his directorship of 2HD.

TALK.START.PARA: —No benefit?
—He has none.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition and the seconder of the motion were heard in silence. The Minister will also be heard in silence.

—Persistently through the points made by the two Opposition spokesmen in this debate has been the suggestion that, if Senator Richardson had attended a Cabinet meeting in this regard, he had direct personal pecuniary interest in this area. The fact is that he does not. The particular station in question is a station that is operated by the Australian Labor Party's New South Wales branch. It has operated it for years.
—Did you know he was a director?
—Was he paid for being a director?
—He receives no payment.
—Does he get stamps?
—I warn the honourable member for Kooyong.
—Does he get a free lunch?
—I warn the right honourable member for New England.

—He does not even get stamps, and so he was not able to make a contribution to the campaigning activities of the former Leader of the National Party. He receives absolutely no pecuniary interest from this exercise. It is the sort of position that long-serving officials of the Australian Labor Party in New South Wales get appointed to from time to time, as part of their effective duties associated with their activities as members of parliament. So he had absolutely no personal pecuniary interest in this matter at all.

PARA.TAB: The second point I make relates to decisions that were taken in relation to a reduction of licence fees. As was rightly pointed out by the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), that decision by us to halve the licence fees that radio stations were paying was a step of considerable importance to the radio industry in this country. As honourable members would know, there is scarcely a radio station in this country making a profit. The decision that we took on that particular matter, to lower their fees by some 50 per cent, was the correct decision, but it was a decision taken in the absence of Senator Richardson at both the Expenditure Review Committee meeting and the Cabinet meeting which decided on it. So that particular point made by the Opposition has no substance to it whatsoever.

The fact that Senator Richardson experiences any particular difficulty at all with this matter arises from his membership of the Cabinet and not his membership of the Senate. As honourable members would be aware in this place, all of us here, courtesy of the initiatives of this Government, are required to make a statement of our pecuniary and other interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senators are not.

—And senators are not. That is a very good point raised by the Leader of the National Party, interjecting out of his seat. The reason is that the Liberal Party of Australia takes these matters so seriously that it will not permit us to carry in the Senate a proposition that honourable senators should be in a position to declare their pecuniary interests.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much noise.
—As we hear guffaws of propriety from honourable members opposite on this, they might come to reflect on the fact—

PARA.TAB: Mr Filing interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Moore will cease interjecting or I will name him.

—The only reason why they themselves make any particular points on this and are in that situation is that we made them do it. When they are in a position to stop us making them do it, then they are very clear cut about opposing us.

PARA.TAB: I make a further point on this, that Cabinet Ministers also make a declaration of their interests. When we determined that Cabinet Ministers should make a public declaration of our interests, who opposed us? The good old team opposite. They did not think that that was a very good idea at all. They said that Ministers ought to disclose their interests to the Prime Minister, but Ministers ought not to be placed under any sort of obligation to publicly expose their interests at all. This is the background of moral rectitude that the Liberal Party brings to this debate in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. My point of order relates to standing order 196 which deals with the issue of pecuniary interests. It is quite clear that pecuniary interests and disclosure of pecuniary interests are a separate matter from registration of interests—
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member will resume his seat.
—and that is dealt with in these Standing Orders and I am sure—
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat.

—Whether it amounts to declarations, disclosures or anything else, I am afraid that those opposite have been markedly lacking in coming forward and supporting the Government—and they still fail to do so in relation to the Senate, as they very well know.

PARA.TAB: The fact of the matter is that the Minister ought not to have been a director and ought to have resigned. He has apologised to the Prime Minister for that. From his point of view, it is a totally inadvertent lapse, the sort that he might well make given that he has no pecuniary interest arising from it.

As far as the substance of this motion is concerned, I remind honourable members opposite and members of this House that the Prime Minister did not happen to be in that position at the time or attend any of those Cabinet meetings. As far as this was concerned, he was simply not in a position to know anything about it.

The Prime Minister has accepted that Senator Richardson has inadvertently failed to place this in his notice. I might say that is not unusual for members of this House. I would be interested to know whether all honourable members opposite have declared in the register every particular organisation of which they are a member. Indeed, the inadvertent slips in this regard, as far as members on both sides of the House are concerned, have been quite frequent. A ton of hypocrisy has been introduced in this debate. There is no danger that the public interest in any—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Under standing order 91 the time allowed for debate has expired.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Dr Hewson's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) asked me whether, in the light of the disclosure by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Richardson), I would ask the President of the Senate whether there are any circumstances where there has been a conflict in the Minister's failure to disclose and his vote on the record of proceedings in the Senate chamber.

PARA.TAB: As is made clear in House of Representatives Practice, each House functions as a distinct and independent unit within the framework of the Parliament. The right inherent in each House to exclusive cognisance of matters arising within it has evolved through centuries of parliamentary history and is made clear in the provisions of the Constitution. The complete autonomy of the Houses, within the constitutional and statutory framework extant at any given time, is recognised, among other matters, in regard to its own procedure.
As the right honourable member for New England would realise—as I said to him at the time—it would be quite improper for me to do what he has asked. I certainly do not intend to do so.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Public Works Committee: Construction of a New Permanent Repository for Australian Archives, East Burwood, Victoria

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEDDALL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus), I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Construction of a new permanent repository for Australian Archives, East Burwood, Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed work recommended by the Public Works Committee involves the construction of a new permanent repository for the Australian Archives at East Burwood, Victoria. The proposed facility will provide up-to-date climate controlled, secure storage facilities for permanent value Commonwealth records. It will consist of three main elements, record storage, office accommodation and conservation. The office accommodation and conservation areas will be located in a two-storey configuration fronting a three-level record storage area. The building and site planning will also allow for future expansion of the facilities.

PARA.TAB: The proposal was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works in December 1991. The Committee tabled its report on 31 March 1992, recommending construction at a cost of $6.5m at October 1991 prices.

The Australian Archives and Australian Construction Services have noted all the Committee's recommendations and provide the following responses. The Committee felt that there may be insufficient car parking spaces if staffing levels at East Burwood were to increase in future. The staffing levels at East Burwood are based on maximum expected levels when fully operational in the future. However, the site has sufficient scope to expand car parking facilities to cater for additional vehicles should they be required.

The Committee felt that Archives should proceed with the upgrading of all air-conditioning systems in existing purpose-built repositories. Archives will continue to upgrade all existing air-conditioning systems as part of its ongoing energy management program.

The Committee recommended that the domestic hot water required at the proposed East Burwood facility be provided from solar hot water heaters. The domestic hot water supplied to the new facility will utilise solar energy through solar panels erected on the roof which will be assisted by a small gas booster.

The Committee recommended that the building structure be designed to withstand the effects of an earthquake similar in magnitude to the 1990 Newcastle earthquake. The building structure is inherently suitable to resist earthquake loads and it is expected to survive an event comparable to the Newcastle earthquake with minor damage to cladding, partitions and services, but without any major damage to the structure. I thank the Committee for its report. I commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition parties do not oppose the motion to have this work done. I would like to make one very brief observation, one that I have made on some of the recommendations from the Committee in the past. While I understand the reason why the Committee recommends that the hot water service include solar panels, I would point out that, even at today's pricing, that is a more expensive option. I believe that it is an option that is not necessarily ruled out at the time of construction and may well be adopted at a later stage. I merely make that observation. I also add that, as this construction work is to be in the electorate of my colleague the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Beale), I believe he has some very pertinent comments to make.

—As the Federal member for Bruce, I welcome this motion that will result in the construction of the Australian Archives building in East Burwood. I should tell the House that this is a beautiful part of Melbourne. As one comes along the Burwood Highway heading out towards Ferntree Gully, Springvale Road turns to the right. This Archives construction will be in the middle of that huge block on the corner of Springvale Road and the Burwood Highway, which currently houses Radio Australia, a transmitting station of Aussat and, of course, the Tally Ho Technology Park. As one stands on the block and looks east, one looks out towards the beautiful Dandenong foothills. The city and the town at the bottom of the foothills is appropriately named Ferntree Gully because it is such a beautiful part of Melbourne. This building of two storeys which is to be built there will no doubt have beautiful views out along the Dandenong. I think those people who work there will have a most enjoyable workplace.

PARA.TAB: I note that the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) has said that there will be appropriate air-conditioning. I can assure the Minister that, at least for several months of the year, that is certainly needed there. I only wish that I had an appropriate level of air-conditioning in my electoral office, which is several miles down Springvale Road from where the Archives centre will be.

Whatever the economic merits might be of increased or decreased government spending, given an overall level of spending, the centre is to be welcomed because it will create some jobs in my area of Melbourne. I will make sure that—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is he going to privatise it?
—It is not a bad idea to at least contract out the services. Perhaps that is something that we will have a look at in about a year's time.

PARA.TAB: Being there on the spot, I will be keeping an eye on this construction, firstly to make sure that the Minister's interests are protected by there being no cost overruns and, secondly, to make sure that we do not have operating there those restrictive work practices that hamper so many government projects. I welcome this motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Public Works Committee: Installation of fire sprinklers to the International Terminal Building, Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEDDALL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament: Installation of fire sprinklers to the International Terminal Building, Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: The international terminal at Kingsford-Smith was opened in 1970 and met all the then relevant codes. Since that time the building has been modified in a number of areas to ensure that public safety is not compromised. Airport terminal buildings are not expressly covered by codes, but need to have appropriate protection. A number of reports have recommended the installation of fire sprinklers to provide safety to the occupants of the building, to protect property as well as other improvements, to provide smoke isolation, an emergency evacuation system and additional fire exits.

PARA.TAB: The Federal Airports Corporation assumed control of Sydney Airport on 1 January 1988. Since that time additional fire exits have been constructed as part of improvements to the international terminal, which was completed in 1989 at a cost of $50m. Smoke isolation measures were also installed on existing stairwells and escalators.

The Corporation later proceeded with further extensions to provide a new 70,000 square metre terminal and concourse at a cost of $272m. The design of the fire protection measures for the new terminal expansion was based on the assumption that the existing terminal building would have fire sprinklers installed. The works proposed at this time comprise installation of fire sprinklers throughout the existing building, associated building works, the replacement of plasterboard ceilings and ceiling tiles in the customs hall and departures area, and the treatment of asbestos from within the ceiling voids associated with the sprinkler installation.

The FAC board has approved funding of $14.6m as an outturn cost for the installation of fire sprinklers in the existing terminal building. It is proposed that these works will commence in June 1992 with completion within 2 1/2 years. In its report the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works agreed to the installation of fire sprinklers to the international terminal building at Kingsford-Smith Airport to meet the current fire safety standards, subject to the following recommendations.

The Committee recommended that the Federal Airports Corporation commission a fire safety study to determine whether cost savings can be made in the provision of fire sprinklers. The Federal Airports Corporation has accepted a proposal to undertake a fire safety study by the CSIRO Division of Building Construction and Engineering. This study will proceed without delay. May I say, as one who has visited that fire safety operation of CSIRO, that it is perhaps one of the best state-of-the-art operations in the world.

The Committee recommended that the Minister for Shipping and Aviation (Senator Collins) direct the Federal Airports Corporation to complete an approved master plan for Sydney Airport as a matter of extreme urgency. A draft planning strategy for Sydney Airport was circulated for public comment in August 1990. This public review period closed on 13 November 1991. The FAC is about to commission the consultants SKP/Bechtel to finalise the Sydney Airport planning strategy, based on comments received, as a matter of urgency.

The Committee recommended that the Federal Airports Corporation thoroughly reassess all aspects of the outturn cost of $14.6m to determine areas of possible cost savings. On receipt of the findings of the CSIRO fire safety study, FAC will take all opportunities to minimise outturn costs. The Committee also recommended that the Federal Airports Corporation take all possible steps to minimise the need for the payment of disability allowances, and advise it on the extent of any such payments.

The FAC will undertake the timing and staging of the works so as to restrict the extent of any disability allowance and will seek advice from tenants as to the extent of any such payments made. I would like to thank the Committee for its support on this particular motion and the others that have come through to us today, and I commend this motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —While not opposing this motion, I would like to emphasise a couple of the points that the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works has drawn to the attention of the Government. I believe these are quite serious, and that the Government ought to be making sure that some action is taken. The first one is the Committee's recommendation that the Federal Airports Corporation commission a fire safety study to determine whether cost savings can be made in the provision of the fire sprinklers. I will come back to this point in a moment. While the Government has said that this has been accepted by the FAC, the fact remains that the Committee has drawn attention to it as a point of concern and obviously has strong reasons for it.

PARA.TAB: The second point is that the Committee again talks about a master plan as a matter of extreme urgency. This has been raised before. Despite that, there are still some delays, and clearly it is a matter of great concern. If we do not have a master plan, money could be wasted because it might be directed into areas that are not a matter of priority or are not a matter of long term need. It is a matter of grave concern that it has had to be raised yet again. I commend the Committee for having the courage to state that it is a matter of extreme urgency. It does place pressure on the Government, and on the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) in particular, to do a little bit more.

Again the Committee has come back to the point about cost savings. It is very important that this matter be raised, and the fact that the Committee has alluded to it means that the Committee itself is of the opinion that there probably are cost savings to be made. The onus is now on the Federal Airports Corporation, through pressure from the Government, to actually achieve those savings. I would hope that when the project is complete we will be able to hear about how those savings have been achieved.

The last point I would like to come back to is the Committee's recommendation that the FAC take all possible steps to minimise the need for payment of disability allowances and to advise it of the extent of any such payments. I think that is another very important point, because questions arise as to who will pay the disability allowances. Is it going to be the users or is it going to be the FAC? Again, the fact that the Committee has alluded to this indicates that it could be potentially quite a serious problem. I believe it behoves the Government to ensure that such a problem does not arise before rather than after the event, when it is too late. With those comments I would like to again support the Public Works Committee in its efforts. As I say, the coalition does not oppose this motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Order! Mr Speaker has received a message from the Senate acquainting the House that Senator Bourne has been discharged from further attendance on the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations.
Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Asian Development Fund Bill 1992 is to authorise a contribution by Australia of $350m towards the fifth replenishment of the Asian Development Fund. The ADF is the concessional lending arm of the Asian Development Bank. Its resources are directed towards the poorest countries in the Asia-Pacific region. It is important that we contribute to and work towards improving the standard of living of these economies, because not only is it compassionate and sensible to do so, but also, of course, as the economies of these nations and their political and economic stability improve, Australia will become a recipient of bilateral trade.

PARA.TAB: The Asia-Pacific region as a trading region is expanding dramatically for Australia. I think the region accounts for something like 70 per cent of our trade; it is certainly worth something like $19.1 billion, $7.5 billion of which is a surplus in our favour. That is growing at something like 8 per cent per annum. I think that is very exciting.

The opportunities that will come through as consumer demand grows and standards of living improve in these nations can never be underestimated. Australia has been a member of the ADF since it was established in 1974 and has participated in the four previous replenishments. The Asian Development Fund Act 1974 authorised Australia's contribution to the establishment of the fund. Further contributions were authorised under the Asian Development Fund Acts of 1976, 1978, 1982 and 1987.

The Australian contribution of $350m amounts to about 6.5 per cent of the total fifth replenishment value of about $US4.2 billion. The main principle of payment arrangements is that contributions should be paid in instalments in such a manner that at least one payment is made in each of the four calendar years covered by the fifth replenishment, that is, 1992 to 1995.

With regard to the financial impact, in accordance with Australian practice, payment will be made in the form of non-negotiable, non-interest bearing promissory notes which are expected to be encashed over a period of nine years beginning in 1992-93. Funds required for 1992-93 will be provided within the global development assistance allocation. Funds for future years will be found within the global development assistance forward estimates.

The Government recognises that banks can be particularly effective in many areas. In particular, they can encourage macro-economic reform in developing countries, as I said, with the stabilisation of monetary and fiscal policies, flexible exchange rates and debt reduction and management. They can also implement development cooperation activities on a scale that is not possible for Australia as a single donor, particularly for poor groups in countries which fall outside the regional focus of Australia's bilateral aid. Banks can also be particularly effective in stimulating policy reform, for example, with regard to specific cross-cutting issues such as the environment and women in development. They can develop better policy environments by, for example, reforming institutional frameworks and including transparency in policies. Banks can also undertake research functions.

The environment is a very important issue with regard to developing countries. One of the things that always concern me is that some multinational companies see an advantage in setting up in Third World countries because the infrastructure costs are much less and because there is not, in many instances, a requirement for the level of pollution controls that we expect and that are accepted in Australia and, indeed, in most of the developed world. Because these countries are keen to have industry, they have in the past in some instances accepted lower standards for themselves to see those jobs and industrial growth.

I have always believed that the environment is a global issue. There are people who, while they may be dedicated to the environment in this country and want to stop development here, shut their eyes to development in Third World countries that are actually polluting the environment. Either we have to work, through frameworks such as this Bill recognises, to improve their level of education and understanding so that they ensure that decent pollution controls are in place or we have to develop those industries here under our control so that we can ensure that the global issues of pollution are managed in a sensible way.

There are some countries in South East Asia that are cutting down massive areas of rainforest for industrial development and also for agriculture—some of which is necessary. But it is interesting to note that often the people who criticise us when we cut down a tree in Australia do not level the same amount of criticism at these countries. Those problems can be resolved only by creating a better economic environment in Third World countries, a better understanding and better cross-referencing of ideas.

The Australian Government directly focuses about 70 per cent of its aid on the Asia-Pacific region. However, the Government recognises that some of the world's poorest people live in the countries where we do not have bilateral development cooperation programs. Providing aid to these countries, whether directly or indirectly, helps meet our objective of being a good international citizen. I think that is important. We can be proud of the role we play in many areas—Cambodia is one that comes to mind—certainly ever since the United Nations was formed, and Australia played a leading role, we have been at the forefront in trying to make it a better world. As I said, this Bill contributes in that way.

The multilateral development banks represent a means for Australia to channel funds into the poorest countries, whose populations are mostly in Asia. Other organisations which have a global mandate also focus aid in the Asia-Pacific region.

The other matter I would like to touch on briefly, because time is short, is that of using letters of credit. Australia could stop using promissory notes and use letters of credit, as do some other countries, but there is a problem with this. To make a change to letters of credit would result in Australia having to make payments for existing commitments and the new commitments at the same time. This would substantially increase the share of the development cooperation budget going to the MDBs in the short term and place severe pressure on the bilateral component of the aid program. I think we can justifiably say that the present system of using promissory notes makes sense.

As I said earlier in this speech, I think that Australia has a massive role to play in the Asia-Pacific region. We can be proud of the role we are playing. It will need to be increased. I am pleased that the Opposition is supporting this Bill; that is important. Where it is possible for both the Government and the Opposition to be in tune, it is an advantage on the international stage because other countries look at us and take cognisance of what we say. I think we can be very proud of what we have done. Because time is short, I will close on that note.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the previous speaker, the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice), because, as he pointed out, the purpose of the Asian Development Fund Bill is to authorise a contribution by Australia of $350m towards the fifth replenishment of the Asian Development Fund.

PARA.TAB: I note that, in presenting the second reading speech, the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) presented background information on the Asian Development Bank and the role it plays as a major international development agency. He noted in that speech that the Asian Development Fund was established in 1974 and that its parent body is the Asian Development Bank. That bank, of course, was established in 1966 with the principal objective of encouraging economic growth and development in Asia and the Far East, including the South Pacific. The Asian Development Bank is a multinational one in character with 47 member states, the majority being from the Asia-Pacific region. It promotes investment of public and private capital for development purposes; provides loans for the encouragement of growth; coordinates the economic and development plans and policies of its member states; provides technical assistance in support of important development projects and programs; and cooperates with relevant United Nations agencies.

As the honourable member for Macarthur pointed out, the Asian Development Fund is the concessional arm of the Asian Development Bank and about one-third of the bank's lending is on concessional terms. The contributions to the fund are one of the largest single items in Australia's official overseas development commitment. Australia has been and remains a strong and active supporter of the bank. I believe it is generally acknowledged that the bank is highly regarded in the international capital markets for its responsible and rigorous operational practices in increasingly complex and demanding circumstances.

Since its establishment, the bank has lent about $33 billion for well over a thousand projects. The bulk of this lending has gone into mainstream economic development projects and programs. But in looking at the history of the bank, it is interesting to note the change that has occurred over 26 years in the relative importance of sectoral lending. For example, in the 1960s the major sectors were ranked in the order of transport and communications, finance, agriculture, industry and mining, energy, and social infrastructure. By the late 1980s and early 1990s that order had become agriculture, energy, transport and communications, social infrastructure, finance, and industry and mining. In short, agriculture, energy and social infrastructure have gained in relative importance, while finance, transport and communications, and industry and mining have fallen.

There has been some criticism over recent years of multilateral development banks generally, including the Asian Development Bank, about what might be called their project lending philosophy. It is possible that the bank's altered lending patterns referred to above reflect some success in moving the bank away from an emphasis on lending targets and towards such policy reform areas as structural and social adjustment and, more recently, towards environmentally aware projects.

In view of that criticism, it is surprising to me that the bank has not responded more aggressively with evaluation material to support the benefits which come from its lending strategy. For example, the bank does comment in its annual reports on what it calls its post-evaluation policies, but there is surprisingly little information given. What is reported gives the reader the impression that that evaluation is more in terms of whether the project is judged to be a success or failure in terms of its direct benefits. What I would look for, particularly in relation to infrastructure and structural adjustment projects, is not only an assessment of their immediate success and benefit but also a careful analysis of their success within the broader arena of structural adjustment compliance and an assessment of their effectiveness in terms of the bank's broad policy framework. Perhaps this is simply a matter of editorial policy in the bank's annual reports. If this is the case, it is a policy I believe to be regretted, for it is a practice which leaves the reader with a concern that projects which offer immediate, identifiable and apparently significant benefits at the project level might be given some preference over other projects which have less identifiable immediate benefits but offer important increments within a given structural adjustment program.

It is possible that the bank has done considerable work in this area of evaluation, but if it has it is not being properly reflected in its published material. In fact, I believe some concern must be felt that the bank's 1990 annual report not only reported very briefly on its post-evaluation work but gave much of that space to the fact that resource considerations had forced it to alter its policy from one of evaluating all projects and programs to one of selective evaluation. I think there must be some sympathy for the pressures which forced such a decision, but the matter of real moment is that those scarce resources be applied in the most effective manner within a clearly structured policy program.

There is, I believe, growing tension among both donors and borrowers as to the most appropriate lending policies for multilateral development banks. I have seen published reports that the World Bank is suffering a decline in its success rate. Clearly, this is also a factor which must be given careful attention by the Asian Development Bank. In its latest annual report it admitted that only eight, or 30 per cent, of the 27 projects evaluated in 1990 were considered to be successful. The bank correctly acknowledges that one of the disadvantages of selective evaluation is that it tends to direct resources towards those projects which appear to have problems. However, it also acknowledges that its long term overall success rate is only 63 per cent, a figure which suggests that far greater attention needs to be given to research, policy conditionality and project management.

Perhaps the implications of what I am saying could be better understood if I were to point out that what we really face is a situation not only where $37 of every $100 loaned by the bank is unsuccessful by its own criteria, but also where some of the bank's critics would question both the appropriateness of that criterion and its associated policy framework. Some donor countries are clearly concerned about the value which recipient countries are receiving from each loan dollar, and there is some evidence of a growing momentum in favour of change. The strength and direction of that change is for the bank's board to assess, but it seems evident that there will be increasing demands from major donor countries for loans to be conditional on borrowing countries accepting policy reforms and for more evidence that funds are being used effectively.

These are matters which I would expect the bank to be addressing in a highly professional way. Its lending philosophies have been and are being questioned and its policy strategies and effectiveness are in need of careful scrutiny. I believe we are heading into an increasingly complex and uncertain time and this, together with expected fiscal constraints throughout the 1990s, points to a need for the Asian Development Bank to show a responsible and responsive attitude.

The honourable member for Macarthur has referred to policy guidelines recently set by the bank, including a focus on poverty alleviation, the role of women, cooperation with non-government organisations, the environment and the development of the private sector. These are sometimes referred to as social sector and cross-cutting programs. It should be noted that their place within the bank's policy framework is not yet agreed on and is still the cause of considerable debate.

The honourable member for Macarthur also suggested that the bank became increasingly concerned in the 1980s about the impact of development projects on the environment. A policy framework has now been established, we are told, which incorporates environmental considerations into every project. That may well be the case, but I can find little in the bank's published material which indicates that it has a sufficient appreciation of the critical and urgent interrelationship between development and the environment and the importance of this for many donor countries. For example, in its latest annual report it offers an administrative note that its environment division has been upgraded to the Office of the Environment, but there is little else by way of comment on environment related content within its project and program lending.

If the honourable member for Macarthur is correct in saying that the bank is genuinely concerned about environmental matters, it must be assumed that the sensitive nature of environmental guidelines for some borrowers is encouraging the bank to under-report both its efforts and achievements in this field. The bank will be well aware, I am sure, that the development-environment relationship is a matter of importance to Australia as well as to a number of other major donor countries. This subject will inevitably become a matter for increased and urgent attention by the bank.

There are some grounds for concern about the bank's response to these considerable and admittedly complex pressures but, as I have suggested above, there is some feeling that the bank is not identifying and adjusting quickly enough to the rapidly changing economic and geopolitical circumstances of the 1990s, that its loan quality is not receiving sufficient attention and that its project orientation and lending criteria are no longer totally appropriate to today's circumstances. At the bank's 1986 annual general meeting, Australia's then Acting Treasurer, Chris Hurford, commented:

SPEECH.PARA: The argument that the bank should not sacrifice the quality of its loan projects in order to achieve lending targets is one which we support. Bad projects benefit neither the bank nor the developing countries concerned.

PARA.TAB: If we relate that comment back to the matters that I have already stressed—the low rate of success of projects, the reduction in evaluation auditing, the slowness of policy reforms and an undue cautiousness in handling environmental considerations—then we see that the bank has reached a point where a major review of its objectives and operations may be needed. Here I readily admit to a sympathy for the bank at this time of very rapid and complex change. But in such circumstances the obvious need is urgent and effective dialogue to establish agreed policy strategies and lending priorities. What many of us want, in short, is evidence of a commitment to the inevitable process of change.

If I can take the House back to 1982, we will recall that the bank's replenishment target for the years 1979 to 1982 was $US2.15 billion and that Australia contributed $A97m or 5.14 per cent of that target. In negotiating for the next period, from 1983 to 1986, the bank recommended the target of $US4.1 billion, a figure which would have maintained its annual lending growth at about 17.5 per cent. Australia supported that target, but international support was not forthcoming and the target was reduced to $US3.2 billion. At this level the bank was able to maintain its lending in real terms, but without any growth. To meet that target, and to give tangible evidence of its support for the bank, Australia was obliged to increase its share to about 7.2 per cent. Negotiations over the next replenishment period, from 1987 to 1990, began in 1985, with Australia among a small group of countries which agreed on a $US4 billion replenishment target in order to maintain real lending levels but again with no provision for growth. In this case, the final agreed target was reduced to $3.6 billion and Australia's pledge of $A410m increased its contribution to a 7.98 per cent share.

As we debate the present replenishment, Australia now finds itself in the position of being the fifth largest donor overall and the second largest in this region after Japan. But to maintain the existing share contribution of 7.98 per cent, Australia would have to provide $A431m. In fact, as the honourable member for Macarthur has already pointed out, our contribution is to be $A350m, a share of only 6.5 per cent. That, of course, is a very substantial reduction.

Mr Deputy Speaker, no doubt you will recall that the honourable member for Macarthur referred to the increasingly satisfactory performance of the bank, but reflected on Australia's need to consider its capacity to contribute to future loan commitments. Specifically, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the reduction from our last share was necessitated by our difficult economic and budgetary situation, and our wish to maintain flexibility in the aid budget.

That latter remark is directed to the current fiscal constraints and a wish to place a greater emphasis on bilateral aid assistance. Of course, the Opposition has some sympathy for this and honourable members will be aware that the Fightback package commits the coalition to an overall reduction in the aid vote, but with increased emphasis on, and attention to, bilateral commitments to improve delivery, greater priority to our regional interests and greater opportunities for Australian firms.

PARA.TAB: What is clear is that just as a number of donor countries have previously constrained their contributions to the bank, Australia now finds itself in circumstances where it has similar constraints. Realistically it seems to me to be unlikely that the Asian Development Bank will operate through the 1990s with other than, at best, a maintenance of its lending programs in real terms, and I would be surprised if it achieved that result.

The bank must be well aware of these influences and I would expect it to respond accordingly. I believe it has played an important role in fostering economical and social development in the region of immediate interest to Australia and, as I have pointed out, we have given it very considerable support. While Australia will continue to play its part as a significant member of the bank, global, economic and geopolitical circumstances suggest that the bank must now review its present strategies and policies if it is to meet the needs of members into the next century.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gayler Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The sole purpose—I stress the word `sole'—of the Asian Development Fund Bill currently before the House is to facilitate a contribution by Australia of $350m towards the fifth replenishment of the Asian Development Fund. Whilst that is the only purpose of the Bill, I think it is important to refer to some of the past efforts of the fund and the bank and look somewhat into the future as the previous speaker, the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar), did in the latter part of his address.

PARA.TAB: The Asian Development Fund is the concessional lending arm of the Asian Development Bank. Its resources are directed towards the poorest countries in the Asia-Pacific region. Australia has been a member of the ADF since its inception in 1974 and has participated in the previous four replenishments.

Contributions to the ADF are one of the largest single items in Australia's official development cooperation program. As such, the size of payments can have a significant impact on other components in the program. A $350m contribution represents an appropriate balance that will enable Australia to continue to play a significant role in the Asian Development Bank while, importantly, allowing financial flexibility in the rest of the development cooperation program.

Whilst Australia's contribution is lower than that committed to the fifth replenishment, explanation of that reduction was given to participating members of the fund. Australia's contribution, accounting for about 6.5 per cent of the total replenishment, is still higher than the 6.1 per cent average of Australia's previous contribution to the ADF, and we remain, as other speakers have pointed out, the second largest regional donor in the fund, after Japan. This move to limit the growth of share of ADF in the overall development cooperation budget reflects the need to maintain flexibility, as I mentioned previously.

Turning to the role of the Asian Development Bank, a major international development agency owned by the governments of 36 countries from the Asia-Pacific region and 16 countries from Europe and North America, it is worth while making reference to the agreement establishing the bank. That agreement, which forms part of the Asian Development Bank Act, expressed the view of the contracting parties at the time in these terms:
Considering the importance of closer economic cooperation as a means for achieving the most efficient utilisation of resources and for accelerating the economic development of Asia and the Far East;

SPEECH.PARA: and:

realising the significance of making additional development financing available for the region by mobilising such funds and other resources, both from within and outside of the region, and by seeking to create and foster conditions conducive to increase domestic savings and greater flow of development funds into the region;
and, further:
recognising the desirability of promoting the harmonious growth of the economies of the region and the expansion of external trade of the member countries.

The passage of time since that agreement was forged in 1966 has not altered the basic charter of the bank. In 26 years of operations the bank has become a major catalyst in promoting development of the most populous and fast growing region in the world today.

PARA.TAB: The bank's principal functions include, firstly, to make loans and equity investments in the economic and social advancement of developing member countries; secondly, to provide technical assistance for the preparation and execution of development projects and programs and advisory services; thirdly, to promote investment of public and private capital for development purposes; and, finally, to respond to requests for assistance in coordinating policies and plans of the member countries. In its operations the bank is also required to give special attention to the needs of the smaller or less developed countries and to give priority to regional, subregional and national projects, together with programs which will contribute to the harmonisation of economic growth in the region as a whole.

The bank's operations cover the entire spectrum of economic development, with particular emphasis on agriculture, energy, capital market development, transport and communications, and social infrastructure. Most bank financing is designed to support specific projects; however, the bank also provides program sector and multiprogram loans. The bank actively pursues cofinancing activities with official as well as commercial and credit sources. The bank has also entered into equity operations.

When one looks at the history of the Asian Development Bank, it is clear that the bank has played a significant role in the development of the Asia-Pacific region. Up until last year the bank has committed about $37.8 billion in loans and investments for over 1,100 projects. The bank's cumulative commitments have amounted to $655m for about 79 projects. Technical assistance in grants and loans has amounted to $2.7 billion. Cofinancing, which has become an integral part of the bank's operations, has amounted to $10.8 billion, out of which official sources have contributed $7.5 billion and commercial sources have contributed the balance of some $3.3 billion.

The bank also has a fine record with sectoral activities. It has financed about 159 irrigation and area development projects, benefiting 28.3 million people; 82 fisheries, livestock and forestry projects; 99 projects for industrial crops, agro-industry and support services; and eight fertiliser projects. In the important area of energy, 178 projects, including 152 power projects, have been funded.

In the area of transport and communications the following projects have been funded: 46 projects in the ports and shipping sector for the construction, rehabilitation, modernisation and expansion of port facilities; 81 projects for the rehabilitation, maintenance and construction of primary, secondary and feeder roads; seven railway projects to increase freight capacity by about 70 million tonnes; and 14 telecommunication projects to improve and extend services.

As far as social infrastructure is concerned, funding is being made available for the installation of water supply and sanitation projects, benefiting more than 85 million people throughout the region. Funding is also being made available for 51 education projects involving the establishment, as well as the rehabilitation and expansion, of primary, secondary and tertiary education and training institutions, together with a variety of urban infrastructure facilities. Of course, not all projects have been successful. However, with the careful monitoring of the projects and programs, the success rate continues to improve. The Australian Government directly focuses about 70 per cent of its aid on the Asia-Pacific region.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension I was indicating the enormous contribution that Australia makes to this region as far as aid is concerned. I indicated that Australia focuses some 70 per cent of its aid in the Asia-Pacific region. However, the Government recognises that some of the world's poorest people live in the countries where we do not have bilateral development cooperation programs. Providing aid to these countries whether directly or indirectly helps to meet our objective of being what can be referred to as a good international citizen.

PARA.TAB: The multilateral development banks represent a means for Australia to channel funds into the poorest countries whose populations are mostly in Asia. Other organisations which have a global mandate also focus aid in the Asia-Pacific region. The ADF focuses most of its lending on the poorest countries. As mentioned in the second reading speech, about 60 per cent of ADF funds are committed to projects in the Bangladesh and Pakistan areas where the average per capita income was $US180 and $US360, respectively, in 1989.

Our aid enables us to contribute to areas and in ways that we could not as a bilateral donor; for instance, policy dialogue in Papua New Guinea. Maintaining a share to the MDBs at about 12 to 14 per cent would still enable generous bilateral programs to be maintained with countries in our own region.

The Government has strongly encouraged the ADB to: firstly, give more attention to activities in the South Pacific area, for example, prepare economic reports for a number of individual island economies; secondly, continue concessional lending to PNG, most recently at 3.19 per cent of the ADB commitments in 1991, which is up from some 1.3 per cent in 1990; thirdly, expand the activities of its South Pacific regional office in Vanuatu—in April 1991 additional ADB responsibilities were transferred to that region; fourthly, to support efforts by the region to help itself and set its own agenda. In other words, this Bill reinforces the Asia-Pacific focus squarely and unequivocally.

I conclude my remarks today by making reference to some specific areas within the region. I will refer to India and China first. I understand that access to ADB for both India and China was supported by all donor countries, with the exception of the United States. Australia argued against separate treatment for India and China both being eligible under ADB criteria for ADF funding and noted that Australia would consider additional funding over the course of ADF6 if India-China access was accepted. Once again, this was rejected by the United States, and access to both India and China was denied. India and China continue to have access to the ADB loans on non-concessional terms—a position that I trust will be reversed in the not too distant future.

Turning finally to Papua New Guinea, Australia supports the lead agency role of the ADB in Papua New Guinea. However, in the agricultural, transport and health sectors some concern must be expressed that the banks have not given sufficient attention to sector development projects which would require the ADB to take a more active and substantial role in both program design and monitoring performance. It is important that we look at collaborating more closely with the ADB and these sectors in sector studies and co-financing programs and projects.

Whatever the shortcomings and flaws that have been shown to exist in the implementation of the projects and programs funded by the ADB in Papua New Guinea, it is imperative that ADB activities continue in our nearest neighbour both to complement and support our bilateral aid to that country. As we continue to see the increasing importance of the development of our region and acknowledge the critical role played by the Asian Development Bank and its Asian Development Fund, it is timely that the Government sees fit to make a significant contribution to the sixth replenishment not only to confirm our support for the poorest developing countries in the region but also, most importantly, to allow the necessary programs to be implemented.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dobie The Hon J.D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add my comments today on what is being said about the Asian Development Bank, which I recall I last spoke about in this House some 20 years ago, in August 1972. The Bill we have before us is to authorise a contribution by Australia of some $A350m towards the fifth replenishment of the Asian Development Fund, ADF6. This Bill, together with previous commitments to the international financial institutions, will add to the already substantial proportion of the global aid program committed to the international financial institutions in the years 1992-93 onwards.

PARA.TAB: The Asian Development Fund is the concessional lending arm of the Asian Development Bank which was established in 1974. It should be emphasised that the ADB provides roughly one-third of its loans on concessional terms. It is worth recalling that the basic role of international development banks is to supplement and add to the flow of aid going to developing countries from government sources. The banks have available to them large amounts of capital from donor governments which is not paid in but callable and thus serves as a guarantee for the borrowing activities on the capital markets of the world.
