That is a point that is not often understood. The banks then re-lend the amounts that they have borrowed to the developing countries at relatively low rates of interest. The developing countries themselves either do not have access to these markets or else would have to pay far higher rates of interest; this is known as a soft loan. International development banks thus add substantially to the amounts of capital available to the poorer countries of the world for development purposes.

The ADB was established in 1966 with the principal objective of encouraging economic growth and development in Asia. The ADB promotes investment in the Asian regions of public and private capital for development purposes. It provides loans for the encouragement of growth, coordinates the economic development plans and policies of its member states and provides technical assistance to help prepare, finance and implement development projects and programs.

It is owned by the governments of 36 countries from the Asia-Pacific region and 16 countries from Europe and North America. Its resources are mainly directed towards the poorest countries of the Asia-Pacific region. It is the only regional development bank to which Australia belongs and as such is a symbol of our commitment to the Asia-Pacific region and an expression of our desire and ability to be a good neighbour.

Australia has been a member of ADF since its establishment and has participated in the four previous replenishments. As with the World Bank, Australia has been a strong and consistent supporter of the ADB and ADF. Our Asian Development Fund Act 1974 authorises Australia's contributions to the establishment of the fund, and further contributions were authorised under the ADB Fund Acts of 1976, 1978, 1982 and 1987.

Between ADF3 of 1979-82 and ADF4 of 1983-86, Australia increased its share of ADF funding from 5.14 per cent to 7.10 per cent, or by approximately 40 per cent. This enlarged contribution was initiated by the coalition Government under Malcolm Fraser and continued under the current Labor Government. This change was a reflection of our growing interest in the Asia-Pacific region not only in terms of development assistance but also in terms of foreign policy and trade perspective.

Australia is currently the second largest regional donor to the ADF after Japan, and is the fourth largest overall. Australia's share of ADF6 is, in fact—and this should be noted—lower than its share of ADF5. It is fair to say that this reflects our large existing commitments to the World Bank and our current economic circumstances and prospects. I shall not take the time of the House to discuss this part of my speech further.

Since the inception of ADF our share of funds has, however, averaged around 6.1 per cent. As a major shareholder and contributor to the bank, therefore, Australia plays a significant role in formulating the bank's policies. All Australian Governments must remain vigilant to see that Australians occupy significant positions in the bank's staffing arrangements and control.

In the intervening 20 years since I last spoke on similar legislation in this House, I have visited the Asian Development Bank as I have had close friends who have worked there. It certainly is a very specialised expert group of people who work for ADB. I believe the great trauma is that, despite our large contributions, our staffing positions are nowhere near as senior as they should be. I think that I heard one of my colleagues, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), say earlier that this was because Treasury men were running it. A close friend of mine who was there as a director was in fact a trade department man. So it has not always been Treasury, even if that is the case now.

We really have to be more serious about seeing that Australians have positions of control and authority within the bank. What is not realised anywhere near enough is the degree to which expert consultancies are used by ADB. This is an area where we must continue to see that Australian consultancy firms—particularly in the engineering field—are utilised. It may sound simple but it is something that has to be constantly looked at.

I say to both the Minister in charge of this Bill and his advisers that this is something that has to be examined closely. Far too often we see some of the larger countries taking over as if they half own it. I will not name the nations I have in mind, but they are there and have to be watched. We have to see that we promote Australians to these positions. It is not just a case of getting chaps senior jobs; it is a matter of ensuring that Australian experts are used as experts for the developing countries in Asia. Far too often this is ignored. As I said earlier, I say again to the appropriate people: do something about it. Do not sit back and let the other countries take over, which I suspect they have done. That was certainly happening some few years ago and I strongly suspect that it is still happening.

Consistent with Australia's overall policy standards, ADB is being encouraged to pay greater attention to issues such as the alleviation of poverty rather than having an all-out focus on economic growth. Far from being concerned only with international finance and capital markets, the bank has developed a good reputation in assisting small scale enterprises by local populations. It now systematically looks at the alleviation of poverty as one of its main objectives in framing its strategies to assist development in member countries. Australia also encourages the bank to look at more lending for infrastructure projects, including primary education and health. This trend away from traditional infrastructure projects is similar to the pattern found in the World Bank's policy, and has to be commended.

A second objective of the bank's policy formulation is the role of women in development. For example, the ADF supports a program in Bangladesh known as the rural women employment creation project. This aims to assist women in rural areas by facilitating their access to credit and generally raising their awareness levels about what sort of assistance is available to them.

Another important consideration and relatively recent development in bank policy which Australia, together with other donor countries, has encouraged is the consideration of any negative environmental consequences that the bank might unwittingly promote through the use of its funds. Goodness knows where it is putting some of its funds for the development of the southern Asian region. Very strong environmental considerations need to be brought to bear in this area. However, it has started and one must be pleased about that. For example, for projects that have a significant impact on the environment the ADB releases environmental impact assessment statements at least four months before the project goes to the executive board for consideration. It is in this particular role that we should be seeing Australians coming to the fore, especially with the history and record of Australian consultants in this area as well.

Furthermore, as the previous speaker, the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler), mentioned, Australia has consistently supported the incorporation of India and China within the aid framework of the ADF. However, I understand that no consensus was reached at the last set of negotiations on the ADF and so these funds remain inaccessible to China and India. Australia will continue to lobby for the incorporation of these two countries to access ADF funding, but not at the expense of the smaller traditional recipients on a bipartisan basis.

Another area which Australia has consistently sought to promote within the auspices of the ADF has been the continued high level of assistance to smaller Pacific Island countries and Papua New Guinea. It is probably worth reminding the House once again that, although Papua New Guinea is now a member of the ADB in its own right, at the time of its accession to the bank Australia agreed to stand behind Papua New Guinea's obligations until such a time that it was able to take over its own responsibilities. It is perhaps appropriate that I should mention this as the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) recently visited Papua New Guinea, where he had some interesting things to say about economic development in that country.

The ADB is now taking a leading role in Papua New Guinea in agricultural, road, port and health projects. The promotion of business and economic cooperation at a regional level is one area in which the ADB has played a significant and beneficial role for Australia. I believe that these links are indispensable in promoting a greater sense of community among the nations of the region, and have assisted Australia to come to terms with itself as a fully-fledged partner within the Asia-Pacific group of nations.

Changes within the region and the domestic situations of certain member nations of the ADF are perhaps worth mentioning at this point. While Australia has had constraints due to domestic budgetary pressures to take into account, other players in the field have, in contrast, markedly improved their own economic situations. We will inevitably see a movement away from the traditional spheres of influence such as the United States of America, and a move towards a greater influence by the Asian nations themselves with regard to the direction of policy formulation within the ADB. I am thinking particularly of Taiwan and Japan. A recent Time magazine article says:

SPEECH.PARA: Not surprisingly in a world hungry for investment capital, Taiwan's cash hoard is attracting overseas suitors and multiplying Taipei's opportunities for dollar diplomacy.
Last year the Asian Development Bank successfully raised $100 million in Taipei—
that is, $US100m—

as part of a $300 million dragon bond issue. Says the Bank's Treasurer Tomoo Hayakawa: `For the past 25 years our major capital markets were Tokyo, New York, London, Frankfurt and Zurich'. But now this is where the money is.'

That is, it is in Taipei. I think that this should be taken into account by all Australian politicians and Australian advisers. The significance of Taipei must not be understated as far as Australia is concerned. If we are going to play a part in this neck of the woods, the rim of the Pacific, we have to be much more realistic about our associations and relationships with Taipei. It is good to know that we now have an air service going between the two places.

PARA.TAB: Let me also remind honourable members that Japan has a substantial economic and trading relationship with countries of the Asia-Pacific. In 1990, 32 per cent of Japan's exports were destined for the United States; 14 per cent to the newly industrialised economies, such as South Korea, Hong Kong, Thailand and Singapore; 7 per cent to other ASEAN countries; 2 per cent to China; and 2 per cent to Australia.

In addition, 23 per cent of Japan's imports were sourced from the US, 7 per cent from the NEIS, 10 per cent from the rest of ASEAN, and 5 per cent each from China and Australia. That takes care of half of Japan's imports. Japan's direct investment in Asia—approximately $US7 billion in 1990—has been necessary for the continued development of regional countries. These statistics, therefore, are obvious indicators of Japan's crucial economic importance to the region. It is not just a case of buying properties on the Gold Coast.

Yet Asian nations have been critical of Japan for focussing on Japanese interests and seeing them only in terms of markets, low cost labour and an abundance of natural resources. The belief is widely held that Japan has been unwilling to transfer technology and management skills as part of its investment. I come back yet again to the need to ensure that Australian expertise in the field of consultancy is pushed very strongly. I cannot feel more strongly about this.

The fact that this Japanese investment is substantial and important is illustrated by figures for investment in the ASEAN countries. Figures published recently by the Asian Development Bank indicate that Japanese investment constitutes 45 per cent of foreign investment in Thailand, 27 per cent in Malaysia, 20 per cent in the Philippines, and 16 per cent in Indonesia—making it the largest investor in all four of these countries which are vital to Australia. These are indeed sobering figures. In the Australian Financial Review of 13 April it was reported:

SPEECH.PARA: Developing Asia will continue to be the fastest growing region in the world, underlining its importance as an investment and export market for Australia.
The report went on to say:
It may well be that for a few years, most of the economic dynamism in the world will be concentrated in developing countries in Asia and the Middle East, and to some extent in Latin America.
Greg Earl's article in the Australian Financial Review went on to say:

Malaysia is projected to be the region's growth leader with an 8.5% increase in gross domestic product which is down slightly on the past two years but may pose inflation and current account problems. The region's other growth leaders will be Thailand with an 8.5% increase, China with 7.8%, Taiwan 7.5% and South Korea with 7.3%.
Despite the good figures for inflation which came out today, it is interesting to see where Australia stands when compared with those figures.

PARA.TAB: The figures I have just mentioned should be extremely significant for Australians—governments, traders, tourist industry folk and members of this Parliament—for we must realise that our future depends on the success of the ADB region to overcome poverty, protect its environment and keep up with tourist development.

The ADB is a sound institution to help achieve these goals and I strongly support the Bill, with the regret that bad local circumstances in Australia have meant a lower contribution this time around. I wish the ADB great success. It has a history of strong expert knowledge and dedicated people have worked for it. My great regret is that there has not been a greater contribution by Australian citizens in Manila where it is based.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to join in this debate on the Asian Development Fund Bill because I think it is important legislation. It relates to the role that we as a country can play in helping other nations.

PARA.TAB: I will go back only seven or eight days to an occasion in my office in Rockhampton. I received a phone call from one of my constituents from the central highlands. This person was quite irate to start with. He was very upset and concerned generally about a decision he had just heard of that the Australian Government was going to assist Vietnam with a contribution of $100m in aid. He said—and I had heard it many times before—that charity begins at home. This brought back to me something of the division that exists in the attitudes across this country as to what role we ought to play when it comes to assisting developing nations.

I am pleased to be associated with this legislation. Whilst the previous speakers have pointed out that our contribution this time around will fall to $350m from some $430m, it is still a significant contribution and it will be money well spent. It is being spent through an organisation which has proved itself to be a very efficient and effective vehicle for delivering developmental assistance to the poorest developing nations in our own region and throughout South East Asia and the Pacific.

I think we need to tell the story and explain it to Australian people because, like my constituent who said that charity begins at home and expressed concern about the money that we were giving by way of aid to Vietnam, there are hundreds of thousands of other Australians who do not understand why we, as a country of only 17 million people, are playing our role in helping other countries.

There are those at one end who say that we, as part of the Western developed world, have a moral obligation to help those countries who are in difficulty: those who are disadvantaged and those who are developing. There are others who say, `Look, let's not give away everything we've got; there's got to be a balance'. I think that is the position that most Australians take. It is certainly the position I take.

I also take a very parochial position. I believe the aid we give ought to go, in the main, to our region. I know that we ought to take an international position, in that we need to accept that there are countries throughout the planet which are in difficulty. But I think we need to say that we can do more and we can be more effective if our assistance goes to the local region.

That is why I strongly support the Asian Development Fund. I know that the Asian Development Fund has contributors from all around the world—they come from Austria, Italy, Germany and so on. Some 52 nations are members of the Asian Development Bank and they contribute to its lending arm, the Asian Development Fund. I know that they are not being parochial in their attitude when they also contribute considerable moneys—in fact, millions of dollars—to the South East Asian area.

But I think it is proper that that is where we target. I think there is much to be gained as we increase our aid in this area. It was the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) who said not so long ago that we are locked into a course. In fact, I was given a copy of his speech. He made the comment that we were on this course and that there was no turning back. He was talking about our move to Asia. He was not suggesting that we throw off our culture and our heritage to break away from or cast aside what we are; he was simply saying that we must adopt a new direction. I think this has been happening, it is just that the Prime Minister is giving a higher priority and greater importance to it. It is proper that he does so.

We need to maintain our cultural independence, but we need to broaden our understanding of those around us. Often a myopic view—a very narrow view and a blind position—is taken by people who have never left their home towns. I say that, in reality, there are people in this country who have never gone more than 20 or 30 kilometres from the place where they were born. They do not understand that the world is a big place and that we have world responsibilities.

But this is changing. In 1990, some 50,000 Australia students were studying Japanese. In two years, that has grown to 100,000 students studying Japanese. There is also a growing awareness economically. We have 120 Australian companies which are now heavily involved in Indonesia. Australian companies are playing a role in the coalmining and goldmining industries which make us the dominant nation as foreign investors in that country. We see that our role in the Philippines, in Papua New Guinea, in Indonesia particularly, and throughout the Asian areas is increasing.

Tonight I had the privilege of going to the Chinese Embassy for dinner. I was quite surprised when the Ambassador explained in some detail the growth in our trade with China. It is very clear that what was said some time ago about the drift to three clear economic zones—the Europes, the Americas and the Asias—is coming to pass. This is certainly so when it comes to savings, trade and production.

We need to grab hold of the opportunity that we have. I was given a special report from Ross Garnaut entitled Australia and the North-East Asian Ascendancy. I think he sums up what we have to be about and explains why we need to be part of the Asian Development Bank and support the concessional funding that comes from the Asian Development Fund. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: This is a time of great opportunity for Australia. It is a time when Australians have a chance to grasp the prosperity, self-confidence and independence in an interdependent world that earlier Australians in expansive times had hoped for their country. . . The North-East Asian economies are more closely complementary to Australia in their resource endowments and in the commodity composition of their trade than any other economies on earth. . . In economic terms, Australia's horizons are being widened rapidly by the sustained growth close to our northern shores, of economies that need, uniquely, the goods and services that we have the chance to produce well, and that possess resources that we need most for our development.

I think that sums up the reality, as Malcolm Fraser would have put it so long ago: the reality is that Australia will gain enormously by building those bridges and establishing our credibility and bona fides with our neighbours to the north. It is vitally important that we do not just talk about these things but are in there doing them.

PARA.TAB: We gain greatly, because as we give moneys through the Development Bank—and those moneys are lent in concessional loans to the many different developing nations for the some 63 different projects that are being pursued at the moment—it is our industry and our entrepreneurs that are able to provide products and services. There is an economic gain.

I urge those Australians who have concerns about the amount of money we give in overseas aid to understand that ultimately we are the beneficiaries. The world benefits most in that we have a better and a healthier world and we start redressing the sorts of poverty that exist. Poverty reduction has to be placed on the top of the agenda in this world of ours. But we gain not just in moral and human terms, but also in economic terms.

A couple of years ago I had the privilege of being part of a delegation to Indonesia. Whilst we were there, we were talking to some very senior Ministers, as well as the President of Indonesia, and it was pointed out to us in a number of discussions that in that year the Japanese had given $2,000m in aid to Indonesia. That is an enormous amount of money. It is well known that the Japanese have a policy that they go in with their aid and follow with their trade. That is not a bad cliche to run, in some ways. We can gain from that.

We have come a long way from the days when Bill Hayden was foreign Minister. When we took over Government in 1983, I think the trade-aid link was only about 25 or 30 per cent. In those days, the trade-aid link with the USA, Russia and Japan was something like 70 per cent. We have now lifted that, and we are gaining enormously as we go into these countries with our aid support. We also gain significantly when, through a vehicle such as the Asian Development Bank, we are willing to give some $350m to ensure that this money goes to upgrade and enhance the quality of life of the people who live there.

Let us remember that there are some 1.7 billion people in this economic zone. It is a zone in which productivity has been growing above world levels and world averages. It is a zone in which it is all happening, and in which there is an excitement. Those who have had the privilege to visit will understand what I say. It is no wonder that the Western world is pouring so much money into this area.

In 1991 the ADF lent $1.35 billion. Fortunately for us, some 5 per cent, or $70m, of that went into the Pacific area. We must gain, because it supplements what we ourselves are doing. It means that those around us are gaining: they are having infrastructure built—be it in health, education or in general areas of industry. That improves their quality of life, their purchasing power and, ultimately, their demand for products that we produce. This is the point Ross Garnaut has made: we are well-placed geographically and we are well-placed in resource terms to meet the needs of those nations around us. Therefore, it is important that we establish our bona fides well and that we do the right thing.

I have some figures for the last financial year as to what we are contributing in terms of aid. The USA provided 21 per cent of all the money under this scheme. Japan contributed an enormous 35 per cent. We are only a small nation, yet we contributed 6 per cent. I think that is quite significant. I accept that it is down from the previous 7.13 per cent figure, but this $350m will be a major part of the financial resources that these nations need to draw upon to build up their infrastructure to become developed nations rather than developing nations. It is so important that we play our role.

I also note from the figures in material that the Parliamentary Library gave me and that the Minister assisted me with that since the development fund began in 1974, the South Pacific region, our nearest neighbour in those terms and the region which we have a special link with, has received $413m in assistance. We must remember that this is money given interest free with only a one per cent service charge. I think that is considerable. That has meant enormous advantages and leaps forward for our own region. When we add to that the assistance that has now gone to PNG, the Philippines, Indonesia and to those in our near north, we see that our region is benefiting.

I believe it is because of what has happened since 1966, when the bank was set up, and 1974, when the fund was set up, that Asia is now such an exciting place. It is because of that $1.3 billion that has been poured in there over these many years that Asia, South East Asia and the north-east Asian areas are booming in economic terms. Even if it sounds like a broken record, we need to tell those doubters over and over again, `Yes, we understand why we need to give special preference to our own in this country, but we also need to take a worldwide point of view and, more importantly, we need to take a regional point of view'.

I was at a meeting recently when some concerns over environmental matters were expressed to me about a country to our north. I suggest to this House that if we are going to have any impact in environmental terms in our north, we need to be in there, having established our credibility, paying our way, so we can say to these countries we are helping, `We give you this money. We are not going to set strings upon it, but we really believe you must give weight to the environmental needs of these projects'. I believe that is happening.

I note that the bank itself has changed its environmental unit into a full time office. I note that there are more environmental assessments and impact studies now being carried out. It is because Australia is playing its part in saying to these nations, `We want you to develop. We want you to produce. But you must also preserve for the future, and that means preserving your environment'. It is being achieved because Australia, as a contributor, is able to encourage those nations around us to recognise their environmental responsibilities.

We have seen enormous changes. I think our nation can be proud of the part it has played. It is not a lot of money in world terms—$350m, if you say it quickly, is not very much—but it means so much to those nations who get the money. I have travelled in those countries. When I was in Indonesia I was able on behalf of the Government to announce moneys for a water scheme.

When I was in Vietnam a couple of years ago, I saw the work we had done there and the assistance we had given in terms of all sorts of health services. I know these nations have gained by our assistance and that they appreciate it greatly. That is where the friendships begin. That is how we achieve political stability in our region—not by huge armies, not by the might and force of some nation, but by the friendship, trust, cooperation and partnership that is the product of this sort of involvement, an involvement through a joint bank that takes up the causes of those who are the needy, not the greedy.

In saying that, I am not having a go at the countries that do not receive money, but it would be wrong for Hong Kong, Taiwan and Korea to gain from these resources. They are not allowed to. They are not within the two categories that are accepted under the rules of the bank. They do not obtain these funds, and I do not think they need them. What this means is that there is more of the financial cake to be cut and given to those who need it more.

I believe that we as a nation can be extremely pleased with the role we are playing. I understand those who say that we ought to give more, and I understand those who say, `Let's look after our own'; but we ought to have this balance. As we look after the quality of life of our own people—the aged, the young and the families—we have to accept that we are part of a regional area, we are part of a zone, and we need to be a regional partner. The opportunities that this creates for our industry are unlimited.

When I was in Vietnam, I was talking with some Australians from Western Australia who were involved in goldmining there. When I was in Indonesia, I was talking to people who were involved in all sorts of industries there. There are even some people teaching English in the tertiary studies area. It was pointed out to me that there are 11 million Indonesians who are learning English after work each week. That is a massive number when one thinks about it. In a nation of 186 million people spread over 13,000 islands there are 11 million people voluntarily learning English. We are in there supplying some of those services.

I have a very special respect and regard for Indonesia. As chairman of the Australian-Indonesian Parliamentary Friendship Group I have tried to play my role in building that friendship and that partnership. When we as a nation go into independent bodies such as the Development Bank we show these people that we put our money where our mouth is. That is what this Bill is about; it is about giving $350m that belongs to the people of Australia to other people. But we are giving it because we know their need is very important. I am not saying it is greater, but it is certainly very important and in some instances it is more important than our own.

I am not sure that the ultimate result, the ultimate benefit, can be measured. We are playing our role regionally. As I said, some 70 per cent of our assistance is going into this area. We need to take heed of what the Prime Minister says, that this is the future; this is going to be the new economic zone of the twenty-first century. We are perfectly placed geographically and, I suggest, politically to gain from this. We are in a perfect position to be a major player in this new economic bloc that will be east Asia in the future.

We need to ensure that we maintain our independence. We do not want to throw off what we are but we need to prove to these people that we are fair dinkum. We need to show them that our bona fides are genuine, that they can be trusting of us. If we do that, I suggest that we will understand why the Prime Minister was saying that the course we are on is irreversible.It is in our interest. We need to do it financially; we need to it politically; and we need to do it morally.

I entered this debate mainly to take up these issues and hopefully to explain—I will send a copy of my speech to a number of people who have raised this issue of aid with me—that there is good reason for us to be in this role of the contributor in aid programs. That is vitally important not only from a member of a world family but also from a regional partner. It is ultimately vitally important to our own country in the future. I am pleased to see that members of the House on all sides are supporting the principles which have been enunciated in this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a contribution to the debate on the Asian Development Fund Bill 1992 for a number of reasons. The first is that for a long time I have been interested in the distribution of Australian aid, the countries to which our aid is given and the way by which we distinguish between bilateral and multilateral programs. However, to begin, can I say that I find the whole nature and character of debate in this Parliament something that increasingly concerns me.

PARA.TAB: How ridiculous it is that we are talking about spending $350m of taxpayers' money when the Minister at the table is the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown), who has no responsibility in the field—the legislation was introduced by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Martin), who represents the Minister responsible for this area—and when there is nobody in the House who has any bearing on this debate. We pretend that this House in some way has some influence on Government policy. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), who has the prime say in the field, is of course in another place. Essentially, what we are doing is saying that the Senate can conduct a decent debate and pursue matters of detail but we are not giving ourselves an opportunity to do so.

Before I start on the matter, can I just register my concern that the Government is really treating this House with an interesting measure of disregard and, frankly, somewhat less than proper respect. That is apart from any behaviour of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) today at Question Time or immediately after Question Time. I think it is a pity, because this is an area of prime responsibility at a time of economic malaise in this nation.

In our Fightback program we have committed ourselves to reducing our expenditure in the foreign aid field. We have done it on the basis of the best figures that are available to us. The best figures at the moment are provided in what is called the `Green Book'. It is entitled the Australian Official Development Cooperation—Statistical Summary 1990/ 91. This is April 1992, and the figures that I have are already out of date. As everybody in this place will know, the only basis on which we have any chance of making assessments is figures that are already antiquated by the time we deliberate upon them.

We are talking about an expenditure which is going to allow the Asian Development Bank to provide its allocation of funds, as I understand it, to its lending authority over the period from 1992 to 1995. The money is then going to be spent over approximately a 10-year period with draw downs that we are told will represent $1.8m per year over the period from 1992-93 to 1995-96, $9.6m in 1996-97 and approximately $83m per year in the following four years.

If one has a look at the content of the second reading speech of the representative Minister—as I say, it is not the Minister responsible; it is somebody representing him, and so we are down the chain—one sees that there are a number of statistics that I think are absolutely appalling. The speech says that 52 per cent of the projects were assessed to be `generally successful'. What the devil does that mean? Does `generally successful' mean—

TALK.START.PARA: —They weren't real bad.

—They were not too bad. Does it mean that generally the projects were seen by the participating government as being in a worthwhile area? Or does it mean that in normal terms of a banking investment, a fair return on equity has been achieved?
—No, it doesn't mean that.

—Of course it does not mean that. What we have been told is that 52 per cent were only `generally successful'. Never mind the mumbo jumbo; I would like to know how many have been successful. I presume that because they are termed `generally successful', the percentage is significantly less than 52 per cent.

PARA.TAB: But if we thought that was bad enough, the next phrase says, `43 per cent were assessed to be partially successful'. What the devil does that mean? In other words, 95 per cent have been less than fully successful—either `generally successful' or `partially successful'. We have got 5 per cent that we know have been an abject failure.

This is not an ordinary bank; this is a bank that fits within our multilateral aid projects. Let us have a look at our multilateral aid programs. Honourable members will be interested to know just how many there are. Under the heading `International financial institutions' the Australian Government advanced funds of $70m in 1991 to the Asian Development Fund and this year the estimate is nearly $50m; the International Development Association last year was advanced $108.5m and this year the estimate is $109.5m; and the International Fund for Agriculture Development was advanced $2.5m and this year the estimate is $2.8m. In other words, the Asian Development Fund received $70m last year. Presumably, there is a forward commitment, but there is nothing in the second reading speech which allows us to see, other than from the estimate of $49.9m, whether, as I would presume, some part of the funds which are allocated in this Bill will be added to them. We are not told exactly what they are. We will have to wait until next year's `Green Book' comes out to tell us what we are about.

We are supposed to be legislating and deliberating on providing $350m of hard-earned taxpayers' funds. The Ministers are not here. The second reading speech of the representative Minister does not tell us any of the detail. The statistics in the `Green Book' show that we are apparently going to have $49.9m, but nothing tells us how much is really going to be provided and whether that $49.9m has taken into account the additional allocation or not.

If we look at the multilateral aid programs, we see 10 under the `United Nations' title. We then have a general item `Commonwealth Organisations'. The total for the United Nations is $72.5m. Let us put that in perspective: the Asian Development Fund is one of a group of international financial institutions which are allocated $162.2m. There are 10 instrumentalities under the United Nations, and the total is about half of that at $72.5m. I do not know what `Commonwealth Organisations' includes, because we are not given the benefit of any explanation. They are allocated $12.2m. Then we have four `International Research, Environment and Development Organisations', which receive nearly $20m, or $19.6m. Of the total estimate of $1,313.9m for this current year, $266.5m will be allocated to international organisations.

It worries me that Australia is extraordinarily generous. The speaker who preceded me, the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), told us how much money had been spent in Indonesia. Australia has been a very generous contributor to international aid projects over the years. Frankly, whether it is the Asian Development Bank or any of these other funds, I am a bit sceptical about whether we have really received our value for the dollar. There are two bases for saying that: one is this pretty bland statement about success rates of ADB loans, and the other is that we do not really get our fair return in terms of the way in which the ADB fund or any of these other financial institution funds are allocated. Sure, we have a representative on the board and we have a governor, and we participate in all those funds, but things are pretty crook in Australia at the moment.

I do not know whether many people in the electorate of Wills really feel that the employment rate is particularly satisfactory. They are not unique. We could go around Australia at the moment and look at some of the areas where the Victorian Labor Government decided it was going to spend money. Its success rate was probably about the same as that of the ADB. The State Bank of South Australia has not been too hot with its record of successful loans, either. And we could go to Western Australia and look at its record of preferred loans. Are we really getting value for the taxpayers' money in allocating so much to these Development Bank funds?

I move to the record of our bilateral programs. My trouble is that we seem to be always giving with very little return. Sure, we are now contributing a lot more in our region, and I think that is good, but unfortunately in this latest `Green Book' the statistics do not go very far back. They do give us a record of expenditure from 1987-88 to 1991-92 estimates. There is little doubt that we are now spending a big percentage of our aid programs in Papua New Guinea, the South Pacific and South East Asia, and I think that is good.

I notice that we are, however, still maintaining programs in Africa and we are maintaining a number of these international aid programs that make me wonder what we get out of them. I am all in favour of helping women, but we provide a considerable grant to the United Nations Development Fund for Women. We provide a considerable grant of money to the United Nations environment program and the United Nations fund for population activities. We provide significant funds to a range of things such as academic research seminar support. I can tell honourable members that there are a few people around the place who would love to go on academic research seminar support. I do not know quite what it means. We have a range of programs that are too vague, too imprecise, with a success rate that is not sufficiently identified.

If we are going to provide money, as we have, of this order, we really deserve a little more analysis from the Government of what percentage of the ADB's funds is spent on administration. There is none of that here. We like to think that the aid we contribute is actually going to help people, but the Minister representing the Minister representing the Minister has not really told us what percentage of this $350m that we are spending is providing the administrative staff. I will always remember the period when I was President of the Food and Agricultural Organisation of the United Nations some years ago. I was horrified to learn that approximately 40 per cent of the FAO staff is permanently based in Rome. I am not too sure what the ADB's record is.

Australia is the second biggest regional contributor, and the ADB is a very important agency as far as Australia is concerned. It is a pretty appalling effort by the Government to produce a bland statement saying, `We are going to give you this money', without identifying what proportion of the money is going to administration and to what degree something serious will be done about evaluating the success of these projects and making sure that these rather obtuse comments about the partial success of loans that have been made to date are going to be improved for the future.
There is a statement here which I think is an absolute classic:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's Executive Director on the board of the ADB has an important role in encouraging the adoption of better management procedures to improve the administration of the Bank.

I jolly well hope he would. We have been a member since 1974—and this is 1992. Is he only just going to start that role? What exactly has been achieved? Is there a performance record which can satisfy the genuine concerns of the taxpayers of Australia who are wondering whether they are getting value for the dollar spent in this additional allocation of money?

PARA.TAB: Of course, there are, without doubt, a number of projects that we need to address. A lot of our multilateral programs are in areas where they could properly be given more serious review. Some years ago the late Sir Gordon Jackson brought out a very good report on Australia's aid programs. It is my opinion that in 1992 it is time that we had another analysis of the direction and the content and the volume of Australian aid.

I see my colleague the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) in the House. He and I and a number of others have had long debates around Cabinet tables about the amount of money that should be spent on bilateral programs. Frankly, looking at these figures, I would repeat the concern that I have expressed in some of those debates, that I think we give too much money to too many funds and we would do far better by particularising our aid to a greater degree.
By way of example I want to read the titles of a few of the United Nations agencies to which we make significant contributions:

SPEECH.PARA: Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific, Food and Agriculture Organisation, International Atomic Energy Agency, IFAD Technical Assistance, International Labour Organisation, U.N. Border Relief Organisation, U.N. Development Programs, U.N. Disaster Relief Office, U.N. Environment Program, U.N. Education, Scientific and Cultural Organisation—
and remember that was the show that Gough Whitlam was involved in for a while—

U.N. Fund for Drug Abuse Control, U.N. Fund for Population Activities, U. N. High Commissioner for Refugees, U.N. Children's Fund, U.N. Fund for Women, U.N. Industrial Development Organisation, U.N. Organization (Head Office), U.N. Relief & Works Agency, World Bank—Regional Programs, World Food Program, World Health Organisation, Other United Nations Organisations.

They are all eminently desirable and they sound great; but are we getting value for the money we spend? Are we really overcommitting ourselves in a range of international agencies, for which all we get is the bland statement from the Minister that 52 per cent were generally successful, 43 per cent were partially successful and 5 per cent were failures? I do not think it is good enough. I think there is a problem.

PARA.TAB: In this Parliament we need first of all to have Ministers knowing what is happening to the moneys that the taxpayers are contributing; and, secondly, we need to have Ministers in this Parliament who are able to tell us just what is happening to these funds and whether or not the Asian Development Bank and each of these other international financial institutions and multilateral aid programs are yielding to the Australian taxpayers the returns that I believe they deserve.

As a representative of the rural sector, I should add that there is also a real worry—as there is in manufacturing; in our consultancy services; in health, education and all of those other tertiary sectors—that when we give funds to international aid organisations a greater effort needs to be made by this Government to ensure that we are in there and available to get a fair share of the contracts that are issued.

In my own area, in Armidale for example, a number of outstanding agricultural consultants have had a degree of work from many of these international agencies. After talking to them—I met many of them undertaking their tasks in countries around the world—it seems to me that we have really gone overboard in trying to ensure that everybody is represented and we have not done enough to ensure that the people who can best do the job are allowed to get on with the job. I think they are too top-heavy by far in administrative support. The assessment of individual projects seems to me to be based more on a product of a heart on the sleeve attitude than on a hard economic approach. I think it is all too important at a time when we are getting stretched for cash and all of us would like to see a fair return for the Australian dollar spent in overseas aid.

I do not oppose the measure; I express my concern. I regret that the Government has thought so little of the importance of the measure that it did not bother to bring a Minister who is responsible in the field into the House. I think it is a great pity that, in the consideration of serious projects that involve a great deal of concern for average Australian taxpayers, we are given so little information. At the very best, all we are told is that some of those projects were generally successful. It is not good enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse the reservations and concerns of the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). I have been following these agencies for eight years now. I inform the right honourable member that never over those eight or nine years that I have actively participated in debates in this place has the Government ever been represented when the Bill is being debated by the relevant Minister. Nothing is different tonight.

PARA.TAB: The Asian Development Fund Bill authorises the contribution of $350m to the Asian Development Fund, the ADF. The ADF is the concessional lending arm of the Asian Development Bank, the ADB, similar to the World Bank's International Development Association, the IDA. The bank provides development assistance to the poorest developing countries in the Asia-Pacific region. In the context of an Australian aid budget that has been declining in real terms, the Government has sought to limit Australia's contribution to 6.5 per cent of the total of the fifth replenishment of the fund. This means that Australia will remain the second largest donor in the region to the fund, after Japan, and the fourth largest donor overall. However, it also means that an increasing proportion of Australia's official development assistance will be channelled through multilateral development banks at the expense of direct bilateral assistance.

According to the second reading speech of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Martin), the share of the overseas aid program going to international financial institutions could rise by over 18 per cent by 1994-95, compared with a share of around 8 per cent in the mid-1980s. Contributions to the ADF are one of the single largest items in Australia's foreign aid program. This is clearly an unsatisfactory state of affairs, as the Government appears to have acknowledged in the Parliamentary Secretary's second reading speech. However, having acknowledged the problem, the Government has not acted upon it by slashing Australia's contribution to the ADF or to any of other international financial institutions to which we regularly contribute. The reason for this is fairly clear. The Government does not want to compromise Australia's position of influence within the Asian Development Bank, which is considerably greater than the almost non-existent role that we play in other international financial institutions.

I suggest that Australia's contribution to, and participation in, the ADB is not worth while and should be scaled down accordingly. I would like to do this by challenging some of the more absurd claims made by the Parliamentary Secretary in his second reading speech about the Asian Development Fund. The Parliamentary Secretary began with the claim that `participation in the ADF has been an efficient means of achieving aid delivery to the poorest countries of the Asia-Pacific region' and that the ADB complements our bilateral aid in the South Pacific. I think it is now well established that the most efficient way of delivering aid, whether comprised of official or unofficial funds, is through many of the non-government organisations, the NGOs.

The next most efficient means of foreign aid delivery is bilateral aid, although there are a host of difficulties with such official development assistance, which I will come to later. But by far the least efficient means of foreign aid delivery is through multilateral development banks.

I want to make a number of criticisms of foreign aid delivered in this way. It should be noted, however, that many of these criticisms are equally applicable to bilateral development assistance at a government to government level. What makes bilateral aid preferable to multilateral aid is that Australia exercises a greater degree of control over these funds. Moreover, such bilateral aid is not consumed by the bloated bureaucracies of the multilateral development banks that seem too often to put their own interests ahead of those of aid recipients.

As I hope to make apparent, these banks become ends in themselves and Australia has been caught in this trap in its agreement to such a large contribution to the latest replenishment. If Australia is to have a foreign aid budget, it should be channelled through NGOs to the greatest extent possible. Domestically, we have come to realise that the provision of welfare, whether funded by government or privately, is usually best done through private sector voluntary agencies. We need to come to the same realisation in the case of official foreign development assistance.

The Government, through the Parliamentary Secretary, claims that the ADB `has become a major catalyst in promoting the development of the most populous and fast growing region in the world today', thereby implying that the massive economic growth in our region is attributable in some measure to the ADB. A moment's reflection should make it readily apparent that the massive economic growth in our region is due principally to private domestic capital formation and foreign direct investment from private sector sources. The significance of this is that it is frequently argued that foreign aid is essential to capital formation which, in turn, is essential to wealth creation. In fact, capital formation is the result of economic growth, not its precursor.

The economic development of the West was not underpinned by foreign aid, nor has the bulk of the economic development in our region owed itself to foreign aid. In fact, Asian-Pacific governments and businesses can readily borrow funds, both domestically and internationally, from private sector sources, assuming always that the projects for which they are seeking support are productive and the country concerned does not have an overly restricted foreign investment regime.

The contribution of the concessional finance that is disbursed by the ADF to the economic development of our region is thus limited to the savings made by borrowing from the ADF, rather than from private sector sources, with the difference being paid for by Western taxpayers. The contribution of such foreign aid to economic development is therefore minimal. Moreover, it may well be that these savings do not offset the costs involved by some of this capital being lost to the bureaucracies involved in administering the donor's aid program, as well as by the recipient government's administrative excesses. Many, even most, of the recipient governments to which we dispense foreign aid in this way are notorious for the misallocation of these funds.

We are told that we are about to face a world capital shortage which will make the development task of developing countries more difficult. But, at the same time, Western governments preside over the misallocation of billions of dollars annually to multilateral development banks and bilateral aid programs forcing up the cost of private capital to developing countries. Any benefits arising from the concessional lending of bodies, such as ADF, are largely illusory.

Private investors in developing countries pay for such concessional lending through higher borrowing costs, and Western taxpayers foot the bill for concessional lending by Western governments and multilateral agencies. The net effect is a transfer of wealth from Western taxpayers to aid bureaucracies in recipient and donor countries, as well as bureaucracies of the international financial institutions. The ADB is no exception to these bureaucratic excesses.

According to an article written for Triple A magazine a few years ago, `The lifestyle for ADB staff is good; they are seen locally as the fat cats, earning tax-free salaries in US dollars, driving smart cars—the bank has more than 300 Mercedes—which are out of the car park by 5 p.m'. The article quotes another observer as saying, `The ADB offers a nice life for people who are not necessarily geniuses'.

Creating more powerful governments and aid bureaucracies is the end result of foreign aid, with the possible exception of those official funds channelled through NGOs. Needless to say, many of these recipient governments follow policies entirely antithetical to economic development. While in the Western world we are attempting to dispense with the dead hand of government in our lives, in the case of the developing world we are actively promoting it. An excellent example of this is found in the case of the ADB's grants to the People's Republic of China.

Late last year the ADB approved a technical assistance grant of $600,000 to the People's Republic of China to `strengthen the State Planning Commission' of that country. According to the bank, `The main objective of the technical assistance is to strengthen the institutional capabilities of the State Planning Commission in indirect management of the national economy, through macro-economic planning, coordination, supervision and regulation'. So much for promoting the free market.

This was only one of a number of ADB grants to foreign states regulatory authorities in the centrally planned economies of China, Laos and Vietnam over the past 12 months or so. How the strengthening of state regulatory authorities in centrally planned economies is designed to foster economic development in the Asia-Pacific region escapes me entirely.

The Parliamentary Secretary noted that `development of the private sector is also a major policy aim of the bank and the ADF'. This is now a common line spun by international financial institutions, by which they pay lip-service to the market, but with little of the substance in terms of their lending practices. Again, there is a double standard in comparison with our own practices domestically. In Australia, government support of the private sector is known as `picking winners' and is rightly frowned upon, yet we actively promote this same process in developing countries.

If we were really interested in the development of the private sector in developing countries, we would facilitate its access to foreign direct investment from private sources by having the ADB and other international financial institutions pull out of international capital markets. If anything, concessional lending by the ADB encourages the recipient countries to maintain restrictive foreign investment regimes so that their governments can maintain control of the bulk of the foreign investment activities in their countries and obtain investment on concessional terms.

It is being said that the shortage of capital is the main justification for foreign aid, yet this very aid helps to ensure these capital shortages. Peter Bauer, a leading critic of foreign aid, has rightly observed: `It diminishes the people of the Third World to suggest that, although they crave for material progress, unlike the West they cannot achieve it without external subsidies'. It does diminish those people.

Of course, a major goal of the ADF is poverty alleviation rather than economic development as such. This is a worthy goal, but the ADF pursues it in a counterproductive way. The first thing to note is that ADF lending is aimed at the poorest countries. Generally speaking, only countries with a GNP per capita under $US860 are eligible for ADF funds. In this way, lending by the likes of the ADF and the International Development Agency actually serves to reward poverty in developing countries.

ADF assistance to governments in developing countries ignores the fact that it is often those very same governments that are responsible for the impoverished state of their people. While lending to NGOs is an effective way of bypassing the destructive policies of these governments, lending to the governments themselves is effectively a pat on the back for their policies and may even assist them in pursuing those policies.

It is difficult to conceive how official development assistance can help alleviate poverty in countries with governments that systematically impoverish their people in the quest for political and economic control. These governments also often maintain large military establishments, further underlining their own lack of commitment to poverty alleviation. Official development assistance should follow political and economic liberalisation rather than precede it, if it is to have any hope of achieving meaningful poverty alleviation.

In the case of eastern Europe, Western governments have mostly ensured that foreign aid has followed rather than preceded economic and political liberalisation, although even here it could be said that we have been too forthcoming, which is one of the main criticisms that has been made of the ADB's cousin, the European Bank For Reconstruction and Development. But in the case of both the IDA and the ADF, only the weakest and most inconsequential reforms are required to secure access to funds.

At the ADF6 negotiations, Australia argued for Vietnam and China to be given access to ADF funds. It would be difficult to argue that either of those countries is sufficiently committed to economic and political liberalisation to justify the resumption of ADF assistance. Fortunately, a consensus could not be reached on admitting China, and Vietnam is still excluded from receiving funds. It would appear that one of the motivations behind granting access to China and India is the need to find new recipients of ADF funds. Economic growth in the region has been so strong that there is a decreasing demand for ADF funds generally, and project lending in particular.

However, the ADF continues to expand its lending activities, at the expense of the quality of its lending program. Indeed, the ADB has gone so far as to consider granting full membership to the former Soviet republics of Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan and other Commonwealth of Independent States members in central Asia, on the grounds of some weak link to the Asia-Pacific region, and despite the fact that these countries will be eligible for EBRD lending.

The bank needs to move towards providing assistance for the development of regional capital markets and providing governments with advice on such issues as privatisation and deregulation rather than continuing with the expansion of unnecessary project lending. Such moves are being resisted by the management of the bank, since a new focus for its activities would require new skills, which would in turn require staff changes.

The decline in the quality of ADF lending has led to accusations of project assessments being falsified by ADB staff to show returns where none in fact exist. The Parliamentary Secretary put forward two particularly silly arguments in favour of our continuing subvention of the ADF. The first is that, `As a major shareholder of the bank, Australia plays a significant role in formulating the bank's policies'. It is true that Australia plays a far more prominent role in the ADF than in other multilateral development banks where the same argument is used, but with very little truth. It should be obvious that the argument is an entirely circular one. It is silly to argue that we should contribute to the bank because this then allows us to play a greater role in the bank—one naturally follows from the other. Playing a role in the bank is entirely incidental to the issue of whether and to what extent we should be contributing funds at all, which is surely the more important question.

It is in this way that the ADB and bodies like it become ends in themselves rather than the means to achieve what should be the carefully considered goal of maximising the value of our foreign aid expenditures. It is pointless boasting about our role in the ADB if that institution is a fundamentally inferior way of delivering aid. To quote Peter Bauer once again:

SPEECH.PARA: Foreign aid consists of inter-governmental wealth transfers. To describe these transfers as development aid disarms criticism, obscures issues and prejudges results. It has helped bring about an axiomatic support for this policy.

The other particularly silly argument put forward by the Parliamentary Secretary was that `the ADB provides a significant source of procurement for Australian business'. Australian goods and services bought with our official development assistance funds are simply given away by the Australian Government, and constitute a transfer from Australian taxpayers to the Australian businesses which benefit from this procurement. We are hardly better off as a result of that process. In fact, we are worse off to the extent that not all foreign aid is returned to Australia in this way.

PARA.TAB: The Parliamentary Secretary is really saying that we should be grateful for any of the funds that come back our way, even if they do go towards lining the pockets of select Australian businesses in a rather arbitrary way. Any benefits Australian business may derive from our foreign aid program are purely incidental to the question of whether such assistance should be provided at all, and ignores the costs involved in providing such assistance which, by definition, must outweigh any such incidental benefits. With such a high and increasing proportion of Australia's official development assistance being chewed up by the multilateral development banks, Australia should conduct a detailed examination of its role in these and other international financial institutions. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Speeches such as the speech just delivered by the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) do this Parliament proud. It was an extremely interesting and well considered speech. People may or may not agree with it all, but it certainly was a very thoughtful contribution to the debate. I am only sorry that, when people do talk about the activities of the Federal Parliament, they hear much more about the ravings and rantings of Jack Lang and others who, throughout history, have been expelled from the Australian Labor Party, rather than the very valuable contributions such as the one we have heard from the honourable member for Curtin.

PARA.TAB: As every other speaker in the debate has said, the Asian Development Fund Bill authorises a contribution of $350m to the fifth replenishment of the Asian Development Fund, ADF6, which will be used to provide loans on soft terms to qualifying Asian Development Bank member states. The Bill, together with previous commitments to the international financial institutions, will add to the already substantial proportion of the global aid program of Australia committed to IFIs, as they are sometimes called—international financial institutions—in the years from 1992-93 onwards.

In the case of the ADF, the projection in the Bill does not show substantial draw downs until 1996-97. Interestingly, the share of ADF6 taken by Australia is lower than ADF5, reflecting both the large existing commitments by Australia to the World Bank and Australia's economic circumstances and its prospects. As others have said in this debate, we on this side of the chamber do not oppose this Bill but we make the point that the level of support Australia can give must be constrained by its own economic circumstances and that, as I have mentioned, is why our share of ADF6 is lower than our share of ADF5.

The honourable member for Curtin made the point that an increasing proportion of our global aid budget is going to development banks at the expense of bilateral and other multilateral aid programs. That comment demonstrates that this is a difficult issue of balance to which we have to give a great deal of thought. I am glad that the commitment in this case goes to the ADF, a bank within our own region, because we on this side of the House very strongly hold the view that a greater proportion of Australia's aid Budget should be directed to our own region rather than to other parts of the world.

It is interesting to reflect, on the one hand, on the rhetoric we have had from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in recent weeks about the need for Australia to concentrate on its own region and to integrate more successfully within its own region and, on the other hand, on the fact that through the life of the Hawke-Keating Government the focus of the Government's aid effort has been as much extra-regional as intra-regional. The debate that we had some years ago about aid, for example, to the southern African states outside South Africa reflected the concern on our side of the House that we were not putting enough emphasis on our own region. For the Labor Party to have put so much emphasis on aid in parts of the world outside our region and to try to take on the weighty responsibilities of resolving problems in southern Africa and in Central America does not sit comfortably with the latest hot wind coming from the other side of the House on the need for regional integration.

The Bill really raises the broader question of the different methods which can be used to obtain economic growth in developing countries which desperately need to get out of the cycle of poverty and achieve significant rates of growth. I think all of us in this Parliament are very committed to helping developing countries in our region—and of course outside our region—to achieve greater rates of growth where they are struggling, where they have zero growth or, in some cases, even less than that. But just providing aid in one form or another is not going to be the fundamental solution to the economic problems of those countries.

I think that too much of the debate in this country—what used to be described as the North-South debate—focuses on the need to provide increasing quantities of aid to try to resolve development problems in developing countries rather than on a range of other much more important methods which can be used to encourage growth. This is one of my last speeches as the shadow Minister for trade, so I really want to take the opportunity to make this point. I believe fundamentally that the greatest prospect of achieving economic growth in developing countries is to open the markets of the world generally to liberalise international trade so that those countries have the opportunity to find markets.

It strikes me as one of the cruelest post-war ironies that First World countries, the Europeans in particular, continue with the policies of agricultural protectionism to the extent that they ban altogether imports of many agricultural products from countries whose very survival and any prospect of economic growth is going to depend on gaining access for raw materials and agricultural products which they have available to them. I really think that is one of the cruelest ironies of the post Second World War world.

It is a great shame that in the general debate on development and these sorts of issues, such as the role of development banks, and in the broader debate about international trade, the case for developing countries is one that is so seldom put. It used to be part of the international agenda a decade or so ago when developing countries were arguing, admittedly not always very consistently, for something that used to be described as the new international economic order, and they operated as what was called the group of 77. But that agenda has just disappeared from international economic debate, very much to the convenience of the European Community, let me say, and significantly at the expense of developing countries, particularly those which are agriculturally dependent.

It is interesting to have a look at some of the data here. The World Bank has estimated that agriculture accounts for about 35 per cent of the gross domestic product for low-income developing countries, and between 10 and 15 per cent for middle-income developing countries. Food production on average employs up to 70 per cent of the work forces of low-income developing countries. It is really worth reflecting on that.

In 1965 agriculture accounted for 17 per cent of the GDP, on average, of the world's most indebted nations but it fell to 10 per cent in 1988. That happened not because people have stopped eating but because there is less incentive or capacity to produce food domestically. There is less incentive to do so because so many of those countries have simply been crowded out of international markets. So much of the aid program and so much of the work and contribution of development banks, such as the Asian Development Bank that we are debating this evening, are simply compensation for the utterly immoral agricultural protectionist policies of the European Community, to the largest extent, and some countries over and above the European Community. That is a case we need to argue in Australia. The Cairns Group needs to argue and the developing countries themselves need to argue much more vehemently than they have done in years gone by.

I am not claiming that a lack of access to international markets is the only reason why a lot of developing countries, including developing countries in our own region, suffer from starvation and famine and very substantial humanitarian problems of that kind. That is not the case. In many instances, the problems relate to the lack of facilities to distribute food efficiently and also to the domestic economic policies of many developing countries. That has been particularly true in post-colonial Africa, but it has also been true in some of the developing countries in our own region.

Their capacity to improve the quality of their agricultural production and to upgrade the productivity of crops, livestock and so on, has been inhibited in many cases by land distribution issues. The fact that governments have decided to nationalise land and that collectives have been created in order to administer land, rather than land being owned by individuals and run on traditional capitalist private enterprise principles, is one of the reasons that those countries have enormous economic difficulties. It is a part of the debate which we do not hear very much about any more today and that is a very great shame.

I was glad to hear the honourable member for Curtin in his interesting speech refer to the work of Professor Peter Bauer, who used to be at the London School of Economics. Peter Bauer was one of the very few and great advocates of the cause of liberalising international trade and reforming domestic economic policies, providing for private ownership of land and competition to ensure that those countries worked their way out of their poverty. The first great aspect of achieving growth in developing countries lies in those two areas.

I am not walking away from the fact that development banks, such as the Asian Development Bank, and the Asian Development Fund and bilateral and multilateral aid of other forms, can also play a very important part in helping countries establish the appropriate economic structure. Again, people will talk a lot about assistance with infrastructure, which is part of the work that the Asian Development Bank funds, but it is important that developed countries provide assistance in a lot of less tangible ways. For example, developed countries can assist developing countries in constructing efficient, modern taxation systems. One very good illustration is the International Monetary Fund and the OECD which have urged developing countries around the world to introduce an indirect tax system known as a goods and services tax. Those sorts of organisations and developed countries which have introduced modern indirect tax systems should be able to assist developing countries in setting up those systems. A lot of that work has been done.

It is true that a growing proportion of developing countries, as well as just about all developed countries, have a goods and services tax system. A lot of assistance has been given by developed countries to help establish that system. They are not only establishing a proper and modern indirect tax system but are also assisting developing countries with establishing proper methods of accounting for government and private enterprise, and ensuring that there is a proper structure for competition policy within those countries as well. Then those countries can turn their backs on the old monopoly business situation which has characterised so many of them and move towards a competitive marketplace which, in turn, will create prosperity for consumers as well as producers and employees of those businesses.

If we look at a country like the Philippines, we will see that there are a range of reasons why that country has substantial economic difficulties. Many of them relate to some of the issues I have already raised in this debate. One reason is a lack of competition within that country. The sugar producers—dare I mention sugar; there has been a lot of talk about sugar—
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Dare, dare.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will dare to mention sugar.
—There are no Queensland Nationals here, so go ahead.

—No; but there are some Queensland Labor Party members not far away. We all know how they feel about the Government's policies on sugar. They are not sitting, with their knives drawn, behind the honourable member who interjected, but they are in their offices sharpening them.

PARA.TAB: Let me just make the point that in the Philippines the refineries and, in particular, the sugar mills tend to be owned by a very small handful of oligopolists who exploit oligopoly rents at the expense of not only consumers of that product but also an efficient industry. I think that is profoundly regrettable. Again, my point is that developed countries, in assisting developing countries, can help them establish competitive industries and break away from the old style—usually left wing driven, but not exclusively—monopolies and oligopolies that have characterised those countries.

That brings me to the issue of straight-out aid and the sort of assistance that the Asian Development Bank can provide. The Asian Development Bank lent about $9 billion in the last fiscal year, and others have described how that money was lent. I think that can be a very effective form of aid. As I mentioned earlier, there is no doubt that that sort of assistance can help with the creation of appropriate infrastructure, giving those countries an opportunity to establish a structure for a more modern economy.

I must say it is important that, since soft loans are being provided in these cases—certainly as far as this legislation is concerned—those loans must go into investments which will yield a net return. Too often, in terms of aid policy, soft loan lending and, indeed, finance that comes from taxpayers' money in a range of other areas, that investment goes into projects which offer, if you like, a gross benefit.

It is perfectly clear that if a new road or whatever is built, some benefit comes from that. It is rather like the argument about the Alice Springs to Darwin railway. There is no doubt that if the railway were built, there would be a gross benefit from it. However, the question that must always be asked is not whether there is a gross benefit, but whether there is a net benefit and whether the costs really make that investment worth while or whether it would have been better to have put that money into some other sort of investment which would have yielded a bigger return.

I appreciate, particularly with public sector infrastructure investment, that it is very hard to measure the net benefit or disbenefit that comes from that investment. Where money, albeit a soft loan, is provided by a bank, I suppose it is implicit that there will be at least some significant return because over time that loan has to be repaid. However, if it is a soft loan, there is clearly an element of subsidy and the net benefit, as a result of that, is all the harder to measure.
