If honourable members really want an illustration of how to waste resources, not just in developed countries but, as the tone of my whole speech suggests, in developing countries, they should invest in just about anything that politicians happen to think is pretty or might help them to get re-elected and worry only about the gross benefits, not the net benefits.

I have noticed that nowadays people talk with great disdain about economic rationalism. People who criticise economic rationalism, by their own definition, are economic irrationalists. They measure only the gross benefits and never look to see whether there is a net benefit at all. That is the difference between an economic irrationalist and an economic rationalist.

If we want to help developing countries, there is no point doing things which are irrational. There is no point pouring money in—however we pour it in—in a way that achieves nothing but a net cost, both to the country that is providing the assistance and, maybe in the longer term, to the recipient of that aid.

Let me finish on the point of humanitarian aid. Right at the beginning of this speech, I said that once money allocated to a development bank, such as the Asian Development Bank, is drawn down out of an aid budget, it is ultimately spent on that project rather than on other forms of aid. That has to be weighed up against what I think is the most valuable and important type of aid: humanitarian aid. When individuals within a country simply cannot obtain sustenance, we have a humanitarian responsibility to give those people assistance. I reckon that I speak on behalf of all 17 million people in this country when I say that none of us would want to deny humanitarian assistance to people in countries which are in very real need.

Let us ensure that these development banks—and indeed other forms of assistance—provide this assistance not as humanitarian aid but as broader economic aid on the basis of net benefits, not on the basis of gross benefits and handouts. Let us also ensure that, in future, the debate on assistance to developing countries is raised to a new level, which includes a debate about liberalising international trade and ensuring that domestic economic policies in developing countries are of assistance to the people within those countries, not just to monopolists and special interest groups.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Asian Development Fund Bill is to authorise a contribution of $350m towards the fifth replenishment of the Asian Development Fund. I think it was the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Martin), who is at the table, who told us during his second reading speech that the contributions to the ADF was one of the largest single items in Australia's official development cooperation program. As such, the size of the payments can have a significant impact on other components of the program.

PARA.TAB: It is perhaps worth briefly reminding the House what the Asian Development Fund is all about. The ADF is the concessional lending arm of the Asian Development Bank. The ADB has—I have read various numbers ranging from 47 to just over 50—around 50 member countries from the Asia-Pacific region as well as from western Europe and North America.

The ADB really has four functions: firstly, to make loans to, and equity investments in, developing country members of the bank; secondly, to provide technical assistance for development projects and programs; thirdly, to promote investment of public and private capital for development purposes; and, fourthly, to assist in the coordination of development policies and plans of member countries.

Loans from the ADF are available only to the least developed members of the bank at highly concessional rates. ADF loans are interest free, but carry a one per cent per annum service charge. Repayment periods range from 35 to 40 years. Other loans from the bank come from its ordinary capital resources and all developing member countries are eligible. The interest rate for OCR loans is currently 6.58 per cent.

The ADF is funded through the bank's special funds. Special funds come mainly from contributions made by member countries. The special funds for the ADF have been replenished five times since the establishment of the ADF in 1973, and the sixth replenishment this year will total some $US4.2 billion.

I think the case for humanitarian assistance is clear and I think the case for our assistance is clear. For economic and environmental reasons, it is important that Australia support the activities of the ADF to provide assistance to the poorer developing countries. It is not done just to make us feel warm and comfortable; it is really done for very practical, if not hard-headed, reasons.

Perhaps when we talk about the Asian area a lot of thinking is going on in Australia about `think Australia', and about the importance to Australia of Asia and our links to it at the present time. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has, of course, just come back from an overseas trip to Asia. In the Fightback program, which the coalition put forward before Christmas, there is significant reference to our future needing to be tied in with Asia. The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has made many trips to Asia in the last couple of years.

Clearly, as a nation we are changing our emphasis. Having gone from a dependence on Europe to a heavy dependence on the United States, we are now increasingly changing our direction towards Asia. Perhaps a lot of that thinking tends to be in terms of a warm glow about the opportunities. It is a warm glow about: `It's going to be the second biggest retail market in the world in the next 10 or 15 years' and, `Look at those wonderful commercial opportunities. Look at the five Asian tigers. Look at the way that Japan has developed economically and how powerful it is'. Those are all very true statements, but I think there are also very real concerns about what is going to go on in Asia in the next few years. If those concerns are not addressed, they are not just going to be disastrous for the people of Asian countries but they are going to rebound on us as well.

It is perhaps a sobering thought to remember that there are two billion very poor people in this world and another four billion in the poor category—that is six billion who are officially deemed to be poor or very poor—and 70 per cent of that number is in Asian countries. In the 1990s, the cities of Asia will grow by a further 500 million people. That is equivalent to the population of the United States and Europe combined. That growing population, of course, is not always affluent. In fact, the vast majority are poor people—they are not the rich ones—and so they bring a lot of problems with them in terms of sheer numbers.

For a start, the pressure on food production is quite horrendous, particularly when one looks at things like rice, which is the staple diet in many of the countries in Asia. There are a lot of problems with producing rice these days. In many of the intensive care areas one will see that, in fact, productivity is going backwards, for reasons that are not well understood, and a lot of research work is having to be undertaken at the moment.

The huge cities that are developing, of course, are gobbling up good agricultural land. The increased population is putting pressure on health services and on housing and education needs. There is often political instability. The over farming of much of the arable land is causing increased salinity and alkalinity. There is, as I said before, a noticeable decline in rice yield in intensive farm areas.

Some of that, if not all of that, often seems very remote to people here in Australia. But I put it to the House that, if there is no solution to many of those problems, there will be an explosion in economic and political terms onto the rest of the world. It will be bad for us in an investment sense, but it will also generate environmental and political refugees who will start to look in our direction.

My colleague the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), who spoke before me and who should be congratulated on his recent elevation to the shadow Cabinet, made the point about the United States-Europe trade wars. I will not go into that again, but I think it is a significant factor that we should not overlook. Of course, as many of these countries do maintain their existing poverty or even get poorer, particularly in the rural areas, it drives people into the large cities which worsens the problems of overcrowding, living space, services and so on.

It is very interesting that, just this week in the Australian newspaper, Julian Cribb is doing a series on the global food crisis. Yesterday he wrote a very effective article, I thought, in terms of Asia in particular and I would commend it to the House.

It is for the sorts of reasons that I have mentioned that the coalition has said very clearly in its Fightback! document that our aid program will be structured, taking into account a number of criteria. The program will be concentrated within our own area, the Asia-Pacific region, which reflects our foreign policy and trade priorities. There will be increased emphasis on alleviating poverty and on the delivery of services through non-government organisations. Preference will be given to bilateral aid and the provision of Australian goods and services. Aid will not be applied in ways which support repressive governments or given to those with excessive military expenditure.

The bottom line of all of that is that we need to be stronger economically to be able to make a bigger contribution, and the previous speaker, the honourable member for Mayo, dwelt on that at some length. We need to put our aid where we can influence some of the decisions to ensure that it does actually the good that we want it to do.

Of course, Australia is a very attractive country and has a good climate, although in Canberra it is slightly invigorating at the present time. We have plenty of space and a good standard of living. For many migrants this is a country that has `opportunity'. I speak as a migrant. I came here as a migrant, as many others have, and it is a tremendous country of opportunity. At the moment we might be arguing about our immigration levels, but if there are problems in Asia on an ongoing basis on a large scale, there will be pressure there to look in our direction. It is in Australia's self-interest to make sure that Asia avoids the catastrophe scenario. If Asia does well, then we will gain; but if it has a lot of problems and goes downhill, then inevitably we will lose.

The money for the Asian Development Fund must be committed. Australia has a history of support. Although historically that fund has had a number of management and accountability problems, those are gradually being addressed. There have also been control problems and issues about where the funds are directed. Perhaps there has been an increasing shift in emphasis over the years in the type of project being undertaken. For example, I understand that there is an increasing importance on the environment, women in development and poverty alleviation in the assessment of projects. Like all organisations, it does have its inefficiencies. We should support it, but we need to look more critically at bilateral aid as well.

We need to look not only at better targeting in a country sense, or which country we pick, but also at the type of project and method of delivery. We should consider not only the social or short term economic facts but also some of the longer term factors that are relevant in terms of giving aid. For example, earlier I was talking about the problems with food, saying that the rice yield in intensively cultivated areas is going down. It seems to me that some of our aid needs to be given in technical assistance to investigate some of those problems that can have widespread long term benefits.

A few weeks ago I tabled in this place the report of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology into genetic engineering. It seems to me that Australia has growing expertise and abilities in this area and we can look at giving some real practical aid—not only dollars but real skills—to help our neighbours to the north with some of those problems. There are many outstanding features and discoveries in the agricultural field that are on the way that I am sure will be very useful.

I served in the forces in Asia more than 30 years ago and saw some of the basic lifestyles enjoyed—if that is the word—by many of the people in the Asian countries at that time. Looking at it through European eyes, we probably took the view that many of the Asian countries had lots of character and local colour. However, it really was not so good for the indigenous people at all. That is not necessarily the case in many of those countries now and many have advanced tremendously. Nevertheless, there are far too many people who are living in really appalling circumstances because of the increasing population. Pressures are applied simply through better communications: however poor a country is, people have television screens; they have a window to the outside world to see how good it can be. Therefore, they are all looking for a better standard of living and their expectations are raised. Lifting themselves out of poverty—and often ignorance, unfortunately—is obviously very difficult and our help is needed. Careful targeting is required. We have a responsibility to provide that help because it is in our interests as well.

In closing, I will take a few minutes to remind honourable members of the size and scope of the problem that is on the nation's doorstep. Bangladesh, a country which I think we all understand is riven by natural disasters and appalling poverty, has a population in excess of 100 million people. China has over one billion people. We are all aware of such things as the political problems, the communist influence and whether it will crack, the impact of what is going to happen to Hong Kong, and the economic development. It has tremendous problems. Some of its remoter regions are still living in the Middle Ages.

India, with its caste system and endemic poverty in so many areas, has over 800 million people. Indonesia, our nearest neighbour, has over 180 million people spread over many islands over a two million square kilometre area. The logistics of getting around that area are frightening. Pakistan, which is surrounded by countries either at war or on the verge of war, has over 100 million people. How does it improve its economic lot in that situation?

The Philippines, where I suggest corruption is reasonably endemic and political instability is never far from the surface, has over 60 million people. Then we have the beautiful little island of Sri Lanka, which has been torn asunder by civil war. It has a small population—not quite 20 million people—but it is still a heck of a lot more than Australia's population. Thailand has 60 million people. Perhaps it is relevant to mention Thailand, because at the moment we are recalling the days of the Burma-Thailand railway in another sense and from another time.

I looked up some figures for the amount of annual income per person for 1989 in Australia, which were the latest figures I could get. The average income per head is just over $15,000 in this country. The annual per head income in India is $301. That is 2 per cent of what it is here. In Sri Lanka it is $390 per head for a whole year. That is 2 1/2 per cent of our figure. In Indonesia it is $473. That is just 3 per cent of our figure. In Thailand, people do very well. The figure is $1,130. That is still only 7 1/2 per cent of what we get in Australia.

In the middle of the worst recession in 60 years in this country, those figures still make us look pretty good and remind us of our responsibilities to help our less fortunate neighbours. It is a daunting picture. The Asian Development Fund is one mechanism for helping. I commend it to the House. Having approved it, I think it is important that we remember that we should not sleep easy in our beds, because the problems of Asia are only just beginning.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MARTIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank all the participants in this debate this afternoon and this evening: the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar), the honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie), the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), and the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent), from the Opposition side, and those three amigos from Queensland, the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice), the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler), and the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), from the Government side. Each of them made a contribution worthy of some comment, principally for what they had to say, and also in terms of providing the opportunity to clarify one or two points.

PARA.TAB: Before going to that, I will briefly reiterate the main benefits arising from Australia's contribution to the Asian Development Fund, because I think they got lost in some of the contributions this evening. Firstly, the Asian Development Bank is the largest regional multinational agency delivering concessional finance to the poorest countries in the Asia-Pacific area. Australia, as the fourth largest donor and the second largest regional donor, has been able to have a significant influence on the activities of the bank in a number of important areas. I think that is quite significant. For example, the bank is now playing a much larger role in the Pacific island countries, our neighbours in this region—as has been stated by a number of honourable members on the other side—which we are so concerned about. The bank plays a lead role in aid coordination and policy dialogue.

Secondly, contributing to the ADF complements the rest of our development cooperation programs. The bank has become involved in a number of areas where we have a limited capacity under the bilateral program. It can implement much larger infrastructure projects as well as negotiate policy changes as a condition for the approval of the loans. Again, I think that is appropriate. It can provide loans in sectors that Australia would support but where we do not have a comparative advantage. I think those two very important points need to be made. However, there are others.

The ADB supports programs in a number of very poor Asian countries where we do not have a significant bilateral program. There was conjecture about bilateral versus multilateral programming and so on; I use by way of example Bangladesh and Pakistan. This is an effective means of achieving our humanitarian objectives, and I am sure no-one in this House would object to that. The proposed contribution, in fact, represents an appropriate balance between maintaining a significant influence in the bank and efficiently achieving the priorities of Australia's bilateral aid programs.

As I indicated, a number of comments were made by honourable members on both sides of this House and I would briefly like to touch on those. The three Government members, of course, gave a fairly clear and erudite explanation as to the reasons behind the passage of this legislation this evening. They clearly also demonstrated their understanding of the aid program and the dimension of the aid difficulties facing Australia, but so, too, did a number of the honourable members from the Opposition and I think that shows the degree to which this issue enjoys bipartisan support.

There were some misunderstandings, and I would very briefly like to go to those in summing up this Bill tonight. Firstly, in respect of replenishment sizes, the honourable member for Warringah spoke at some length about the fact that the replenishment sizes were only just maintaining the same level of real lending. I would like to point out that, with great respect to the honourable gentleman, he is somewhat mistaken. There has recently been a change in policy by the ADB and the board of directors agreed that repayments from existing loans could be used to finance new loans. In the past, of course, these repayments were accumulated. These funds are now drawn down for new loans and the ADF has an additional $US1.5 billion available for new commitments plus the $US4.2 billion funded by donors under the ADF6 replenishment.

The honourable member for Warringah was also somewhat critical about the reporting of the ADB project performance. In fact, again, he is mistaken because the ADB has changed its policy with regard to evaluation activities and will now have a more comprehensive coverage of all its projects and programs—and I am sure honourable members on both sides of the House will find that an appropriate change in policy. The bank's post-evaluation system has been very useful in terms of identifying the reasons for past failures. In particular, it appears that projects in new sectors with new executing agencies have more problems than other projects. The honourable member, in fact, commenced his speech by commending the change in the sectoral focus of the ADF lending. It is, therefore, only reasonable to expect that there may be an initial decline in performance while both the ADB and the recipient agencies gain the necessary experience to implement projects very successfully.

The honourable member was also somewhat critical about the reporting on the performance of structural adjustment program loans. I would like to clarify the situation for his benefit. The bank's program lending only began in 1977 with fairly modest aims. Given that evaluations can only be meaningfully assessed some time after the completion of the project, there is not a great number of projects to draw on. Nevertheless, of the first nine program loans approved, six were rated as generally successful and the other three were rated as partially successful.

Furthermore, a key lesson that is coming out of evaluating program loans is that policy reforms must have broad based support and commitment from within the country itself. To achieve lasting change and to sustain the desired policy directions, a long term continuing commitment by the bank through a series of programs may be required rather than just a single operation.

Finally, the honourable member for Warringah was somewhat critical about the bank's approach to environmental concerns and the protection of its projects. The bank has recognised that its programs should reflect careful environmental planning and management, something which, I think, in this day and age, all members of this House should support. Environmental policy framework was in fact adopted in 1986.

A range of measures have now been enacted including: the identification of high priority environmental projects, environmental impact assessment statements on projects with significant environmental impacts themselves and, of course, enhancement of environmental planning capabilities in recipient countries. All those measures represent a change in the way in which the bank approaches this particular issue. Unfortunately, it was an issue with which the honourable member for Warringah was seemingly not conversant.

The right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) commenced his contribution by saying that the Minister responsible for this legislation was not in the House. As the Parliamentary Secretary responsible for introducing the second reading speech, I inform him that I listened very carefully and watched every sentence pass his lips on the television while I was preparing to come to the chamber tonight. I have also sat in on the other contributions, so I am fully apprised of what he had to say.

The right honourable member was supportive of the Bill but expressed a number of concerns. He was critical of the Government for not taking the House seriously, as I have mentioned. I think we have dealt with that particular issue. He was also critical of the bank's assessment categories labelled `generally successful', `partially successful' and `unsuccessful'. He wondered what each of those categories meant. The categories are based on calculated economic internal rates of return and use a number of indicators in this assessment and, therefore, provide an appropriate way in which to assess the level of contribution and the way in which the projects are being successful.

The right honourable member for New England was critical of just about every aspect of the aid program. He was into multilateral aid and bilateral aid. I am not sure whether he could quite work out which part of aid he was into. I am pleased that the new shadow Minister for trade, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), is in the chamber listening to this debate. He is following a very difficult act, which I will come to in a moment. The right honourable member for New England also said that something like 85 per cent of Australian aid returns to Australia for procurement of goods and services—
Opposition members interjecting—
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Order! The Parliamentary Secretary does not need the assistance of honourable members on my left.

TALK.START.PARA: —The right honourable member also asked how much money would be used for administrative costs, which I was about to elaborate on for the benefit of those opposite. The answer is none. The ADB's costs are paid for by a one per cent administrative fee on loans. Again, I would have thought that would have been known. He was also somewhat confused about how much is being paid to the ADB. As was stated in the second reading speech, payments will be made over the years 1997-98 and the years 2000-01. It will average something like $83m a year compared with the payment of $49.5m made since 1990-91. Therefore, the reason for saying that there has been a decrease somewhat escapes me.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) and the honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie) also commented, in somewhat negative terms, on the fact that Treasury officers have been the Australian representatives of the bank. They were a little critical of that fact. I am pleased that the honourable member for Dundas is with us tonight. The present Australian executive director of the bank's board is from the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau, AIDAB, which of course is the Government's overseas aid agency.

The inadequate level of senior Australian appointments to the bank is a matter of concern to those on the other side. Australian representatives on the bank's board have played a significant role in successfully encouraging the ADB to adapt more transparent staff selection procedures. As a result, it is much more certain that the best person for the job will be selected in future. I think we would all agree that is an appropriate mechanism to put in place.

I was concerned about the rhetoric from the honourable member for Curtin. It was almost a complete misrepresentation of the role of the Asian Development Bank. There is no doubt that the needs of the poorest countries in our region greatly exceed the funds provided by donors, but to say that the ADF is looking for new recipients to use up the funds is somewhat nonsensical. For example, Vietnam is not receiving funds only because it has not yet paid off its arrears to the IMF. Vietnam is making great efforts to comply with the demands of its creditors and is very deserving of assistance from the multilateral development banks. Cambodia, to which the honourable member referred, is also a very needy recipient. I am pleased to say that the ADB's board of directors recently approved a technical assistance project to Cambodia. China has the largest number of poor people but is making great efforts in improving its economic performance. The reason for its exclusion was its creditworthiness; it had nothing to do with any other issue. It does not make sense to penalise a country for performing well; the needs are still very great.

The honourable member for Mayo informed the House that he was making his farewell speech in his role as shadow spokesman for trade. He actually made some points with which I fully concur. The irony of the post-war era is that EC protection keeps out the agricultural exports of developing countries—hence, many of the countries in our region—while giving huge amounts of aid to those same countries. We fully endorse that. That is why we are so active in the Uruguay Round of negotiations. We are concerned because those subsidies and the role being played by European countries hurt not only developing countries in our region but also Australia.

Finally, the honourable member for Aston, in a very cogent and well argued case, clearly reminded us all of the size of the problem in developing countries in our near region. Clearly, he was concerned about ensuring that the importance of our Asian neighbours was recognised by this House and that Australia must have a responsibility for helping those less fortunate countries in our near region. This was clearly demonstrated by his reference to yearly income receipts of Australia compared to those of people in many Asian countries.

As I indicated, I think the range of issues canvassed tonight were appropriate. I am pleased that those on the other side of the House have chosen to support this legislation. I wish it speedy passage through the other place.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Martin) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: CRIMES (TRAFFIC IN NARCOTIC DRUGS AND PSYCHOTROPIC SUBSTANCES) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 5 March, on motion by Mr Duncan:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before the House the Crimes (Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances) Amendment Bill 1992, which seeks to make certain amendments to the principal Act of 1990, which bears a similar title to the Bill under present consideration. Although we have concerns with some aspects of the Bill, and with respect to one of those concerns we will be moving an amendment in the committee stage, at the end of the day we will not be opposing passage of the Bill.

PARA.TAB: On 18 October 1990 the House debated the 1990 legislation, which sought to give effect to the United Nations convention against illicit traffic in narcotic drugs and psychotropic substances which was entered into in 1988. The 1990 legislation was designed to put in place at the Federal level the legislative framework needed for Australia to proceed with ratification of the convention. The basic thrust of the 1990 Act, which is yet to become law, was to extend Australia's extraterritorial jurisdiction over crimes relating to drugs.

Furthermore, and relevantly, subsection 5(1) of the principal Act preserves the division of responsibilities between, on the one hand, the Federal Government and, on the other, State and Territory governments. However, the Bill, for reasons which I will explain in a moment, seeks to alter that division. That is one of the concerns that we have with the Bill, which in due course I will elaborate on. Before addressing the concerns that the Opposition has with the Bill, it is appropriate that I give a very brief outline of the Bill, because it is so long since it was last before this House.

The Bill has five elements. First, the Bill inserts into the principal Act a definition of `serious State drug offence'. Secondly, the definition of `dealing in drugs', as presently found in section 6 of the Act, is to be widened. Thirdly, the Bill will amend the Act to provide that, where knowledge is an element of an offence under the Act, such knowledge may be proved by way of inference from the circumstances surrounding the conduct giving rise to the relevant prosecution. Fourthly, the Bill once enacted will create additional offences under the Act of converting, concealing or acquiring property derived from a serious State drug offence. Finally, provision is made for regulations that may prescribe the States and Territories to which the amendments as contained within the Bill will apply.

The concerns that the Opposition has with the Bill are threefold: firstly, the impact that the amendments may have on the division of Federal-State responsibilities in the area of drug offences; secondly, the definition of `serious State drug offence', and in particular the reference to the threshold requirement that such offences must carry a minimum penalty of 12 months imprisonment; thirdly, the introduction of an objective test for the requisite fault element for an offence under the Act.

I turn now to consider the question of Federal-State responsibilities. At the time the 1990 legislation was debated the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) said that the Government was concerned to respect the traditional division of responsibilities in the area of drug offences. The Attorney also said that the Government would not ratify the convention until consultations with the States and Territories were concluded. In this regard it was envisaged that ratification would not take place until all States and Territories had passed legislation dealing with the confiscation of assets and money laundering in the context of State or Territory drug offences.

However, the Federal Government has now chosen to rely on the external affairs power and the convention to fill the gaps found in some State and Territory jurisdictions in this area. I note that in his second reading speech the Attorney did not say whether or not the States and Territories have agreed to the passing of legislation—which we now find before the House—that will enable ratification to take place.

Whilst I fully appreciate and support the obvious importance of Australia doing what it can to tackle the drug problem, both at an international and domestic level, it is important that the traditional Federal division of power and responsibility not be usurped. Accordingly, I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General (Mr Duncan) to advise the House what attitude the States and Territories have with respect to the amending legislation.

As I mentioned earlier, the Bill seeks to insert into the Act a definition of `serious State drug offence'. In essence, a serious State drug offence is defined as involving conduct that is prohibited by the provisions of section 6 of the Act where such conduct constitutes an offence against State or Territory laws punishable on conviction by imprisonment for at least 12 months. The amendments, once they become law, will have the effect of invoking the additional offences, as contained within this Bill, of converting, concealing or acquiring property derived from a serious State drug offence. I note that the new Federal offences attract, on conviction, a maximum term of imprisonment of 20 years.

The difficulty we have with these provisions is that, having regard to existing State and Territory legislation, the threshold requirement of 12 months imprisonment may be too low. In this regard, there are a myriad of State or Territory drug offences carrying terms of imprisonment above 12 months which, generally speaking, may not be considered to constitute `serious' drug offences. In other statutes, such as the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979, a `serious' criminal offence is defined as involving a threshold requirement that such offences attract penalties involving imprisonment for a minimum of seven years.

In light of the fact that the attitude of the States and Territories to the amending legislation is unknown, there may be a concern that the 12-month requirement is far too low. Again, I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to clarify this on behalf of the Attorney and advise what discussions there have been in selecting and identifying State and Territory drug offences which ought to form the basis for the invocation of the new Federal offences contained within the Bill. The honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) may now be interested in this, being a distinguished member of the Victorian Bar. Proposed section 8A provides as follows:
"8A.(1) If a particular knowledge, intent or purpose is an element of an offence against this Act, that knowledge, intent or purpose may be inferred from objective factual circumstances.
"(2) Subsection (1) is not intended to exclude or limit any other way of proving knowledge, intent or purpose as an element of an offence for the purposes of a prosecution.".

SPEECH.PARA: There is a very real risk that these provisions may alter the burden traditionally placed upon the prosecution to establish the mental element needed to secure a conviction for a criminal offence.

PARA.TAB: I want to trace this point through. I reiterate that we are not opposing the Bill. We may oppose this clause because of the alteration in the burden of proof. The provisions of proposed section 8A reproduce the terms of article 3.3 of the convention. However Australia would not be obliged to adopt word for word the tests set out in article 3.3. In the first place, the convention provides that the implementation of its provisions is subject to `constitutional principles and the basic concepts of the legal systems' of signatories to the convention. Secondly, on a number of occasions the High Court has held that, in passing legislation pursuant to the external affairs power, parliament need not slavishly reproduce the terms of the relevant convention in the form of a code.

Proposed section 8A may introduce into our criminal law an objective test for the establishment of an accused's state of mind. This is contrary to a very long line of authorities. It is very well recognised that establishing the requisite mental element for any offence is in theory well nigh impossible for, as Chief Justice Brian said as far back as the fifteenth century, `The devil does not know man's intention'. Nonetheless, despite these difficulties, our common law has insisted that the relevant test of guilt involves establishing the actual state of mind of the accused.

In this regard, the law is not concerned with the state of mind of some hypothetical or reasonable person. In contrast, proposed section 8A appears to be primarily concerned with the question of whether a reasonable person would foresee the natural consequences of his or her conduct. As a matter of

SPEECH.PARA: principle, this is erroneous.As an example, in the 1952 decision of Stapleton v. the Queen, Sir Owen Dixon said:

The introduction of the maxim or statement that a man is presumed to intend the reasonable consequences of his act is seldom helpful and always dangerous. For it either does no more than state a self evident proposition of fact or it produces an illegitimate transfer of the burden of proof of a real issue of intent to the person denying the allegation.
In a similar vein, Sir Garfield Barwick, in the 1971 decision of Pemble v. the Queen, said:

Although what the jury think a reasonable man might have foreseen is a legitimate step in reasoning towards a conclusion as to the accused's actual state of mind, a firm emphasis on the latter as the fact to be found by the jury is necessary to ensure that they do not make the mistake of treating what they think a reasonable man's reaction would be in the circumstances as decisive of the accused's state of mind.

Although it may be somewhat trite to observe that a jury may always draw inferences as to an accused's state of mind, what proposed section 8A fails to do is state the qualifications to the reasoning process that a properly directed jury should undertake when drawing such inferences.

PARA.TAB: In this regard, I refer the House to the judgment of the Full Bench of the High Court in the 1988 decision of Pereira v. the Director of Public Prosecutions in which it is said that although the necessary mental element may be inferred from the circumstances, there are three qualifications. They are as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: First, in such cases the question remains one of actual knowledge. It is never the case that something less than knowledge may be treated as satisfying a requirement of actual knowledge. Secondly, the question is that of the knowledge of the accused and not that which might be postulated of a hypothetical person in the position of the accused, although, of course, that may not be an irrelevant consideration. Finally, where knowledge is inferred from the circumstances surrounding the commission of the alleged offence, knowledge must be the only rational inference available.

Given that proposed section 8A does not embody these qualifications, there may be an argument that parliament, having turned its mind to the issue, decided to displace its application. In my view, and in the Opposition's view, this would be a most undesirable consequence. For these reasons, as I indicate, at the committee stage we will seek to amend to delete proposed section 8A so that the position at common law may be preserved and protected.

PARA.TAB: I might also add that the provisions of proposed section 8A would appear contrary to the recommendations made by the Committee for the Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law, chaired by Sir Harry Gibbs, in its interim report of July 1990. In that report, the Gibbs Committee recommended that the minimum fault element for a criminal offence should be recklessness. In this regard, the requisite fault element for a criminal offence can be comprised of knowledge, intention, recklessness and negligence. It would seem that the test found in proposed section 8A may be akin to the objective test of negligence. This may mean that a prosecution would only have to prove that the accused ought to have known of the consequences of his or her conduct and the prosecution would not have to establish actual knowledge.

Furthermore, the proposed test may affect the well recognised defence that, in cases of strict liability, it may be a circumstance of exculpation that the accused had an honest and reasonable belief which, if true, would have rendered his or her actions innocent. Given that the net cast by the provisions of the principal Act in terms of offences relating to dealings with drugs is extremely wide, it is in our view wholly inappropriate, as the Gibbs Committee recognised, that the requisite mental element for such offences be anything less than reckless.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

PARA.TAB: That the House do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the House that last Saturday we as a nation celebrated the seventy-seventh anniversary of Anzac—and a proud moment it was too. What I found particularly interesting at my Anzac ceremonies was that increasing numbers of youth came out to participate and to honour the dead—more particularly, on the day that we gather to celebrate Anzac, to express to the living that we honour the dead and pay respects to their comrades who were prepared to sacrifice their lives. That spirit of the youth gathering is important.

PARA.TAB: Today in my electorate office we had a telephone call from an Australian holidaying in the United States who had heard that our Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on Thursday last in Indonesia had the audacity, the unmitigated gall, to tell a foreign nation that in his view our flag was no longer satisfactory; that our flag that so many brave Anzacs fought to defend, gave their lives to defend, is no longer representative of our national interests. It is indeed almost a criminal act that our national leader could so denigrate the spirit of Anzac.

Our flag is a very important national emblem representing our heritage. There may be those in favour of a new flag who will say, `How can you, the member for La Trobe, come to this place as a new Australian and with your accent and claim the flag as your own?'. When I swore allegiance to the Queen, I swore allegiance to Australia and I took Australia as my country. I also accepted the heritage of this country and I accepted the flag that represented that heritage.

We are in fact the sixth oldest surviving continuous democratic parliamentary system in the world. Only Great Britain, the United States, Canada, Sweden and Switzerland have democracies that have been uninterrupted by either dictatorships or military takeover for longer periods than Australia. So we are not a new country; we are an old country with an old heritage, and our flag represents that heritage.

In case honourable members have forgotten, I remind them that in 1851 an anti-transportation league was formed. The anti-transportation league comprised those individuals who were very much against the continuing transportation of convicts from Great Britain to Australia. They formed themselves, through the various colonies, under the name `The League of Solemn Engagement of the Australian Colonies', and in 1851 they took for their flag a blue background with the Southern Cross.

In 1901, when from 35,000 entries was selected the flag which sits today before us and which flies on top of our building, and which represents our country at the Olympics and sporting events and in war, we took the crosses of St George, St Andrew and St Patrick, which represented part of our heritage. We added to them the Southern Cross on a blue background, from 1851, and that represented part of our heritage. We then added to it one seven-pointed star to represent the six States and the Territories. I respect our flag, and I only wish that the Prime Minister would join me. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the Paul Lyneham program tonight the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) was asked this question:

SPEECH.PARA: And we had Doug Anthony the other day talking about you in terms of tariffs, suggesting your sort of academic economic theory approach is the sort of thing that leads to five-year plans in eastern Europe.
The Leader of the Opposition said in reply:

In a sense, I take that as a compliment when people from the past come out with those sort of hardline comments against me when they have had their chance and obviously didn't achieve what they set out to achieve, and that confirms me that I am on the right track.

That is quite an interesting comment from a leader of a coalition party about one of the icons of the National Party, basically saying that Doug Anthony was a failure.Earlier, in relation to the sugar issue, the Leader of the Opposition was questioned by Mr Thompson on the AM program and he said:

Why did Rob Borbidge come out? Why did Ron Boswell come out? They're running their own personal political agendas in Queensland at the expense of the national interest. Quite frankly, the days of pork-barrelling and Queensland-style National Party politics are finished in this country. The electorate won't tolerate it and why should the average Australian. . . .?
It is quite obvious that the National Party is held in contempt by the Liberals—and to some degree I can understand that, but they are in coalition.

PARA.TAB: This week the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott), who is now a shadow Minister, changed his position. I take him at his word when he said today that he does support the coalition's position of zero tariffs and the Fightback strategy; but when he was door-stopped earlier on this issue he said, `I would hope that they would see the Queensland position, to be quite honest'. It was indicated that he was supporting the other point of view. He is now firmly in the Liberal Party camp, and along with his leader, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer)—and I believe both of them to be closet Liberals—he is supporting the Liberal cause. That is in stark contrast to the National Party's position in Queensland.

The National Party members in Queensland have made it very clear that they are protectionists and do not support these sorts of policies. Mr Borbidge said that if he cannot convince the coalition to rethink this issue, the Queensland Nationals might have to reconsider their support for Fightback. The Herbert River Express of 28 April 1992 made the following reference to Mr Bob Katter, one of the candidates for the National Party in Queensland, who comes out with some real pearls of wisdom:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Katter instanced the failure of the oil companies to lower prices in line with a drop in the World price and said it was unlikely CSR would easily give up profits realised through the `Fightback' package and pass them back to growers (through the Division Of Sugar Monies), as suggested by Senator Macdonald.

In other words, the National Party candidate does not have much faith in the comments that have been made by Senator Macdonald. Interestingly, Mr Howard Hobbs, the shadow Minister for lands in Queensland, said in response to an interview question:
We believe there needs to be assistance to keep industry on the road to recovery and so, quite obviously, we do have some problems with regard to the total Fightback package as a whole.
Later in the same interview he said:

In Queensland we certainly aren't doing that. We've always believed that we need to have a certain amount of protection and we have unashamedly in this policy launch put it as a policy of protection because we believe that the people out there need some assistance.
He later added:
We really just cannot get down to having zero tariff barriers in Australia.

It is quite evident from these comments that the National Party in Queensland does not agree with the honourable member for Maranoa or the Federal Leader of the National Party and will run its own agenda once again.

PARA.TAB: I suppose that the National Party has a challenge: whether it wants to lie down and politically disappear or try to restore some of its pride and stand up. If it does wish to restore some of its pride, it has to change its position and leadership. Interestingly enough, if we look at some of the other comments that have come out of the sugar debate over the last few weeks, we find Senator Boswell saying, `We are going to stand by the sugar industry'. Senator O'Chee said:

SPEECH.PARA: The National Party position in Queensland is totally unified. We are opposed to the Federal Government's cutting of tariffs and we are going to fight it all the way, and we ask for a little bit of support.

Senator Boswell said the same. Tonight in the Senate when an opportunity to debate this matter was brought on by the Democrats, what happened to Senator Boswell and Senator O'Chee? Not only did they not participate in the debate; they did not even participate in the vote. They ratted and they ran away.

TALK.START.PARA: —How would you have voted?
—Order!
—All the comments they have made for the past two weeks in Queensland came to nought. It was the `Ron and Bill Show'.
—How are you going to vote?
—Order! The honourable member for Higgins will cease interjecting.

—When it came time to front up, they did not cut the mustard. Quite clearly, the National Party is starting to disintegrate. It has to make up its mind whether it is going to defend people like Doug Anthony—the icons of the Party—or lie down and die. (Time expired)

—Mr Speaker, I have been in this place on a number of occasions listening to these debates and the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) always gets up to speak. Every time he gets up, he criticises the National Party. I think he doth protest too much; he might be a closet National Party member. I might have a talk to him a bit later because every time he opens his mouth he attacks the National Party. All honourable members here would know that; they would hear it in his adjournment speech every night. The honourable member for Hinkler keeps attacking the National Party. If he wants to join the National Party I will send him along a little piece of paper; he can sign up; pay the amount of money and join the National Party. He should not keep on attacking us.

PARA.TAB: I think there is something psychological about this. I think that he really loves us, but he loves to attack us also. We will have to watch the honourable member for Hinkler. I am going to get out all the recordings of the Parliament to see how many times he has attacked the National Party. It is a real worry to me. I am worried about the honourable member and I think he ought to go and get checked out about this. It is a real worry.

Today in this place we were talking about the big zero for inflation. The zero that the honourable member for Hinkler and his Leader should be worried about is not the one zero for inflation, but the six zeros that come behind the figure one and that represent the one million unemployed in Australia today. That is what we should be worried about. Those opposite can talk all they like about the zeroes in inflation, but that is not helping those people who are standing on the dole queues, standing in line at the soup kitchens, because they cannot afford to buy the things they should be able to buy which are affected by zero inflation, or not affected by zero inflation—whatever you like.

Let us talk about the national debt. Let us talk about the divisiveness of the Leader of the honourable member for Hinkler. Today I heard the honourable member for Hinkler give a speech in which he said that our trade with Asia is increasing by 80 per cent per annum. Yet today in this place we heard the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) say, `Look, we don't know about our identity. We have to trade with Asia. We have to get rid of the Australian flag because we have to orientate ourselves with Asia and we cannot do that while we have the Union Jack on our flag'. Why we cannot do so, I do not know, but this is part of the argument.

On the Sunday program I heard the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) say that our trade with Asia is increasing at a dramatic rate. Yet we hear the Prime Minister say, `We have to be orientated towards Asia if we want to do any good'. Someone is wrong. It is a little bit like this argument about the National Party which we hear all the time from the honourable member for Hinkler. I think the Prime Minister ought to get checked out too, because I just cannot follow the logic of the argument. Needless to say, Mr Speaker, that is not what I really got up to speak about tonight. But I am really worried about the honourable member for Hinkler.

The Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) has just come into the chamber and I am sure that he would have enrolment forms for the National Party in his office which we could send to the honourable member for Hinkler. It does not cost much to join the National Party. He would be joining a party that is progressive, that is trying to do something for the people in rural Australia, in most of Australia, trying to get them up and going, trying to get employment going and trying to overcome our national debt.

The thing we want least in this country is divisiveness. That is why the National Party is in very strong coalition with the Liberal Party. We believe we have the policies that will make this country great. We do not need to talk about divisiveness; we do not need to talk about the flag. We know where we stand under the Australian flag. We are proud of our flag. We know where we are going. We know we are Australians. We do not need to wear a T-shirt saying, `I love Australia. I love Asia'. We all know where we are going.
Mr Speaker, I thank you for your indulgence. I say once again to the honourable member for Hinkler that I am going to check out those figures because I am really worried about him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to talk about early intervention and, in particular, the reading recovery program. Reading recovery is a school-based early intervention program. It provides a second opportunity for children in year 1 who, after a year at school, have not established effective reading and writing processes. This is a program which is something extra for six-year-olds. Each child has an individual program designed by a trained reading recovery teacher in response to the particular needs of the child.

PARA.TAB: Let me take this opportunity to tell honourable members a little about this excellent extra learning program. Reading recovery was first trialled in New Zealand between 1976 and 1979. Initially it was a trial and error procedure, although based on thorough research and observation, with follow-up research with the children in 1981. It is now regarded as an established, triangulated program.

The reading recovery scheme currently operates in New Zealand, where it is a national program for the lowest 20 per cent of all six-year-olds. It has been operating in Victoria since 1984 and has involved some 17 tutors, 550 teachers and 4,700-odd students. It has also been operating in the ACT since 1987, and commenced in New South Wales last year. Overseas countries also have reading recovery programs: Ohio in the United States of America since 1985; Canada since 1989 in six out of the 10 provinces; and last year it was taken up by the Surrey Local Education Authority in the United Kingdom.

It is okay to talk about programs such as this, but what about the results? In New Zealand only one per cent of children require further support; in Canberra there has already been a success rate of some 96 per cent. It has, of course, meant quite dramatic changes in teacher training and classroom practices. Trainee tutors undertake a specific training course in a tertiary institution. In Victoria this two-year training course comprises both theoretical and practical components. The trainee tutors attend lectures, in-service sessions and participate in daily teaching of individual children. Once trained, the tutors have the responsibility of guiding the professional development of the teachers in reading recovery teacher in-service programs and the administration of reading recovery in their area.

Experienced infant and junior primary teachers participate in a 12-month teacher in-service program conducted by a reading recovery tutor. This involves attending fortnightly in-service programs as well as daily teaching in their own schools of children in a reading recovery program. The teachers develop an awareness, through observation, of the children's reading and writing behaviour and gain an insight into their own teaching practices. This increased awareness enables teachers to understand the children's problem or problems and to assist in the rapid development of children's reading and writing.

It has been clearly demonstrated that reading recovery is very effective indeed and that it enables students, in an average range of 12 to 20 weeks, to make rapid progress in their reading and writing skills. In fact, the great majority of children within this program change from being ineffective readers to active, independent problem solvers, and are able to meet the challenge of reading and writing full-on in both the classroom and elsewhere.

Why has this program been such a success? It has enabled early detection of reading difficulties—which usually result in writing difficulties—and rectification of this, thus enabling the child to participate fully and effectively in the classroom. The program for the early detection of reading difficulties has given our educators an awareness of what is really needed to effect real change. It has enabled strategy orchestration and observation and reinforcement by teachers. It has been found to be a self-improving system which allows children to aim for independence. The acquisition of literacy involves some of the most complex forms of learning. Even the best schools with the best teachers will have some children who will require something extra.

It is now well documented that failure to achieve literacy in primary schools makes school learning difficult and frustrating and creates employment and lifelong problems. As we would all be aware, poor self-esteem and personal and social behaviour problems are often the result. Ninety-five per cent of the prison population in this country is functionally illiterate.

I have said in this House many times, and I say it again, that education is an investment in the future, and prevention costs less than the cure. I commend those involved in the reading recovery program and wish them every success. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —When the will of the people is clearly expressed in an election, as happened in Wills, it should not be frustrated by an artificial interpretation of the Constitution. Section 44(iv) of the Constitution says that a person who holds any office of profit under the Crown is incapable of being chosen or sitting as a senator or member of this House. It goes back to the early days of English parliamentary democracy when it was feared that the King might buy the loyalty of parliamentarians with patronage. Today there are obvious problems with this provision of the Constitution.

PARA.TAB: The only Australian court decisions on the point are old ones which apply in the States. They give little guidance to candidates for election to the Federal Parliament. People standing for election to this Parliament are presumed to immediately know the answers to such arcane questions as: what is an office of profit? When is it under the Crown? Does `chosen' mean `elected'? I think it does. I ask why public servants are advised by the Electoral Commission to resign before they nominate as candidates rather than before the declaration of the poll, which seems to be the only moment when they could be chosen. These uncertainties are further complicated by the Federal system.

Another problem concerns the purposes sought to be achieved by the office of profit provision. As it has been interpreted, some of these purposes are not desirable ones. Members of parliament obviously should not have the right to draw two salaries from public sources, nor should they, by virtue of continuing to hold some Public Service post, be placed in a position to influence executive government which goes beyond their role as a parliamentarian.

The way the office of profit provision is currently applied makes it a bar to Commonwealth and State public servants standing for parliament. This is because the Electoral Commission makes candidates at the time they nominate declare that they are not disqualified from entering parliament by section 44 of the Constitution. Public servants running for parliament are therefore forced to resign their jobs and gamble their livelihood on the election result. People in private employment do not have to do this. To make matters worse, different States impose different rules when their public servants unsuccessfully stand for election and then try to get their old jobs back.

With the increasing politicisation of the Public Service, the risk is also increasing that public servants who unsuccessfully stand for election will find themselves out in the cold. There is also a double standard. Parliamentary staff have a cosy arrangement. They stand for parliament with a firm understanding that their job will be there afterwards if they are unsuccessful. In practice, it is one rule for the politicians and their retinues and another rule for others.

The office of profit provision in the Constitution discourages public servants from standing for parliament. That is against the principles of democracy and it attacks the democratic right of several million Australians. I think it comes down to what is meant by the word `chosen'. As it is used in section 44, it should mean that one cannot be elected or sit in parliament while holding an office of profit. That would allow anyone to nominate as a candidate, to stand for election and, if elected, to take their seat in parliament provided they resign their Public Service position prior to the official declaration of the poll. This interpretation of section 44(iv) still protects the public revenue. It also prevents parliamentarians from holding a Public Service position and exerting undue influence on executive government. There could be acceptable circumstances in which a parliamentarian can hold some additional position in government such as membership of an advisory board or a rank in the Army Reserve. I have seen the Attorney-General of New South Wales, Mr Peter Collins, wearing a naval uniform. I assume that he must hold some office under the Crown which allows him to do that.

In 1981 the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs made recommendations which would have cleared up this whole murky area. Both major parties have been in government since 1981. They both had the opportunity to do something about it and they did nothing. They are happy to keep millions of Australians from participating in the democratic process. It suits them to throw obstacles in the path of people such as the honourable member for Wills (Mr Cleary) when they stand for election to this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak about heritage. In the last few days we have heard a great deal from members of the Opposition about heritage and what Australia's heritage actually is. I draw their attention to the kind of celebrations that are very much part of Australia's and Australians' heritage which have occurred in the last few weeks.

PARA.TAB: Most of us would know that very recently we had a major Christian celebration—the celebration of Easter. I was delighted to find that in Logan City, a city of 130,000, on Good Friday we had close to 1,500 to 2,000 people turn out for the Passion Play, although as some members of the minister's fraternal pointed out probably more people turned up for the free lunch afterwards. However, that may be a little unkind and perhaps not quite in the spirit of Easter.

I think the Passion Play is a reminder of a part of our European heritage, not specifically British. In fact, the Passion Play comes from Oberammergau and other places. Very many of the participants in the Easter celebrations were from all parts of the world. During the week prior to Easter we had a very large celebration for the end of Ramadan. For those people who may not know, Ramadan is a very sacred time for the Muslim community. Those people fast from sunrise to sunset and pray quite seriously. With the end of Ramadan comes an enormous feasting festival which comprises two or three days of eating, with children wearing new clothes, and an enormous amount of joy. Most of the Muslims in our community look to a whole range of places within the Middle East, the Far East or, now, the Near East, depending upon where they come from.

As well as those celebrations, the New Year has been celebrated by a very different group of people in our community—the Cambodian Buddhists. They, too, found within our community a cause for rejoicing. In fact, hundreds of people turned out for what was a fantastic day. A very special group of Buddhist monks came to our city from Sydney and, indeed, a very special Buddha was brought to the celebration for the occasion. Very many of those people would experience joy in the celebrations not only from having escaped from the horror camps of the killing fields but also from living in Australia and experiencing those things Australian. Their Buddhist celebrations are very much a part of Australia, as are the Muslim and Christian celebrations of Easter.

The period has also been finalised in terms of religious celebrations by the Coptic Christian and Orthodox Easter. That has been marked by a whole range of very large communities in our cities and towns throughout Australia, with great eating, great festivals and great religious celebrations. A very large Romanian group also celebrated widely. It was great for the economy. There were all sorts of new clothes and lots of eating and festivities. Similarly with all our Coptic Christian friends.

I simply highlight these facts to show what Australian society is about. It is about the Christians celebrating Easter, about Muslims celebrating the end of Ramadan, about the Khmer Buddhists celebrating the New Year. It is also about our Orthodox friends celebrating Easter. All of those people contribute to what Australia is and what Australia is about.

I suppose one of the most amazing amalgams of the celebrations was at a Vietnamese wedding. It had all the aspects of modern Australian society; it had the traditional acknowledgment of ancestor worship; it had a Catholic nuptial mass; and it ended up with a Chinese banquet.

When we talk about what our heritage is, who we are, what we are and what we are looking to, we are certainly looking to a future that is very different from what the Opposition members would have us believe as they look back on a past and an empire on which the sun has long since set and of which we no longer wish or want to be part.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 3 September 1991:

PARA.TAB: What was the index of Australia's competitiveness compared with that of Australia's trading partners in each year since 1985-86.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Several measures are available of the international competitiveness of Australian industry. The most commonly used measures are based on indices of unit labour costs (ULC) and prices (CPI and GDP deflators) in Australia relative to our four major import sources (USA, Japan, UK, and Germany) adjusted for exchange rate changes. The following table shows the three indices over the period 1985-86 to 1990-91. A fall in the index implies an improvement in Australia's competitiveness.

Quantitative measures of competitiveness are subject to certain limitations as they make no allowance for other factors affecting competitiveness such as product quality and service reliability. In addition, comparisons are very much affected by the starting point chosen for the purpose.
2. On these measures, between 1985-86 and 1989-90 Australia's competitiveness vis a vis our major trading partners deteriorated by:
14.4 per cent in CPI terms;
11.8 per cent in ULC terms; and
13.2 per cent in GDP terms.

3. These movements in the competitive indices must be placed in context. The substantial depreciation in the exchange rate significantly improved Australia's competitiveness in the two years to 1985-86. The subsequent upswing in the $A exchange rate, in particular between July 1987 and February 1989, when the $A increased by 14 per cent on a trade weighted basis, was an important contributor to the erosion in competitiveness in this period. In the case of the ULC based measure, this deterioration has compounded by a continued steady increase in Australia's wages relative to movements in trading partner countries, as well as slower growth in Australia's productivity performance.

4. Since 1989-90, all three measures have indicated an improvement in competitiveness, reflecting the small $A depreciation during the year and lower domestic prices and wages growth relative to overseas. Overall, since 1982-83 Australia's international competitiveness has improved by around 18 per cent on all three measures.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 3 September 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) What were the levels of investment in the (a) non-tradeables, (b) commodity tradeables and (c) non-commodity tradeables sector in each six month period between 1980-81 and 1990-91.
(2) How is each of the sectors referred to in part (1) defined.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The levels of investment in the relevant sectors for each six month period between 1980-81 and 1990-91 are shown in the table below:ESTIMATES OF BUSINESS FIXED INVESTMENT IN THE TRADEABLE
(1) Any discrepancy in the sum of Commodity and Non-Commodity Tradeable investment is due to rounding.

The data is derived from ABS Cat. 5626.0 Private New Capital Expenditure. This survey's coverage does not include the agricultural and community services sectors, for which comprehensive half-yearly investment data is not available.

The survey does not provide seasonally-adjusted, constant-price data by industry. Industry estimates shown have been constructed by Treasury applying a weighted average of the two asset-type deflators (buildings and structures; equipment, plant and machinery) to the current price industry estimates. This methodology means that there can be a small discrepancy between published constant price total investment and the sum of estimated tradeable and non-tradeable investment for each half-year.

(2) The Australian Bureau of Statistics does not distinguish between tradeables and non-tradeables in their investment data. The figures shown have therefore been constructed based on definitions used in Treasury publications since the last major revision of the ABS Capital Expenditure Survey in 1989.
The definitions, which use the industry classifications from the survey, are as follows:

Non-Tradeable component of Business Fixed Investment: Finance, Property and Business Services and Other Selected Industries (ie Electricity, Gas and Water, Construction, Wholesale Trade, Retail Trade, Transport and Storage) less Other Non-Manufacturing.
Tradeable component of Business Fixed Investment: Mining, Manufacturing, and Other Non-Manufacturing (including communication, entertainment, recreation, restaurants, hotels and personal services).
Commodity component of Tradeable Investment: Mining and Basic Metal Products.
Non-Commodity component of Tradeable Investment: Manufacturing (excluding Basic Metal Products) and Other Non-Manufacturing.

Data limitations preclude a more detailed breakdown of the available industry groupings. Accordingly, the allocation of broad industry groupings between the two sectors inevitably implies a certain lack of precision in the data constructed. The figures are therefore best seen as a guide to, rather than as precise estimates of the composition of investment.

More generally, of course, differences in investment in the tradeable and non-tradeable sectors should be interpreted cautiously, as investment in one sector is likely to be influenced by the efficiency of, and hence levels of investment in, the other sector.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 2 January 1992:

PARA.TAB: Will he examine statements by Mr Justice Vincent in the Victorian Supreme Court in which he indicated that bond-type investments had been fraudulently sold as shares by Farrow employees in the Farrow-Clarke group of building societies to determine whether changes are needed to Australian company or securities law.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: I appreciate and share the honourable member's concern about the fundraising activities of building societies such as those in the Farrow group. However, at present such activities are largely a matter for the States.

When the Heads of Agreement for Future Corporate Regulation were negotiated in mid 1990 the Commonwealth proposed that the Corporations Law should apply to the fundraising activities of building societies and other like bodies in the same way as it applies to companies generally. The Commonwealth was unable, however, to secure agreement of the States and the Northern Territory to that proposal.

More recently, the Ministerial Council for Corporations resolved at its meeting in Launceston on 13 March 1992 to recommend to Heads of Government that they consider whether the fundraising provisions of the Corporations Law should apply to State based private sector business organisations.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 25 February 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Federal Government provided for the monitoring of the foreign acquisition of urban land in Australia from State governments; if so, (a) under what provisions and (b) are State governments bound by any of those provisions.
(2) Do any processes exist by which public objections may be made to the Federal Government concerning acquisition of urban land from a State government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (2) The acquisition of Australian urban land by foreign interests is regulated by the provisions of the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975 (the Act). Under Section 12A(7) of the Act, acquisitions of interests in Australian urban land from:
(a) the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory;
(b) a corporation constituted for a public purpose by a law of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory; or
(c) a local governing body,

ANSWER.PARA: are exempt from the provisions of the Act.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, the foreign acquisition of Australian urban land from State governments does not fall under Commonwealth supervision and the Government has not provided for any mechanism to monitor such acquisitions. Consequently, any public objection to such acquisitions should be directed to the relevant State government.
