TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts and Territories, upon notice, on 2 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has any federal authority investigated whether the ACT Government was responsible for allowing more than 100,000 litres of drainage material to be pumped from a drainage dam below the Belconnen Waste Disposal Area into a tributary of the Murrumbidgee River during October 1991.

(2) If the matter has been investigated, did the investigation indicate that any environmental laws had been breached; if so (a) specifically which laws, (b) if penalties were imposed, what were they and (c) has the ACT Government been required to alter its drainage disposal practices as a result.
(3) If the matter has not been investigated, why not.
(4) Is there any evidence that the disposal of drainage material from the Belconnen site caused pollution (a) in the Murrumbidgee River and (b) further down the Murray-Darling Basin system.
(5) Is any action being taken to reduce the disposal of nutrients such as phosphates and nitrates into the Murray-Darling system from the Australian Capital Territory; if so, what action.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. The discharge of surface runoff water stored in the West Belconnen Landfill on 19-20 October 1991 was not investigated by any federal authority. However, I have been advised by the ACT Government that the discharge was approved by an Inspector of the ACT Pollution Control Authority and was in accordance with the licence conditions under the ACT Water Pollution Act 1984. According to that Act all water which leaves the landfill site must meet the standards set by regulations before it is discharged.
(2) See answer to question (1) above.
(3) The matter was not investigated by any federal authority because it was the responsibility of the ACT Government and was carried out in accordance with ACT laws and procedures.

(4) I have been advised by the ACT Government that there is no evidence that disposal of drainage material from the Belconnen site caused pollution in the Murrumbidgee River and the Murray-Darling Basin.

(5) I am advised that the ACT has a four part catchment management strategy for protecting the Murrumbidgee. This strategy includes minimising the amount of sediment runoff during rainfall, the installation of gross pollutant traps to catch litter and coarse sediment, use of water pollution control ponds upstream of large urban lakes or the river, and the provision of a high quality sewerage and sewage treatment system. The sewage treatment plants reduce the phosphorus in effluent to very low levels. In addition, the ACT Minister for the Environment, Land and Planning has directed that an Environmental Audit of the Lower Molonglo Water Quality Control Centre be conducted to assess the nature, extent and potential impact of all pollutants associated with its operation. This Audit will include the level of nitrates discharged into the Murray-Darling system.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts and Territories, upon notice, on 4 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did the Australian Film Commission invest in the production of the film "Sacred Sex"; if so, (a) what sum and (b) why.
(2) Did the film have an Australian connection; if so, what was it.
(3) Is she able to say whether the film was assessed as having artistic merit; if so, (a) in what respect and (b) by whom was it assessed.

(4) Is she also able to say whether there is a connection between the film and the Rajneesh religious group; if so, (a) were those involved in recommending investment aware of the connection, (b) when did they become aware of that connection and (c) why did they recommend investment if they were so aware.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. The Australian Film Finance Corporation Pty Ltd (FFC) invested in the production of a one hour television documentary entitled "Sacred Sex". The FFC did not provide additional funds for the production of the feature film; (a) $205,474 and (b) the television documentary fulfilled the eligibility criteria under Division 10BA of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, and Australian content criteria, market appeal and investment requirements of the FFC. The latter requires that the producer achieves some form of private sector participation. In this case the producer sold the documentary to the ABC, to IKON (Netherlands) and to television NZ. Film Australia Pty Ltd, as the sales agent for the rest of the world has sold the program to North and South America and is negotiating European sales.

(2) Yes; the television production was certified by the delegate of the Minister as meeting the Australian content criteria set out under Division 10BA of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936; the production entity is entirely Australian owned, the director and the writer are Australian, the bulk of the funding was Australian and all creative control was in Australian hands giving the program an Australian perspective.

(3) The FFC does not make an independent assessment of the artistic merit of projects. It relies on the judgment of broadcasters, distributors and other experts in the marketplace, whose decisions to pre-purchase or invest in the program will have taken artistic merit into account. The FFC invests in "qualifying Australian films" under Division 1OBA of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. The FFC makes its assessment on the basis of the track record of the producer, the financial deal the producer has put together, whether the proposed budget is appropriate to the script and the potential returns to the FFC.

(4) The producer/director and co-producer/ researcher of the documentary "Sacred Sex" had previously produced and directed the documentary "Rajneesh—Spiritual Terrorist" in which the FFC had invested. The FFC is unaware of any connection beyond this. (a) Yes (b) AS part of the assessment procedures of the above project and (c) the project fulfilled the criteria outlined at (3). It would be inappropriate for the FFC to make decisions based on the religious affiliations of the applicants.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Reduction in Wholesale Sales Tax for Passenger Motor Vehicles

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 24 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Are four-wheel drive, off-road vehicles excluded from the five per cent reduction in wholesale sales tax announced in the One Nation ministerial statement he made to the House on 26 February 1992.
(2) Is he able to say whether the majority of off-road vehicles are bought by families with five or more members and are driven on normal roads for 90 per cent of the time.
(3) Does the decision to exclude the vehicles from the wholesale sales tax reduction disadvantage larger families; if so, why was the decision made.
(4) Has the Australian Taxation Office given advice on this tax; if so, what was that advice.
(5) Will he reconsider the decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The sales tax reduction for motor vehicles announced in my One Nation Statement applies to vehicles that are classed as passenger motor vehicles for Customs Tariff purposes. Other types of vehicles continue to be taxable at 20 per cent. These include commercial vehicles (eg. delivery vans) and off-road four-wheel drive vehicles.
(2) Information on registrations of motor vehicles is not available to the level of detail requested.

(3) No. It is worth remembering that imported off-road four-wheel drive vehicles (and other imported motor vehicles that are not classed as passenger motor vehicles for Customs Tariff purposes) are subject to a tariff rate of 15 per cent, which is much lower than the present tariff rate of 35 per cent applying to imported passenger motor vehicles.

(4) The Australian Taxation Office was one of a number of Commonwealth agencies consulted in the development of this measure. The advice obtained from the Australian Taxation Office was largely of a technical nature in respect of how the measure would be administered.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 24 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does a difference between the assessment of medical impairment under Comcare Australia provisions and the assessment of impairment prepared by the American Medical Association affect medical practitioners practising in Australia who are required to make judgments on medical impairment; if so, have those medical practitioners been provided with an adequate explanation of the similarities and differences between the two methods of assessment.

(2) Have administrative difficulties been experienced in distinguishing between the two methods referred to in part (1); if so, as a result, (a) have persons been disadvantaged in the compensation assessment process and (b) will they continue to be disadvantaged.
(3) How long does Comcare Australia take to confirm the arrangements for a rehabilitation program for an injured Commonwealth employee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Commonwealth employees who suffer injuries that result in permanent impairment are assessed according to the `Guide to the Assessment of the Degree of Permanent Impairment'.

The purpose of the guide is to provide an accurate and uniform assessment of claims for compensation for permanent impairment and non-economic loss suffered by Commonwealth Employees as a result of work related injuries.
Comcare Australia developed the guide to meet the requirements of section 28 of the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988.

The Guide is adapted from the American Medical Association's `Guides to the Evaluation of Permanent Impairment'. The two other sources of reference were similar guides used by the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Department of Social Security both of which also relied on the American Medical Association's Guide.

Once a claim for Permanent Impairment is received, an officer of Comcare Australia will evaluate the claim to determine whether a full assessment should take place. Some of the issues considered when determining this are whether rehabilitation treatment has been completed and whether the impairment is in fact permanent.

When it has been established that the claim for Permanent Impairment should be assessed, an appointment with an appropriate medical specialist is arranged. The doctor is provided with the employee's details including a case summary and copies of any relevant medical information concerning the employee's claim.

The doctor is also given an explanation of the purpose of the examination and provided with extracts from the Guide relevant to the assessment of the particular case. The doctor is advised that the assessment is in accordance with Comcare Australia's `Guide to the Assessment of the Degree of Permanent Impairment' and that the guide is based on the American Medical Association's `Guides to the Evaluation of Permanent Impairment'.

As Comcare Australia's guide is based on the American Guide and the methods of assessment under both guides are similar, medical practitioners should have little difficulty in assessing permanent impairment for Comcare Australia.
(2) Comcare Australia has not experienced any administrative difficulties to date as a result of any differences between the two guides.

(3) Comcare Australia's objective in relation to injured workers is to ensure early intervention in the management of the compensation claim to ensure that a vocational rehabilitation program is provided to that worker where the injury results in, or is likely to result in, 28 days or more of incapacity or time off work.
Each Commonwealth Agency has a Case Manager who is responsible for identifying those employees who require rehabilitation and then organising the rehabilitation program.
Comcare Australia ensures that any employees who have had 28 days of incapacity have a rehabilitation plan in place by liaising closely with the Case Manager of the agency.

Once an employee has been identified as requiring rehabilitation, the Case Manager organises a Rehabilitation Provider to assess the employee and submit a Case Management proposal. Case Management plans are agreed to by Comcare Australia within 24 hours of receipt from the Case Manager.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, upon notice, on 25 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: What are the details of Commonwealth funding for the rehabilitation of stroke victims.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The Medicare program provides some assistance to stroke victims via the Hospital Funding Grants to the States which provide a general contribution towards the cost of treating people in public hospitals both as inpatients and outpatients. Medicare Benefits provide benefits for medical services including some used in rehabilitation.

The Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service (CRS) provides rehabilitation programs for people aged between 14 and 65 years, to assist them to obtain or retain employment, or to live independently. The CRS target group includes stroke victims.
The CRS provided rehabilitation programs to 24,786 clients during the 1990-91 financial year, including 603 clients whose major disability resulted from a stroke or cardiovascular problems.

(1) The Defence Housing Authority Act 1987 requires the Authority to produce a three year Corporate Plan annually. Production of the Authority's Corporate Plan involves all of its staff up to and including the Managing Director who takes a close personal interest in its development. Each year the previous corporate plan is evaluated by each of the Authority's Head Office and regional business units.

The Corporate Plan is finalised by the members of the Line Management Group using all of the abovementioned inputs and submitted to both the Board of the Authority and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel for approval.

One staff member at the Senior Officer Grade B level ($51,899 pa), on a part-time basis, coordinates the suggestions from the business units for both Line Management Group consideration and the approval process and then is responsible for the production and printing standards of the Plan.

It includes both the operational and administrative objectives, the strategies by which those objectives will be met and the indicators by which performance against those objectives will be measured and reported in the Annual Report.

The Corporate Plan provides corporate direction for all staff whose involvement in its production gives them a sense of ownership as well as direction. Such benefits cannot be quantified.
